PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ADERMANN; BRAITHWAITE; DRUMMOND; GROOM; MILLAR; ROCHER
PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Discrimination against Women
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''.
And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
1. Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

2. ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parential roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

3. The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
4. The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Drummond,Mr Groom,Mr Millar and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Postal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:
1. that Australia as a sparsely populated continent requires the maintenance of a high quality postal service as a vital means of communication.
2. that the Australian postal service meets the needs of all Australians.
3. that any reduction in Australian Post's monopoly power to carry letters for reward will destroy the concept of the national postal service and result in:
increased rates for mail carried outside the capital cities;
a reduction in mail delivery and collection frequencies in non-profitable areas ;
the closure of post offices.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the powers of the Postal Commission to carry letters for reward should be strengthened to ensure that the national postal service is retained in the interests of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of Insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the N .H.S. and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the taxes of all Australians will be used to finance a dam that would flood the Lower Gordon and Franklin Rivers in South-West Tasmania. Your petitioners declare that the intrinsic values of this area, and the provision of funds from the taxes of all Australians, for the destruction of this area of the National Estate and of world heritage value, does make this a national issue. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government take all possible steps, including financial and legal steps and fulfil its responsibilities under the Australian Heritage Act to prevent the destruction of this area of the National Estate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
2. many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
3. Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
4. the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Macedonian Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
(1) That the Macedonian language be used by Government Departments in multi- lingual publications.
(2) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language as a Higher School Certificate (H.S.C.) subject in Secondary schools.
(3) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language in tertiary institutions and that a course be introduced at Monash University in the Department of Slavic Languages.
Your petitioners, therefore humbly request that Parliament take immediate action to implement the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Henty respectfully showeth:

1. That the proposal to charge local telephone calls on a time basis will increase telephone bills, thereby disadvantaging those people who could least afford it, such as pensioners and other low-income earners.
2. That the proposal to change Telecom into a company would be the first step towards selling Telecom to private enterprise.
3. That the proposal to sell parts of Telecom's more profitable operations can only lead to increased charges, particularly for domestic and country services.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government guarantees:
1. That local telephone calls will continue to be charged on a per call basis.
2. That Telecom will remain a Statutory Authority.
3. That no part of Telecom will be sold, and that Telecom's more profitable operations must continue to subsidise domestic and country services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Civic Public Transport Interchange, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Australian Capital Territory shows:
That the exclusion of Taxis from the Civic Passenger Transport Interchange is an unjust decision and places hardship on the sick, elderly, disabled and the public in general.
Your petitioners therefore pray that immediate action be taken to permit Taxis to use the Civic Public Transport Interchange.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Parliament of Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:

(1) that a clear majority of the electors of Tasmania have indicated by their votes on 5 March, 1983 that they believe the Parliament of that State should be permitted to retain the power to make decisions fundamental to the future of Tasmania.
(2) that such matters as infrastructure development have under the Constitution , been matters for decision by State Parliaments since Federation.
(3) Therefore, that the State Government should be allowed to construct the Gordon-below-Franklin dam without interference or obstruction from the Federal Government or Federal Parliament.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled take no action to remove or lessen this power of the Parliament of the State of Tasmania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that your petitioners are outraged and disturbed by the exportation of live animals for slaughter to overseas.
1. That, as a people of a democratic society, we urge the Australian Government to ban the export of live animals for slaughter overseas.
2. That the export of live horses to Japan for slaughter for human consumption be banned on the grounds that it is cruel and unnecessary.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Podiatry Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of podiatry service for lower fixed income members of the community.

Podiatry is an essential health service especially in preventing greater dependency of older people. It would be much more cost effective to maintain the mobility of older people through adequate and effective services than to force them into premature institutional care.

The fees for repeated podiatry consultations to provide essential ongoing care are well beyond the means of pensioners. Considering that Department of Veterans ' Affairs pensioners are entitled to podiatry care, and this scheme is already operating successfully, we strongly urge that this service be extended to cover all pensioners.

We believe this could be best achieved through including podiatry along with the existing concessions on the Health Care cards. This would enable a flexible system of care through private practice, community health or rehabilitation services. It would also be essential in negotiations with the Podiatry Association to ensure assistance would be available to the house-bound and those in institutions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the Citizens of the City of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holdens, respectfully show:
1. That the management of General Motor-Holdens has failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.
2. That a recent statement attributed to the GMH Managing Director, quote:
'The overall objective of our South Australian rationalisation plan has been to eliminate all productive activities on the Woodville site' end of quote.
This statement has not been refuted.
3. That the elimination of the Woodville Plant will cause enormous social disclocation, hardship and misery to the citizens of Woodville and South Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament of Australia will condemn this callous disregard for the citizens of Woodville and South Australia, and do all in its power to force General Motors-Holdens to retain its operations at the Woodville Plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been approached by a couple of honourable members who have sought to establish when they could make a personal explanation. For today at any rate I propose to allow honourable members to make personal explanations at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I would like your indulgence to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I have. In this morning's edition of the Launceston Examiner-

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, this is a very important and very influential paper. It does not have much respect for certain honourable members opposite. In this morning's edition of the Launceston Examiner there is a report which carries an assertion by Senator Jean Hearn that I am advocating secession and that I am supporting the Tasmanian Autonomy Society. That assertion by Senator Hearn is totally false. I am not a member of the Tasmanian Autonomy Society. I have had no discussions with the Tasmanian Autonomy Society. I know nothing about the aims and objectives of the Tasmanian Autonomy Society and I know nothing about the personalities in the Tasmanian Autonomy Society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I crave your indulgence as I have been personally misrepresented.
—Does the Minister wish to make a personal explanation?
—Yes.
—The Minister may proceed.
—My notice has been drawn to an allegation attributed to the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) in a radio broadcast. I have a report which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A Federal Government Minister allegedly accused Tasmanians of being inbred.
The member for Franklin, Mr Goodluck, said the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, had said he (Goodluck) was inbred like all Tasmanians.
Mr Goodluck said that, because of the commotion in Parliament at the time, he did not hear the exact words of the interjection and it had not been reported in Hansard.
He had called for the logging tapes of Hansard to check Mr Holding's exact words.

I did not use the terms attributed to me by the honourable member. I have taken the matter up with him and indicated to him that I feel that propriety would require him, as he made this statement, to take some action as what he alleges was not recorded in Hansard. He has chosen not to do so. I assure the honourable gentleman that I have absolutely no concern at all about either his paternity or his heredity. What I did say, when the honourable member and some of his colleagues were acting in grievous breach of Standing Orders and challenging your authority, Mr Speaker, was: 'Stop acting as if you are inbred'. Such is the paranoia of honourable gentlemen opposite that they are unable to distinguish between--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is now going beyond the correction of a misrepresentation.
—Sit down, you galah.
—Mr Speaker, I ask the honourable gentleman opposite to withdraw that statement.
—I am sorry, I did not hear the remark.
—The remark was: 'Sit down, you galah'.
—Order! I request the honourable gentleman to withdraw the remark, as the Minister finds it offensive.
—I have difficultly in understanding how he--
—You know nothing about koalas and you know less about galahs.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr Speaker.

—Mr Speaker, I do not wish to make a personal explanation but may I ask for your assurance that, should honourable members be misrepresented during Question Time, adequate opportunity will be provided to them after questions without notice to make personal explanations.

—Of course that facility will be offered. I indicated that because of the changed program I had made a decision in running to call on personal explanations when I did, but no honourable member will be deprived of his rights in that respect.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I would be the first person in this House to apologise if I misinterpreted something that was said. But the statement attributed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), which I think is very appropriate on this occasion, was said. It was heard by many honourable members on my side of the House. It was suggested to me at the time that I take a point of order but I did not. The Minister did say it and I ask him to withdraw it. It is a reflection on not only me but every Tasmanian.
—Order! The honourable member is now starting to debate the matter.

DEBATE.TITLE: CHAIRMAN OF THE AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The grave community disquiet created by the allegations of the Minister for Industry and Commerce against the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than ever before Australia needs an independent, fearless, professional Australian Broadcasting Commission. I would have thought that at the very least that is an issue on which this Parliament might be able to achieve a bipartisan attitude. Perhaps that is an issue on which the much sought after consensus between the Government and the Opposition might be achievable. When the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) earlier this week introduced the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, this Government is committed to maintaining a strong and independent Australian Broadcasting Corporation, able to meet the broadcasting needs of the Australian people.
He went on to say:
The Government is committed to maintaining the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's independent news service.

All I can say at this stage on behalf of the Opposition is that they are sentiments with which we totally agree. It is because of our concern to achieve those objectives and give effect to those sentiments that this matter of public importance is brought forward today. The remarks of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) would have been extraordinary in any circumstances but because of some other events that I will come to in a moment they have been given an added significance. They do represent a matter of very grave concern not only to the Opposition but also, I believe, to many people in the community. In another place yesterday, in answer to a question dealing with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Senator Button said that he would hope that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation acted in these matters without fear or favour. He continued:

That is an appropriate position for the chairman of a body such as the ABC to adopt. My only regret is that the present Chairman of the ABC did not, in my view, always adopt that attitude in the past.

What has Senator Button done since making that extraordinary statement to explain what he meant? He has refused to be interviewed on the matter. He has refused to make any public statements about the matter other than to say that he would write to the Chairman of the ABC about it. What has the Chairman of the ABC, Professor Kramer, said about the matter? Interviewed last night on the ABC program Nationwide she was asked whether she had any idea as to what the honourable senator was talking about. A portion of the transcript of the program reads as follows:
Q. No idea about maybe problems that occurred during the campaign between the ABC and the Labor Party; . . .

A. Well, my understanding is that both major parties felt that our election coverage had been very fair and very reasonable and there has been no complaint of any kind from either party since the coverage.
Q. Are there any stories which have been referred to you or to the Commission that have been rejected which might somehow explain his concern that the Four Corners story was allowed to be passed.
A. No. No. None at all. No.
Q. No stories referred up that you may have expressed dis-satisfaction with that could have filtered back to the Labor Party in any shape or form.

A. Nothing; nothing of any kind. I mean I am absolutely mystified as to what is in his mind, and I do wish he would say what it is because you can't respond to a general accusation that is unsubstantiated.

The Chairman of the ABC is a highly respected public figure of a reputable national broadcaster, the independence of which is an article of faith not only of our parties but also of the Australian Labor Party. Yet one of the most senior Ministers in the Government, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, a person who is a close confidant not only of the present Leader of the Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), but also of the former Leader of the Australian Labor Party, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), and a person who played a major role in writing the media policy of the Labor Party when it was in opposition, makes this extraordinary statement about Professor Kramer.

In isolation, those circumstances would be remarkable-even sinister-in themselves. But when we put them into the context of two other events which have occurred in the past seven days they assume an even greater significance. Everyone knows that last weekend the ABC program Four Corners broadcast what many people regard as a very professional, painstaking and well researched program, one which vindicates the high regard that many people in the Australian community have towards the ABC. It is a matter of notoriety now that that program raised very serious questions about the conduct of the Premier of New South Wales, the National President of the Australian Labor Party, in relation to the administration of justice in New South Wales. If those allegations were true they would go to the very heart of the integrity of the administration of justice in New South Wales. They would call into question the integrity of the administration of justice in New South Wales and, therefore, the good order and government of New South Wales under its present administration.

As a consequence of those allegations there has been a chorus of calls, not just from the Liberal Opposition here and in New South Wales but also from a wide cross section of commentators and the community, for a full judicial inquiry into those allegations. As the Premier of New South Wales knows, as I know and as many other people know, the defamation proceedings which the Premier has decided to use in respect of those allegations are manifestly inadequate to the task of establishing the truth or otherwise of the allegations that were made in that program. Indeed, it is a matter of great disquiet that the Premier of New South Wales should have rejected the calls for an independent judicial inquiry. In relation to the course chosen by the Premier of New South Wales, the Sydney Morning Herald, in its editorial of 3 May, said:

But the libel court, at least in the first instance, does not seem to be the proper venue to have the whole of the Four Corners material adequately ventilated and investigated. The laws of evidence and the special rules relating to libel mean that issues to be argued in a libel court can be drawn quite narrowly.

I remind the House that the Four Corners presentation was no ordinary presentation. It was not a run-of-the-mill journalistic effort that had been put together in a few hours without adequate research. The research into it had gone on for months. As the transcript shows, statements had been collected from many people, including senior and experienced magistrates, whose office and stature made them especially credible witnesses. The transcript went on to say that each of the people who provided statements was willing to give evidence on oath before a properly constituted inquiry as to the truth of the statements they had made. In other words, we have a program which says that it has statements from, amongst other people, magistrates who are prepared to give evidence on oath before a properly constituted inquiry. That was no ordinary program.

The allegations were no ordinary allegations. They imply that the Premier of New South Wales had asked the Chairman of Stipendiary Magistrates to ensure that a Mr Kevin Humphreys was discharged regarding certain committal proceedings which were to come before one of the magistrates. That is in any sense, shape or form no ordinary allegation. It goes to the very core of the administration of justice in New South Wales. It raises very serious doubts about the confidence that the people of New South Wales have in a Labor administration which over the last seven years has had a series of affairs involving, inter alia, a former Assistant Police Commissioner, Mr Allan, and numbers of other activities, particularly by the former Attorney-General, Mr Walker. It is the conjunction of that with the remarks of a senior member of a newly elected national Labor Government that gives to this matter of public importance very special significance.

The third issue that gives particular significance to Senator Button's remarks is the fact that at this very moment the Government is reaching for parliamentary approval to dismantle the existing Commission and to establish a broadcasting corporation. Coincidentally enough, that gives to the Government the power and the opportunity to sack all of the existing commissioners and to establish a new broadcasting corporation.

In giving effect to the recommendations of the Dix Committee at this time, the Government takes upon itself a very special onus to satisfy the Australian public that it will not abuse the power that it is now seeking from the Parliament. It must satisfy the Australian public that, in appointing new commissioners to the ABC, they will in fact be people who will act without fear or favour, that they will in fact be people who will be completely dispassionate so far as political comment is concerned, and that they will in fact be people such as Professor Kramer, who was prepared to authorise the Four Corners program to go to air last weekend according to the principles of the ABC, and that it will not appoint people who may on some future occasion refuse to allow a program of that kind to go to air. I say that as a member of a party that can hardly claim to have received favourable treatment from the ABC over the years. I think I would speak for all members of this House in saying that, when the occasion has arisen, the ABC has not been reluctant to put the heat on both political parties in this place, as befits the role of a truly independent national broadcaster.

So we have this rather remarkable-some would even say sinister-conjunction of events: Firstly, we have a senior member of the Government casting unfair, unsubstantiated, unreasonable and, so far as we can ascertain, unjustified aspersions on the Chairman of the ABC; secondly, this comes within days of the broadcasting of a program that raises the most serious questions imaginable about the conduct of the Premier of New South Wales, allegations which, if true, would undermine the confidence of the people not only of New South Wales but of Australia in the good order and government of the State of New South Wales; and, thirdly, at the same time, we have before this Parliament at this very moment legislation from the Government which will give it the power to dissolve the existing Commission and to take upon itself the power to establish a new corporation and to change completely the identity of the existing ABC.

It is within the grasp and the capacity of the Government to put at rest the concerns and fears I have raised, which I believe the community shares, by answering a number of questions. I am glad that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) is to reply. In his reply, he might care to answer a number of questions. Firstly, he might care to tell the House whether he has complete confidence in Professor Kramer as Chairman of the ABC. Secondly, he might attempt to explain, if he knows, what was in the mind of the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, when he made his statements in another place yesterday. Thirdly, will the Minister repudiate the quite irresponsible, disturbing and unfair allegations that were made by Senator Button yesterday against Professor Kramer? Finally, will he give the House a categorical assurance that, if the conversion of the ABC into a corporation occurs before the litigation between the Premier of New South Wales and the ABC is resolved, there will be absolutely no interference or hindrance of any kind on the part of the Government in respect of the ABC's conduct of that litigation? It is only by giving clear, unambiguous and candid response to those questions that the Minister, on behalf of the Government, can put at rest the grave concerns raised by these extraordinary events of the last seven days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point I make about this matter is that I find it extremely interesting that the motion was moved by the honourable member for Bennelong, Mr Howard. One would have thought that the responsible shadow Minister on the Opposition benches would have been the person who would have put forward the Opposition's views on a matter on which the honourable member for Bennelong places such tremendous significance. The fact of the matter is that the last point made by the honourable member for Bennelong may well be the reason why the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has not been on his feet in relation to this matter today. The last issue raised by the honourable member for Bennelong was that there should be no interference by the Government in respect of the litigation between the Premier of New South Wales and the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The quite despicable suggestion that there might be was put forward here two days ago at Question Time and was categorically denied. One wonders where such a suggestion even came from. SPEECH.PARA: I will start with that issue. That is repeated categorically. TALK.START.PARA: —What about the final two questions?

This Government is totally committed to the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It ought to be remembered that it was the post-war Labor Government which set in place key provisions in the legislation to guarantee the independence of the ABC in news and information.

With respect to the independence of the ABC, I turn at this stage to the record of the people opposite who are now complaining about this issue. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Mr Cohen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Connolly had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr. H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has eloquently set out the dangers that the parties on this side of the House perceive in this Bill. I support the amendment that he has moved and those that he has foreshadowed. The Bill in its present form is very widely drawn. It is a measure which will greatly erode the structure of our long-established and well-tried federal system. As my colleague said, the Bill as it stands is a virtual frontal attack on the federal system in this country. It is a major step towards changing, covertly, not by the proper procedure of a reference to the people, the power balance that has pertained in this country since Federation and which has served us well. It is sincerely to be hoped that, at the very least, the Government will harken to the arguments that will be put from this side for amendments to the measure. To that aspect I will return.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, it would be a sad thing if the people of Australia should form the opinion that all members of the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia, because of their concern about the shape of this particular measure, condone the building of the Gordon below Franklin Dam. That is not the case. Indeed, many members and senators from the Opposition parties are strongly opposed to the construction of the dam and are convinced, as I am, that the majority of the Australian people-especially the young-hold the view that the dam should not proceed. I say in this Parliament that that attitude in the Australian community is a broad-based one. It is not just the 'greenies', as some so vociferously proclaim, who hold that view. As I said, it is the view of the majority of, at all events, mainland Australians. It is the view also of the Australian and New Zealand academies of science. They stress the basic fact that research methods in respect of the rich archaeological evidence, and of the ancient vegetation as evidence of climatic change, continue to develop. Thus the evidence cannot be researched once and for all prior to flooding; that is just not reality. Indeed, even more fundamentally, they stress that the right questions to ask emerge only with the development of science. I have a copy of a letter from the Council of the Australian Academy of Science to the former Prime Minister. As I understand that it is now public property I ask for leave that it be incorporated in Hansard to provide enlargement on the somewhat complex questions to which I have just referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Leave is not granted. —I am trying to conform with a suggestion made by the Whips that we limit our remarks. That was the point of the request for incorporation.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, can I intercede on your behalf. I think it is an important letter. I would like to see it incorporated for the record. I take the point that many honourable members want to speak. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Without trying to diminish the important precedent which as been set in parliamentary procedure, having regard to the submission made on behalf of the Government I am prepared to accede on this occasion.

INTERJECT.PARA: P.O. Box 783 Canberra City Australian Capital Territory 2601 Telephone (062) 48 6011 Telex 62406 ACSCI Cables ACSCICAN
President: Professor A. J. Birch, GMG, PRESAA, FRS

The Academy of Science Council, after inquiries, wishes to comment on its assessment of scientific issues involved in damming the Gordon River. Its conclusion is that the building of the proposed dam would deprive Australian science of a number of unique opportunities.

So much of Australia has been irreversibly altered by human intervention, even before European settlement, but much more drastically since, that the few remaining virtually pristine areas must be preserved for long-term investigation . A major area is contained in South Western Tasmania. Due to its inaccessibility and lack of inhabitation for a long period, it represents a virtually undisturbed remnant of the post-glacial era. It is clearly fragile to any disturbance, not alone due to the physical damage due to a dam, but to the influences which go with this construction and use: roads, the introduction of exotic flora and fauna, the probabilities of much more frequent fire damage, general pollution.

The inaccessibility which has preserved it has also rendered difficult its detailed examination. The difficult terrain and the physical obstacles exacerbate problems of systematic investigation. Although some biological investigations have been carried out in areas to be flooded, it is clear that these are rather sporadic and do not approach the systematic long-term work for which there is need and opportunity. Micro-flora in particular require more work . Of invertebrates little is known, except that freshwater ones are unexpectedly diverse. This, and ecological questions, may be correlatable to factors such as diverse but stable habitats, and to the biogeographical history of the area. Nobody knows.

The use of the ancient huon pine potentially to date climate changes, of world significance, back as much as 11,000 years, which is a unique world opportunity, would be inhibited to an unknown extent by flooding of sites for material.

It has been stated that only a small part of the site is directly involved, and that investigations now can provide what information is potentially available. The portion of the site directly involved is in fact a quite large proportion of the critical area, and the whole area is likely to be indirectly affected as noted already. Furthermore, there is insufficient time, or people available, for the researches. Even more fundamentally, we do not now know all of the right questions to ask, and the future will also undoubtedly supply new methods of investigation. It is one of the tragedies of archaeology, that many prime sites have been destroyed before the right questions were asked and the powerful new methods used. Archaeology is also not just a hunt for artifacts and bones but a most laborious, sophisticated use of scientific procedures. The complete destruction of sites by even the most modern is likely to forestall yet unasked questions, and methods not yet contemplated. They should remain available indefinitely.

All of this amounts to a plea for minimum present disturbance of the biological and archaeological situations. The last in particular represents a unique opportunity to examine a period of human development, not available elsewhere.

The scientific arguments are therefore more complex than statements that certain species will or will not disappear. What would disappear is a unique picture of knowledge and understanding in a unique area for which we are responsible to the world at large as part of our common heritage. We are also responsible to our own grandchildren and their grandchildren not to deprive them of unique scientific, as well as other opportunities resulting from our own short-term and probably insufficiently considered alleged needs. Further detailed information could be provided on request.
The Council of the Academy of Science wishes to add its voice to those calling for no dam construction.
The Right Honourable Malcolm Fraser, CH, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I referred a moment ago to the young people of Australia. Let me say this: It grieves me that their aspirations and ideals should have got so tangled up, so fouled up, if I can put it that way, with this far-reaching Bill which has been brought in at this stage, in the almost poisonous atmosphere of the gross failure of the Government to enter into serious, persistent, effective, sincere and meaningful negotiations on this great matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I was saying how broad-based is the judgment that the dam should be stopped. I mention in that connection only that the Young Liberal Movement of Australia, for example, to a man, and to a woman, takes that view as, for that matter, do many, if not a majority, of State Liberal members in the New South Wales Parliament from Mr Greiner down. This perhaps is not the context in which to go over the arguments for not proceeding with the construction of the Gordon below Franklin Dam; rather, we have to look, as my colleague said, to the insidious attack that this Bill makes on the federal system in this country. However, the arguments for not proceeding boil down to this-the recognition, which I have said is very broad-based and is held not least of all by the World Heritage Committee itself-that South West Tasmania, in terms of its physical beauty, its natural features and its archaeological and anthropological richness, is of outstanding value and importance not only to Australia but also to the world as a whole.

To that one may add that the economic case for the dam, given the question marks over the growth of the demand for power in Tasmania, is at best uncertain. Finally, as to the argument which is much favoured by the Premier of Tasmania that employment in the construction phase of the dam is important to Tasmania, I can respond only by pointing out that to construct a dam for that purpose would surely be the most perverse and expensive make-work program one could possibly conceive. There are assuredly other more sensible alternatives to meet Tasmania' s acknowledged problems. We would all back them to the hilt, as I hasten to assure my colleagues and I hope still my friends from Tasmania. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), who preceded me in this debate, talked a lot of mythology about Tasmania and the Hydro-Electric Commission, but not so much, I think, in this area of job generation.

Beyond that very brief statement of the case for ceasing construction of the dam, I am bound to take this opportunity to set the record straight on some of the more misleading things that have been said on this matter. One of these is the claim that the World Heritage Committee, by listing the South West Tasmania area when it was informed that the dam was to be built, thereby condoned the building of the dam. That is not correct. I refer to Dr Ralph Slatyer, not your 'academic greenie' but a hard-nosed scientist whom the Liberal-National Party Government appointed as Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation; he held that post until 1981. I now hear that former Prime Minister Mr Gough Whitlam is to take over that job. Ralph Slatyer, hard-nosed scientist, former Ambassador to UNESCO and currently Chairman of the World Heritage Committee, has categorically stated that the view that the Committee condoned the dam in that way 'is definitely not the case'. He went on to refer to the strongly worded statement by the Committee urging the Australian authorities-that is the phrase that was used-to take all possible measures to protect the integrity of the property, that is, it was saying that the dam should not be built. He makes it quite clear that the Committee proceeded to the listing 'in spite of the planned dam in the hope of sharpening public opinion and bringing about rethinking on the part of the Australian governments'. He added:
Sites listed by the committee are the modern equivalent of the seven wonders of the world.

He said that if the building of the dam on the Franklin River went ahead, South West Tasmania could be delisted as a site and that if it were this would be 'the first time such a thing has happened'. I suggest to this House that most people hope that Australia would not be the first country to have an area delisted.

The second point that needs to be set straight concerns the rather rabble- rousing speech made last week by Premier Gray to the Constitutional Convention that even got the name of Colonel Gaddafi of Libya into the act. For the record, the World Heritage Committee does include Libya. It suffers under the Colonel, no doubt, but also includes certain important monuments, as does Egypt and Iraq, who are also members of the Committee. But also that Committee includes France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Switzerland and-wait for it-the United States of America as well as Australia. There is no question that those substantial Western powers were outvoted or otherwise lent upon or outmanoeuvred by the Libyas and Bulgarias referred to by the Premier.

The third point I make is: Are the Australian people aware that all of this fuss is over a dam to produce a mere 180 megawatts of power? Compare that with the Eraring station in New South Wales to produce 2,650 megawatts, Vales Point producing 2,150 and the new Loy Yang power station in Victoria to produce 4,000 megawatts. Honourable members can get some perspective of the 180-megawatt station when they compare it with the 2,650 megawatts at Eraring and the 4,000 megawatt station at Loy Yang.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a great disproportion between ways and means.

—Yes, indeed as the Minister says. Of course those stations I have referred to are coal fired. I think that underlines that the small 200- megawatt thermal station as proposed by the previous Government would, with adequate planning, siting and modern methods of control, result in few pollution problems as indeed has been recognised by the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said all this, when we turn to the Bill before the House what do we find ? I come back to what my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) so ably said. For reasons known to itself the Government chooses to go beyond what is required for the purpose before us of preserving South West Tasmania for future generations and for science, and brings in a wide ranging Bill enormously extending the powers of the Federal Government, without the due process of constitutional change, grossly increasing the powers of the Government in a way quite unacceptable to this side of the House.

Under the definitions of clauses 2 and 6 of the Bill the Government would have the power to declare any hillock, local waterfall or alleged Aboriginal sites- areas not within a cooee of World Heritage areas-and to do so against the wishes of State governments and local council authorities. Why the Government has taken this course, I am not aware. I sincerely ask the Minister in charge of this Bill , the Honourable Barry Cohen, to explain to us why this is so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I interrupt to say that there has been a tendency today for honourable members on both sides of the House to refer to members in terms of their surnames rather than their electorates. I ask all honourable members to note the complaint that I have made.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. I request the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) to provide us with a direct answer. For the reasons I have stated, my colleagues and I will be moving a series of amendments designed essentially to contain the thrust of this Bill to world heritage properties and in particular South West Tasmania-after all it is called the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill-as well as attempting to clear up a number of other problems in the Bill, specifically related to compensation that could be of very great significance to individuals with properties under threat. Then, with those amendments accepted, the measure can pass this Parliament on a substantially bipartisan basis. We can join together to preserve South West Tasmania for Australia and, indeed, the world for this and future generations so that, to quote the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, in his policy speech of February last, 'it can be enjoyed and preserved for our children'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill I must congratulate the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards). There was a lot of good material in his speech and I hope that our Tasmanian colleagues take note of it. Probably there was less conviction in his argument when he became concerned about the Bill. In supporting this Bill I am deeply conscious of the apprehensions felt by many Tasmanian workers and their families. They have unfortunately become entrapped in a treacle of half truths and fear produced by the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission and retailed by the many myopic politicians who come from that State. In the sphere of the intellect, we have in this Parliament representing Tasmania a collection of giant pygmies. To compound that contradiction, I point out that they come in all sizes. This is a very unhappy situation and I will refer to it at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I must also say that I do not hold with all the people loosely called environmentalists. In my opinion, many of these environmentalists are suburban hedonists, people who have the affluence and the time to enjoy these remote localities and do so. It is an opportunity that many people in the community simply do not get. Even worse than these hedonists are those to whom I refer as environmental fascists who have simply elevated their conception of the environment and made it a fuhrer to which they tend to direct all their regard. They have no consideration at all for other people's views or, in many cases, the concept of joint use. This is not to say the wilderness concept is not valid . I believe it is valid and is endorsed by an overwhelming number of Australians .

The abdication of power that has occurred in Tasmania is almost beyond belief. The Hydro-Electric Commission is the real government of Tasmania and, like all absolute powers, it corrupts. The HEC has as its main concern its own self- perpetuation and in its pursuit of this self-perpetuation it has become enmeshed in self-deception. This self-deception is based on the concept that building dams and creating more electricity will create more jobs. This is very self- deceiving. My colleague the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) has already explained the consequences of this error and I will not go down that road at this stage.

I turn to the economic arguments. The Hydro-Electric Commission's economic scenario calls for a growth of 2.9 per cent per annum in power use between 1981 and the year 2000. Should this rate fall to 2.2 per cent or less per annum, the coal-fired option would become cheaper. That is the position even on the HEC's own plan. The HEC was 30 per cent out in its estimate of power demand in relation to the Pieman scheme-30 per cent in only 10 years. That says something about the HEC's ability to play with figures. The Pieman scheme was also subject to cost overruns and the HEC admits that the cost of hydro schemes is rising faster than the general rate of inflation. This economic scenario is cause for even more disquiet when it is realised that this reversal of relative costs comes about when only one variable-the demand variable-is considered. When other variables such as the future cost of coal and the rate of inflation are considered, the costing of the HEC becomes even more suspect.

All these things demonstrate the ostrich mentality of the HEC. Coal would give greater flexibility to the hydro scheme as it would allow the lake system to be run down with more safety. I do not think anyone would deny that it is a good thing to have flexibility in anything as basic as a power supply scheme. The coal option would also provide many more full time jobs. Tasmania has inland from Bell Bay one of the most easily exploited coal fields in the world. The railway already exists and the coal could be delivered to Bell Bay at very competitive rates. The HEC has not properly looked at the economics of this, and , regrettably, neither has the Government of Tasmania.

It is sad that the constitutional problem here-the State of Tasmania is taking the Government of Australia to the High Court-will stand or fall on section 51 ( xxix) of the Constitution; that is, the external affairs power. Section 51 (xx), which deals with power over corporations, and section 51 (xxvi), which gives the Commonwealth power to make laws in respect of Aboriginals, both relate back to this external affairs power. Therefore, it is my belief that the action will stand or fall on section 51 (xxix). One can only hope that with the departure of Mr Justice Barwick from the High Court the court will practise more intellectual rigour than it has done on previous occasions.

I now turn to the behaviour of the Liberal Party members in this House. I exclude those Liberal Party members who are, understandably, embarrassed. There has been some suggestion by some honourable members-I think by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) to whom I would be quite happy to extend Tasmanian status-that this Bill is some draconian power designed to further the cause of some centralist bogey. In my opinion, the Bill is specifically designed to cover the intransigence of that very obtuse gentleman, the Premier of Tasmania, and it relates specifically to this dam.

How would one describe these members from Tasmania? One gets lost for euphemisms on an occasion such as this. I think of them as some sort of maggot in the collective intellect of Tasmania. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman), with all the Gilbertian pomposity of a retired major, was a half colonel in the Army. The reason the Army only made him a half colonel was that most of the time he is only half there. The honourable member for Bass suggested that the use of the Royal Australian Air Force was not legitimate. The exercise was perfectly legitimate. Most people in Australia accept that the Air Force has the technology, the ability and the best people to undertake this sort of task. Most people in Australia applaud the Government for using the Air Force to take photographs of the area. Honourable members in this House call for the armed forces to be used to help the civil community on many occasions. I believe the forces should be much more involved in civil works.

As I said before, I am really searching for euphemisms in trying to describe honourable members from Tasmania. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) is a very ordinary and a very unctuous little man, but he has introduced burlesque into this House. There was much breast beating here yesterday with the utmost insincerity. He spoke of some threat to Tasmania. He talked of confrontation. This Government is not a confrontationist government. We had a situation in which the Premier of Tasmania was threatening the Government of Australia with his police force. The best way in which to avoid this confrontation was to take the course which the Government did. I do not back away from it in any way at all. I do not think it was a mistake. I commend the Government for it.

Let us look at the hypocrisy of this unctuous little man. He called upon the Government of Australia to send the Army into Tasmania. He was prepared to set the Army on citizens of Australia. He was prepared to set citizen against citizen. In those days, as late as last December, the honourable member for Franklin wanted to send the Australian Army into the Franklin Dam area to round up all the environmentalists.

TALK.START.PARA: —To put the Army on standby, that is right-Bellamy included.
—There we have, from the honourable member's own mouth, an illustration of his hypocrisy.
—It is not hypocrisy.
—Oh, yes-absolute.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to address the Chair.

—The long term development of Tasmania must depend on providing jobs on a long term basis. It must be evident, even to Opposition members, that one cannot go on building dams forever. There must be a limit to the number of dams that one can use, even if one uses them for fish ponds. The electricity will obviously not be needed. Tasmania should be looking very closely at other industries. It may well be that the Hydro-Electric Commission, which has a marvellous technical expertise, would also be very good at building roads. On my last trip to Tasmania, I thought that the roads there could do with some upgrading. If Tasmania could upgrade its roads, it could enhance the tourist industry. It may be able to get people up into various areas to see some of the beauty spots that the island contains. Tourism is an industry in which there are real prospects of growth and in which one can sustain long term improvements.

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania should also, perhaps, be looking at modifying its education system so that it is turning out the sorts of people who can grasp the new technology. It is in those areas that the future and salvation of Tasmania must lie. I urge honourable members who come from Tasmania, instead of adopting the very parochial stance that they do in going on with all this meaningless posturing and breast-beating, to give serious consideration to the real problems that beset Tasmania and not to try to build a smokescreen around some issue of nebulous States rights.

I come from an electorate that is many times bigger than Tasmania, an electorate that contributes very much more than Tasmania does to Australia's overseas earnings. It is an electorate which is very disparate and which covers all sections of the community. I represent to that electorate the Government of Australia. I do not flinch from that at all. I believe that in Australia we are one nation. We are all Australians. The Federation of this country came about at a time when that, perhaps, was not so. But history has welded this country into one nation. It is a matter of grave concern to me and a source of great grief that some people, for the most tawdry reasons, are setting to in an attempt to demolish this growth of Australian nationalism, the concept of Australia as a single nation.

I do not believe that today the great majority of Australians still hold with States rights and parochialism. I do not believe that the great majority want to see Australia go down a banana republic road, so that we would have in the world the Dominican Republic, El Salvador and Tasmania. It is very sad that this Parliament and country are being used as a forum to perpetuate that sort of dissent in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I should like to congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your election to your important position. We certainly wish you well in that position. This is an historic Parliament because, for the first time in our history, we have not one member on the Government side from one of our States. I ask honourable members to consider the significance of that fact. We have a new government, elected with a significant majority. But on that side of the chamber there is not one member from Tasmania. There is no one on the Government side with the local knowledge to speak on all the issues of concern to Tasmania. This is an historic fact and it has some real significance. Why did the people of Tasmania refuse to elect a member of the Australian Labor Party to this House, the people's House? The reason was--
—Fear.

—As the honourable member for Kalgoorlie said, they feared the Australian Labor Party and what it planned to do to Tasmania. I am the local member for this area and we have had this issue for five years or so now. We have had in Tasmania a State election, a referendum and the Federal election. There are people on the other side of the chamber who believe that they know all about Tasmania, having been down there maybe for a day or two. They pretend that they know more about our local situation, and South West area, the Franklin River, the Gordon River and our power needs than ordinary decent Tasmanians.

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy is that the Australian Labor Party and the present Government have been conned by the Tasmanian Wilderness Society, which is not a Tasmanian-based body but a national body based on the mainland. It is headed by a number of fanatics, including Dr Bob Brown. People on the mainland have said that there is concern on the mainland; we are getting a lot of letters from members of the public; there are a lot of letters in the papers; there must be concern. I must say that the Tasmanian Wilderness Society has conducted a very efficient campaign. It has been a very professional and slick campaign. If honourable members want to know why they have received lots of letters and why the media has been bombarded with letters from so-called concerned people about the South West, I suggest they look at some of the tactics of the Tasmanian Wilderness Society. I refer to a letter dated 23 November 1982, signed by Bob-that is not Bob Hawke but Dr Bob Brown. In that letter to people in the Tasmanian Wilderness Society all around Australia he urged them to write furiously to their Federal politicians and to bombard the media, the papers, the television and the radio. The Society put out a dossier on the tactics of interviewing a Federal member of parliament. It advised people not to let the member ask them questions, but to make sure that they continued to ask him questions; how to organise delegations to see local members. This concocted campaign has resulted in an emotional response from many well-meaning people on the mainland.

I ask honourable members on the Government side not to underestimate the depth of feeling in Tasmania. It is not just among people employed by the Hydro- Electric Commission; it is right throughout the Tasmanian community. Ordinary, decent, hard working Tasmanians-not just archeologists, academics, trendies, Dr Bellamy-types from the United Kingdom-feel that the Hawke Government is taking away something that is very precious to them, namely, a large part of our State. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) talked about Tasmanians as vandals. A lot of unfair things have been said about Tasmanians in this House. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) did himself no credit when he referred to the five members from Tasmania, the only Tasmanians in this House, as maggots. The honourable member for La Trobe referred to Tasmanians as vandals .

We are very proud of our record in Tasmania of looking after our environment. Some honourable members have gone with the Tasmanian Wilderness Society and camped on the Franklin River or the Gordon River. But have they really seen Tasmania? Have they seen how beautiful our State is? I am sick and tired of people referring to Tasmanians as vandals. We have protected our environment far better than any other State has. Twenty-seven per cent of Tasmania is national park or conservation area. We have the beautiful Freycinet National Park. How many honourable members have been to that beautiful Freycinet National Park, which I believe is our great national park in Tasmania? I wonder how many people know where is is. How many honourable members have been to Cradle Mountain and Lake St Clair National Park? How many of them have walked through the beautiful bush lands of Tasmania and seen our wonderful beaches? What about the Arthur River? When the radicals from the Tasmanian Wilderness Society come to see me and start asking questions, not knowing that I happen to be the local member and have lived in the area most of my life, I say to them: 'What about the Arthur River?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have never heard of the Arthur River.

—They have never heard of the Arthur River. The Arthur River is our great river-and our great wild river. I suggest to anybody who wants to go and see the beauty of Tasmania that they should go to the Arthur River. Does the honourable member for Kalgoorlie know where the Arthur River is?
—Yes, in the south-west of Western Australia.
—That is about the standard of his knowledge of Tasmania.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to speak through the Chair and not to invite interjections.

—We talk about the power needs of Tasmania. We had a speech from the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), who gave us lots of facts and figures. He also ridiculed Tasmania. His speech was a very patronising speech. It was one that should have been given to students at a university. I think he was formerly a lecturer. He really lectured to us, particularly to the Tasmanians. He tried to tell us what he thinks we should know about Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: In political terms, this is a sad day because the reason this Bill is before the House is that honourable members on the Government side have been influenced by this pressure group-these trendies and radicals who are using the Franklin River as a cause. They are not really in love with the Franklin River but are political animals who are against all progress and all development of this country and are just using this river for their own purposes, and some of them to advance their own causes. Many of them like to grandstand, including Dr Bob Brown, who goes all around Australia. He is a well known grandstander. He was a grandstander before he became involved in this issue.

The Franklin River is a beautiful river but what honourable members have to realise is that 88 kilometres of that river will remain untouched. The upper river is untouched-and that is the beautiful part of the river. Any honourable members who want to raft down the river or canoe down the river will still be free to do so. To those who are listening, to young people who are concerned and to those who have a genuine feeling for the area, I say that they can still go down this river and enjoy the beauty of the South West even when the dam is built. Eighty-eight kilometres of the river-some days trip-will still be a wilderness area. We have a great heritage in the South West and we intend to ensure that that heritage is protected for future generations. But the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian people have a responsibility to make the most of their resources and, knowing the State as they do, to make the most of their opportunities. That is what the present Tasmanian Government is all about.

I believe this Bill is a device to take over State responsibilities. The Tasmanian Government has been responsible for land management for many decades and has done a very good job in Tasmania. This Bill is a device to centralise power in Canberra. I ask honourable members to consider the attitude of the new Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He is a well known centralist. Let us speak about facts. That is the truth. Does anyone on the Government side deny that fact, that he is a centralist?

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that mean?

—It means this: He wants one government and one parliament in Australia . If honourable members doubt that, I suggest they get a copy of the small book The Resolution of Conflict by R. J. L. Hawke, a book containing the 1979 Boyer lectures which were given by Mr Hawke, who was not then in the Parliament. It is stated on page 18 of that book:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the logical implication of this analysis is that Australians would be better served by the elimination of the second tier of government-that is, the States--

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.
—Does the honourable member agree with that? How many others agree with that?
—Put up your hands.
—They should put up their hands. Does anyone not agree with that?
—Order!
—Mr Deputy Speaker, there were hands raised--
—Order! Again, I invite the honourable member not to invite interjections.

—They are coming anyway, Mr Deputy Speaker. There were a number of hands raised in support of that contention and when I asked whether anyone opposed that idea, no one raised his hand. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the elimination of the second tier of government-that is the States-which no longer serve their original purpose, and act as a positive impediment in achieving good government in our current community. This would give us, like the great majoirty of other countries, one Parliament with powers available to the government to match the responsibilities upon it of protecting and advancing the interests of Australian citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is right, you know.

—Again, the honourable member interjects that the Prime Minister is right. The fact and the reality are that we do have a Federation. Australia is a Federation. Our founding fathers came together and the States came together to form a nation. They specified that certain powers should be given to the Commonwealth, and only those powers.

SPEECH.PARA: People who live in a small State such as Tasmania deeply believe in the Federal system. It is all very well for people who live in Sydney or Melbourne. They are in a power base, are close to Canberra and close to the seat of power. They can influence the seat of power. But when people live in an island State, the smallest State in the Commonwealth, and a long way from Canberra, they believe very deeply in the federal system. They desire to have a State Parliament and a State government.

The only reason this issue is now before this Parliament is not because of any great concern for the environment; it is because the greenies, who initially believed that they could influence the Tasmanian people to agree with their fanatical views, failed. They told us that they would win a number of seats in the State parliament. Dr Bob Brown stood for the State Parliament. He saw the State Government of Tasmania as the responsible organ of Government. He failed to be elected initially. The greenies failed dismally to convince the Tasmanian people of their cause because the Tasmanian people can see through what they are all about.

We have a Government which says that it is concerned for consensus, that it wants to bring Australia together. These are fine words but, when we look at them from the Tasmanians point of view, what do they mean? Let us look at the record. Firstly, we had the spy plane incident. We can see that that was not a particularly significant incident. But in that incident our Defence Force, in which the Tasmanian people and, I gather, the people of all the States and Territories have always had confidence, was used for a partisan cause, because there is an action now before the High Court of Australia between the Commonwealth of Australia and the State of Tasmania. Ministers of this Commonwealth Government instructed people in the Defence Force to use a Mirage, initially, and an F111-and there may have been three or more flights, we do not know yet-to take photographs of the South West for a partisan cause. It is clear that the defence forces themselves are not particularly happy about what has happened, but the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) and Government supporters apparently still consider that it was a proper use of the Defence Force. It is most offensive to the people of Tasmania and, I believe, most offensive to people in all States of Australia, when the Defence Force is used for blatant political purposes.

I hope we will have a chance at some stage to debate the regulations. I ask Government supporters to think about the way in which the Government has put up these concocted, draconian and oppressive regulations, under which the ordinary decent, hard working people of Tasmania could be fined up to $5,000 for merely doing their job for a public authority. Did this Government, which believes in consensus, have the decency to permit those regulations to be debated publicly? The answer is no; it did it all in secrecy. To this stage they have not been debated in this Parliament. The regulations were disgraceful and totally oppressive. It is disgraceful that the Government was not prepared to have them debated properly in this Parliament so that honourable members could express their points of view.

Now we have this particular device, the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill, as well. I say to honourable members from all States: Look carefully at what this is all about. It does not affect just Tasmania. It is a real attempt by Hawke, Evans and others to take control of this nation. If there is one thing that Australians should be wary of it is a man with too much power.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a lot of hypocrisy.
—Order! I ask the honourable member not to interject. The word 'hypocrisy' can be regarded as offensive.

—I am endeavouring to make a serious point yet, again, there is laughter from the Government side. My point is that we do not want a dictator in this country. I am not suggesting that Hawke is a dictator, but we do not want anyone to be given the opportunity in future years to become a dictator. The best protector of individual freedom in this nation of ours is the division of power, whereby not one parliament or government is all-powerful but power is divided between the government of the Commonwealth and the governments of the respective States. There are greenies and environmentalists who say that the Commonwealth Government should look after this matter, but that suggests that the Commonwealth Government is superior to any State government, that it will always protect the environment more effectively and with greater feeling than will the States.
—That is very true.

—I ask honourable members to consider history. What will happen if someone who wants to mine all these national parks comes to power and signs a treaty with a right wing government elsewhere in the world or if this Parliament and the Commonwealth Government become all powerful and mine all the national parks of this country?
—Haven't you read the Bill; it will stop that.

—I am suggesting that Government supporters think of the future. Those who think they are wise in what they are doing and who believe that they are protecting the environment should look at this matter with a wider perspective and consider what might happen in the future if power in this country becomes centralised totally in the one parliament. Geographically, we are a large country. It is sensible and proper that we have a division of power. Tasmanian representatives have a duty and responsibility to argue their case. That is why we are in this Parliament. We do not apologise for our strong stand. It is one that we will continue to take.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your election to your high office. I am very proud to see you there. I know you will do justice to the job. I offer you my full support at all times. I hope you will be in the job for many, many years to come.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been listening to the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom). I do not intend to deal for too long with the argument that he put because I do not believe it deserves any great attention, but, as we listened, we found that no real argument was put as to why the dam should be built or why Australians should be destroying the wilderness areas of Tasmania. I feel the honourable member's argument was a nonsense. It had no real relevance to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill whatsoever. The Tasmanian members have become so totally paranoid about F111s, Mirage jets and the Special Air Service that they have been paying no real attention to what will really happen in Tasmania if the wilderness areas are destroyed as the Tasmanian Government is trying to do.

In wilderness is the preservation of the world. This philosophy is particularly relevant to the passage of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983 and the fate of South West Tasmania. Today, we are not debating the property of Tasmania or the property of Australia but the property of the peoples of the world. It is not the property of the shortsighted honourable members who represent Tasmania here today. As a signatory to the United Nations Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage, the previous Government acknowledged Australia's international responsibilities to preserve our heritage for generations to come. By inclusion of South West Tasmania on the World Heritage List, at the request of Tasmania-I repeat, at the request of Tasmania-Australia committed itself to preservation of the area.

Disgusted at the previous Government's lack of resolve in carrying out its responsibilities, Australians gave the Australian Labor Party a clear mandate to take whatever action is required to save South West Tasmania. This Government suffers from no such lack of resolve. We are clear in our commitment to carrying out our wishes and the wishes of the Australian people. Let us have no doubt about the importance of the dam issue in the recent Federal election, the Flinders by-election and the Tasmanian dam referendum. I have heard a lot of nonsense here today. Let us have some real figures. Forty-two per cent of voters in the Flinders by-election wrote 'no dams' on their ballot papers; Milo Dunphy, the 'no dams' candidate in the seat of Bennelong, the seat of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), polled 14 per cent of the votes in that electorate in the Federal election; it was the highest independent vote ever recorded in Australian politics. I hope that the Tasmanian members are taking note of some of the figures. The Tasmanian dam referendum offered only two options-Gordon above Olga or the Gordon below Franklin. Again 45 per cent of people voted informally with 8 per cent voting for the less harmful compromise of the Gordon above Olga. No clear majority can be claimed. Certainly, the Tasmanian Government could not rightfully claim that the majority of Tasmanian people agreed to the Gordon below Franklin scheme.

In a spirit of co-operation and consensus, our Government has made attempt after attempt to negotiate with Tasmania. We have been told that Tasmania relies on the scheme for employment. Accordingly, we have offered a commitment to assist in the transfer of employment from the Gordon below Franklin site to alternative sites, further to reduce unemployment levels and to assist in creating job opportunities in Tasmania. We have been told that Tasmania needs the power generated by the hydro-electricity scheme at the Franklin River. Accordingly, we have offered our commitment to ensure that alternative methods of power generation are found at no financial burden to Tasmania.
