We have offered a number of initiatives to boost the tourist industry of the State, to pay attention to the special needs of Tasmania as our smallest and most isolated State. In other words, we have offered to take a real role in the development of Tasmania. Our attempts at conciliation and negotiation have been met with confrontationist and stubborn attitudes.

The introduction of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill is testament to the unwillingness of Tasmania to come to a real solution and to have a hard discussion. Had agreement taken place prior to today, we would not have had the same need for the Bill. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) himself recognised two weeks ago that the introduction of this Bill meant effective negotiation and reconciliation had not yet been possible with the Tasmanian Government.

Employment has continued to be cited as the major detriment to Tasmania should the Gordon below Franklin scheme not go ahead. But how many jobs are going to be created by the scheme and for how long? We have no figures from Tasmanian members on this. We have had no real constructive argument. Let us look at what we are really talking about. Once the dam is built only 29 operators are needed to maintain the scheme. How many people are required in the construction stage of the dam? Again we have no figures from the Tasmanian members on this matter. The Hydro-Electric Commission of Tasmania, in its submission to the Senate Select Committee on South-West Tasmania in 1979, numbers 3574 jobs dependent on the construction of the dam. The Australian Bureau of Statistics tells us that that figure is only 2.1 per cent of the Tasmanian work force. What happens to these people after the construction? Did we hear anything about that from the Tasmanian members?

The Hydro-Electric Commission's annual review points to a 57 per cent increase in power consumption since 1970, yet Tasmania in September 1982 had an unemployment rate of 10.1 per cent and those losing their jobs were retrenched from the very industries said to benefit from the cheap electricity generated from hydro-electricity schemes. What confidence can we have in the Commission's claim that employment will rise as a result of the dam? Did we hear anything like that from our Tasmanian colleagues? It is interesting to note that in 1981- 82 the Hydro-Electric Commission of Tasmania, whose philosophy it seems is 'if it trickles or flows, dam it', spent 52 per cent of all Tasmania's public capital expenditure. This is an astounding withdrawal of capital away from areas which could prove more labour intensive in the long run for Tasmania, such as home building and local manufacturing. I fear that the public sector is also disadvantaged rather badly by this withdrawal of capital from areas such as schools, health, housing and transport.

The Tasmanian members, as I have said before, have offered no constructive argument why we should be building the dam. I hope they are listening very intently to a few facts and figures and not ranting and raging about F111s and Mirage jets. I suppose there will be another attack on Tasmania by the SAS shortly. No doubt the Tasmanian members will find someone wandering around Tasmania. The Tasmanian Government's determination to proceed with the scheme has, to a large degree, relied on its hope that the cheaper electricity generated by the hydro-electricity scheme will prop up existing industries and attract new industries. Once again, I would be pleased to see documentation from national and multinational companies interested in setting up industries in Tasmania. Once again, we have been given no figures by honourable members from Tasmania. Can the Tasmanian Government provide these expressions of interest and commitment? I fear not. We all know very well that it cannot. Let us remember that only a select number of industries are large and energy intensive enough to be interested in taking advantage of the cheap electricity offered by Tasmania.

What guarantee will these companies provide that investment, profits and jobs will be provided for Tasmania and not elsewhere? Comalco in Tasmania, for instance, has been investing its profits in aluminium smelters in New Zealand and Queensland. Hydro-Electric Commission annual review figures reveal that in 1978-79 companies such as this consumed 67 per cent of the electricity sold in Tasmania but provided only 6 per cent of Tasmania's jobs. For most companies, the cost of transportation across the Bass Strait for machinery, goods and staff , far outweighs any cost savings on electricity. What company would invest funds in the State of Tasmania when it realises that the Tasmanian power grid can never provide the large blocks of power which can now be supplied by the mainland?

The comparative industrial power shortage can certainly not be much of an incentive in this area. Without assurances of investment in Tasmanian industry due to the Gordon below Franklin scheme we would be irresponsible in letting the dam proceed. But it is not very useful to outline only the problems associated with the proposed dam. Our Government has recognised the particular problems faced by Tasmania due to its size and isolation, high unemployment, small market -place and lowered capacity to attract investment. We wish to act to rectify these problems.

The Commonwealth will provide a grant of the full capital cost of a coal fired power station-I hope that the Tasmanians are listening-which would generate the same amount of electricity expected by the hydro-electricity scheme planned for the Gordon below Franklin Dam. Moreover, if it becomes necessary to reduce the cost of thermal power to the cost of hydro-power, the Commonwealth will provide annually a share of the cost of coal during the entire life of the station.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not listening.

—I know they are not listening. They do not want to listen to facts . This offer of about $500m means that Tasmanians will have access to electric power at the same cost as if the Gordon below Franklin had gone ahead. If, as we have seen by the election, Australians overwhelmingly wish the Franklin River to remain undisturbed by industry, all Australians must agree to accept responsibility for any sacrifices made by Tasmania. We all must bear the cost of protection of South West Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: So as not to disadvantage Tasmania the Federal Government is seeking to assist in all ways the creation of employment in the more labour intensive industries such as tourism. If honourable members are interested in Tasmania they would also be fighting for the tourists to go to Tasmania, as tourism is the most labour intensive industry in the world today. A comparison of the number of jobs and the length of employment in the tourist industry, with the precarious existence of construction work provided by dam building, points clearly to the long term preferability of tourism. Think what the wilderness of South West Tasmania has to offer the world for generations to come, against the questionable development of industry in that area. The destruction of the area will not be an easy thing to live with on our conscience . No progressive minded future Federal or Tasmanian Government can undo the destruction of South West Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill absolutely.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I will look at you, Mr Speaker, so that I will not be distracted. I do not usually get personal and attack people but last night the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones)-honourable members tell me that he is a former Pick-a-Box contestant and that he has a very good brain, and I will concede that-spoke down to the Tasmanian members. He berated us and made us feel inferior. He also made the Tasmanian people feel inferior. I thought his remarks should not go without comment. He is a theorist. He projects what is going to happen in 20 or 30 years but says very little that is practical. I will mention some of the things he said. What did he say about the people from Electrolytic Zinc Company of Australasia Ltd when he mentioned zinc? What did he say about the people in Queenstown on the west coast when he spoke about silicon chips? What is going to happen to the people in Tasmania if all that he said last night comes to fruition? He was talking about the future. What about the present? What about the average workers and the ordinary people of Tasmania? How did they like being berated and ridiculed in such a way by the Minister last night? I thought that what he said could be summed up in a poem. The poem covers it pretty well and I will read it before I get too excited and say things I may feel sorry for:

SPEECH.PARA: Barry Jones spoke most superior,
All Tasmanians feel most inferior.
That is the situation after that speech last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are one of their representatives I can understand why.

—Yes, I am one of their representatives-of course. We were elected by the people of Tasmania to come here and press for what they wanted, not for what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wanted. Honourable members opposite talk about being elected by the people of Australia and say they have a mandate to stop the construction of the dam. This Bill, specifically about stopping the dam , has been introduced because the people of Australia have been conned by the Tasmanian Wilderness Society, by people like Dr Bellamy, Dr Brown and others. It has become a real issue about them. They are the ones who get assistance from the media. They have been given all the media attention during the campaign and the ordinary people of Tasmania have been forgotten. Somebody said, 'Mr Goodluck , you are a hypocrite because you said that the Army should be brought in'. I am not ashamed to repeat what I said. The Army should have been placed on standby in Tasmania to stop what was occurring on the west coast. People like Dr Bellamy , who said that he came from England specifically--
—It was an invasion.

—It was an invasion by these types. He came specifically to get locked up for his fiftieth birthday. It was a very well organised campaign. I know it is a divisive issue but we, the Tasmanians, cannot compromise at all. We do not wish to make bad friends of our own colleagues who have a different point of view, but we went into the workshops of the EZ company and into the Hydro- Electric Commission workshops where ordinary people are employed. Honourable members opposite suggest that we started to generate fear.
—That is right.

—The fear was not started by us; it was started by people like the Minister. He came to Tasmania and said that the people of Tasmania would lose their jobs. He was the one projecting these things into the future but he could not come up with anything real then. The fear was created by people like the Minister and by people like Dr Bellamy. They are like kids who want a lolly and when they cannot get it they become nasty. The Tasmanians have a point of view. We elected the Parliament of Tasmania and it made a decision to construct the dam because it was a works program. All of a sudden, people who did not like that got nasty and started to say it should not be built. What if the boot were on the other foot? What if we had decided to take the other tack? We would be the worst people in the world. It is a matter of fairness. We do not wish to be divisive; we want to make certain that we tell the people of Australia what the people of Tasmania want. That is what we are trying to do.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of talk about facts and figures, that we are not coming up with and arguing the facts and figures. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a document containing the facts in regard to Tasmania's next power scheme. It is not from the HEC. It is from the chambers of commerce right throughout Tasmania and they would like to have it incorporated in Hansard. Is the Government game to let me have it included in Hansard?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—No, of course it would not be game; so it should stop talking about facts and figures.
—You never showed it to us. You know the courtesies of the House; you are supposed to show it to us. We have never seen it before.
—Incorporate it in Hansard. Are you game?
—Order!
—You can't incorporate that; it is cartoons.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat while the Chair is speaking .
—You do not want to see it because--

—And so will the honourable member for Franklin. I remind the House of a ruling given by my predecessor as to incorporations. He said that while the ruling was not inflexible, as Hansard was a record of spoken material inclusions would in general be restricted to tables. There is some discretion resting with the Chair.

—I say to the Prime Minister of this country that the honeymoon is over. If we lose in the High Court we will continue to fight about this issue because it is about Tasmania. The judges of the High Court were not elected by the people of Tasmania and neither was the Prime Minister. He was not elected by the people of Tasmania. We will continue to fight this issue right to the end.
—Do you want it in now?
—Mr Speaker, can this document be included in Hansard? It contains facts and figures. That is what has been asked for by honourable members today.
—Yes.

—As I have just pointed out, even if the Government agrees to its incorporation, there are restrictions on the incorporation of material in Hansard. It seems to me that this document is outside the guidelines that have been laid down.
—I am most disappointed about that, but I will seek leave to have it tabled later.
—Order! It being 12 midday, in accordance with the sessional order the debate is interrupted. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

—I notice that the Prime Minister is not present in the chamber. It is most unusual. I will proceed without him. My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Does the Government agree with the demand of the Australian Council of Trade Unions for wage catch-up?

—I was asked a question on this matter the other day. I thought I made the Government's position quite clear. Let me reiterate it: Any increase in real wages should not occur until there is a clear capacity in the economy to sustain such an increase. Let me get that on the record quite clearly so that the Leader of the Opposition can understand it. Quite obviously that cannot be for some time. As will be recalled, the scenarios which were presented at the National Economic Summit Conference did not contemplate any such increase at least until 1985.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to a report in the reputable Dutch journal P.T. Aktueel, No. 43 of 27 October last year? According to the article which was written by Dr Broer Scholtens, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission is to spend 4 million guilders in a collaborative effort with the Netherlands to build a small plant to produce Synroc. Can the Minister inform the House, firstly, whether the report is authentic and, if so, what is the present state of negotiations between the Ministry and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and whichever Dutch institution is to be involved and, secondly, whether investment in such ventures as described in the magazine is in accord with the Government's policy in regard to nuclear power development? Finally, will the Minister inform the House whether similar amounts are spent on solar energy development or on the development of other energy sources by the Australian Government?

—I must say that I am not a regular reader of the Dutch journal to which the honourable member referred. I will treat the question as having been given on notice and ask my colleague in another place to provide an answer at the earliest opportunity.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION: REFLECTIONS ON CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In view of the very serious reflection on the integrity of the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission by the Minister for Industry and Commerce and in view of the refusal by the Minister for Communications to declare his confidence in Professor Kramer, will the Prime Minister declare his confidence in the Chairman of the ABC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the circumstances which have arisen I do not think it is appropriate for me to enter into this dispute. The situation is quite clear. Senator Button- -

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—We have plenty of time. If honourable members opposite want to take up Question Time by interjecting that suits me fine.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. The Prime Minister is answering a question.

—The position is quite clear. Senator Button has said that he will reply by letter to Professor Leonie Kramer. When Professor Kramer receives that letter, I believe that it will contain a invitation to her to make the letter public if she so wishes. In terms of my knowledge of what is in the letter, I hope that she will make it public so that the matter can then be pursued.

—My question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs relates to the Aboriginal Land Claims Bill introduced into the Victorian Parliament on 17 March 1983. Is it a fact that the Minister recently discussed the Victorian Government 's proposals with Dr Ken Coghill, Secretary to the Victorian Cabinet, and the Victorian Aboriginal Task Force?

—I thank the honourable member. By virtue of his own interest in Aboriginal matters and matters which affect the Aboriginal community, some concern has been shown in areas of the Victorian Aboriginal community about legislation that has been introduced into the Victorian Parliament, dealing essentially with questions of land rights and other matters that affect Victorian Aboriginal people. I have discussed that not merely with members of the Aboriginal Task Force but with a wide range of Aboriginal groups in Victoria . They have indicated to me that they desire to have further time in order to consider their position in respect of this legislation and in order to make their views on the legislation known to Dr Coghill and the Premier of Victoria. I undertook to convey those views to Dr Coghill, and I did that personally last Friday.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION: REFLECTIONS ON CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. It is supplementary to the question asked by the Leader of the National Party and concerns the Prime Minister's answer. As a consequence of that answer, does the Prime Minister not agree that he now places the integrity of the Chairman of the ABC under a cloud?
—The answer to that question is no.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the Australian Government has bought two more Boeing 707 aircraft? What is their intended use? Is it for VIP or defence capacity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has acquired two Boeing 707 aircraft. I have seen reports that they are for VIP use. I think that is a matter of some very skilful imagination, and I would wonder how the Defence Force could employ them for VIP use. This year, to date, the usage of the existing two aircraft for VIP purposes is less than 7 per cent of their actual operating time. During the period that they have been in service with the Government, overall operation for non-Defence Force purposes is slightly over 16 per cent of total operating time.

ANSWER.PARA: The two additional aircraft will be utilised for defence requirements both as transport aircraft and, following conversion, as an addition to the present 707 aircraft for aerial refuelling. There is no role or requirement for additional aircraft of that type for VIP use, and certainly there would be no justification for the expenditure of Defence Force or Government funds to purchase aircraft for that purpose. The reason for the purchase at this time is that aircraft of this type are available. They are in extremely good condition, having been formerly in service with Qantas, and the price is less than half of that which was paid for the aircraft which are currently in service. There will be a delay, subject to budgetary and other considerations, also on the basis of need, in the conversion of these aircraft for aerial refuelling, but they will be available and utilised for training of Australian personnel in that area.

I think that the need for these aircraft has been demonstrated by those persons responsible for defence policy, at the level of the Defence Force, and in both the previous Government and the present Government. Under the previous Government funds were allocated and the Royal Australian Air Force was authorised to seek suitable aircraft. The aircraft became available at a price which could not be resisted without some degree of irresponsibility, as any later purchase would obviously have been at a much higher price for probably less suitable aircraft. Any suggestion that these are additions to the VIP fleet shows a total lack of understanding of the existing use of 707 aircraft and the requirements of the defence forces.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer whether, in his speech to the National Economic Summit, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: While forgoing the maximum wage increase that might be extracted in the short run may be regarded as contrary to the self-interest of those who would remain employed under those higher wage levels, it is in the interests of those who would otherwise remain or become unemployed.

In these circumstances, why has the Treasurer failed to reject calls by the Australian Council of Trade Unions for full catch-ups and full indexation, which he showed in his Summit speech are against the best interests of the unemployed?

TALK.START.PARA: —I made the position quite clear in the answer which I gave: I stand by the statement which I made at the Summit in that respect. The Government has made it quite plain that it believes that restraint by all sections of the community is desirable in the current economic circumstances, both in respect of all classes of income-that was also reciprocated at the Summit by indications from business-and in respect of dividends and other areas such as non-wage incomes. I made it clear in my answer to the question asked by the former Treasurer two days ago and to that asked today by the Leader of the Opposition precisely where the Government stands in respect of the so-called catch-up.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Defence able to advise the House of any additional Royal Australian Air Force flights over Tasmania since 5 March?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there have been a number of RAAF flights over Tasmania since 5 March in addition to those already canvassed in this House. Between 5 and 9 March a number of F111s were operating in Exercise Sea Eagle and it is likely that they passed over parts of Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: On 10 March an Orion aircraft carried out an instrument flying exercise over Tasmania. On 30 and 31 March RAAF aircraft flew over Tasmania in both directions between Hobart and Launceston for purposes which were relatively publicly known. On 22 March an Orion aircraft carried out a fisheries patrol operation in the vicinity of Tasmania. On 17 March an HS748 flew between East Sale and Launceston and Devonport on a training mission.

In addition to that, on 9 March three Caribou aircraft carried out low flying training exercises over Tasmania, including low flying exercises in the vicinity of the Franklin dam by two of those aircraft. I assume that, as with the flight of 24 March, honourable members opposite would have anticipated that we would ask for information on 5 April. Therefore, the Air Force would have been able to anticipate, even before there was a change of government, those requests about operations.

Tasmania is part of Australia. It is a requirement of the Australian defence forces that they carry out exercises and training in all parts of Australia to acquaint themselves with the areas and acquire the necessary skills and knowledge that may be necessary for their civilian operations as part of the Defence Force.

I remind honourable members that there are three RAAF helicopters currently operating in Queensland and I would have thought that Queensland members opposite would feel that that was a proper use of aircraft. Training in the areas in which the RAAF is likely to operate is necessary for the safety and effectiveness of the RAAF, and at a defence level it is vital to its capabilities to carry out the defence of this country. I believe that this House and this country owe a debt for the availability of the services which the defence forces of this country carry out in respect of a wide range of civilian activities, including many which are requested by honourable members opposite. I suggest that if we are to go through this cyclical or sickening exercise of trying to suggest--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you answer the question?

—I have answered it in detail, my friend. If honourable members opposite are trying to suggest that operations by the defence forces for training in essential defence purposes are in some way an improper activity, I reject that totally. I believe that the majority of members of this House would not support those who put forward that proposition.
—In accordance with Standing Orders I ask that the Minister table the document from which he was reading.
—Was the Minister quoting from a document on public affairs?

—I have no problem with the document from which I was reading. It is a minute from the Acting Chief of the Air Staff. I ask that the original be returned, after it has been copied for appropriate distribution, because it should remain on our files; it is a minute paper.
—The Minister will realise that the original, once tabled, has to stay with the House.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer whether it is a fact that, in his speech to the National Economic Summit Conference, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The fundamental risk to the recovery we are seeking lies with inflation.

I stress the words 'the fundamental risk'. How does he reconcile this statement with the Government's preference for scenario A, which forecast an inflation rate over the next three years almost double that of the more responsible and restrained scenario C and which involves the creation of 130,000 fewer jobs than scenario C.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point at the outset that the last assumption in the honourable gentleman's question is wrong. The consumer price index assumption in scenario C was 5.3 per cent and in scenario A it was 6.2 per cent. That is the basis of the question. I also indicated at the Summit that there were severe reservations on the part of the members of the technical committee about some of the assumptions in respect of scenario C. They were outlined very clearly to the Summit, expressing the fact that some of the wage assumptions and other assumptions were out of line.

ANSWER.PARA: I have a reference here to the non-farm wage section of those scenarios which were put to the Summit. The non-farm wage share in scenario C in 1985-86 at 62.4 per cent was well below historic levels. Indeed, if one looks at the capacity utilisation for 1985-86 and compares that non-farm wage share with capacity utilisation at other times in the 1960s and 1970s, when we were in a period of recession, one finds that the general non-farm wage share expressed in scenario A is very close to that which prevailed in the 1960s and 1970s. That is the basis on which the technical committee felt that the assumptions were in some respects unrealistic.

But it does not detract from the main point and that simply is-we made it quite clear at the Summit-that the Government must deal with inflation and unemployment simultaneously. That was accepted by the Summit. The honourable gentleman, in his question, again harks back to the simple old Tory shibboleth that we should deal with inflation first. All I can say to the honourable member is that we have seen how that policy has been executed over seven years and we have noticed the result-there has been no substantial diminution in inflation in the seven year period, but rather a massive increase in unemployment, an increase of 270,000 people last year. We made it quite clear, and I have reiterated, that this Government is committed to an attack on inflation and unemployment simultaneously. On that basis, inflation always remains important, but not on the basis that a reduction in inflation is achieved by a policy of increasing unemployment, supposedly as some sort of brake on wages.

This Government will not be sitting locked up in the bunker of Parliament House , pushing and pulling monetary and fiscal levers and hoping that everything outside will correct itself. That is why the Summit process was called. That is why there is substantial agreement about the objectives which were set down by the Summit. That is why this Government is committed to a policy of dealing with inflation and unemployment simultaneously. There is nothing, I believe, in the scenario A option which cuts across that principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In the light of the current high level of unemployment and the current eligibility for working visas, will the Minister investigate reports and advertisements in the Sydney Press regarding the placing of so-called au pair girls from Japan? Will the Minister also examine the conditions in which these girls serve, in the context of Australian industrial law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several days ago I did note these advertisements in the Australian Financial Review and other Australian newspapers which indicated that, under the previous Government, control over immigration entry to Australia had been very lax indeed. It appears that under the working holiday arrangements that the previous Government had entered into with five other countries, these girls have been coming into Australia with temporary working permits for 12 months, as long as they did not work for more than three months in the one job. That practice has been continuing under the general working holiday program. I might say that when I was sworn in as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, I quickly realised that the situation was out of control. What the former Government had allowed was a situation in which 19,000 working holiday-makers, at a time of the highest unemployment since the Great Depression, had been allowed into Australia . The scheme was 11,000 out of balance the wrong way. That is, under the former Government, 19,000 working holiday-makers were coming into Australia, also 11, 000 more were coming into Australia than were going out, and they were entitled to work at each job for periods of three months up to a total of 12 months. What is more, change of status was being allowed and 1,000 of these people were allowed to change from temporary to permanent status at a time of high unemployment during 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the situation with regard to the au pair girls from Japan. It appears that organisations within Australia and Japan, through the use of travel agents in Japan, have been responsible for the penetration of the Australian labour market in this manner. I repeat, agencies in Japan have been organising the working and travel arrangements of these people and then requesting visas under the working holiday arrangements. These people come into Australia under a so- called cultural exchange scheme and they are being placed in domestic situations where they have been asked to work up to 20 to 30 hours a week in return for the provision of accommodation and pocket money only. That is what has been occurring. I have instructed the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that this organised abuse of a cultural arrangement between Australia and other nations will cease forthwith. We will inform those responsible that visas will no longer be issued in these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Did his prediction of 21 April that inflation would be halved by early 1984 which, incidentally, mirrored substantially Treasury advice tendered to the former Government, assume a wage increase of 3 to 4 per cent this year, followed by a return to full wage indexation from the beginning of 1984?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I preface my reply to the question of the honourable member by expressing the observation that if he had over the last few months in fact been frank with the people of Australia in terms of sharing with them the advice which had been tendered to him by the Treasury in regard to the level of the deficit in 1983-84 we would have had more honest politics in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the question is quite straightforward. The proposition that I advanced that we expected the rate of inflation in Australia as we went into the early part of 1984 to be halved, yes, was based upon the proposition that we expected a rate of wage increase in the latter part of calendar year 1983 of the order of 3 to 4 per cent. I point out that the expectation of an increase in wages of that order in 1983, as a result of the policies that we are pursuing, will mean an increase in wages in Australia in calendar year 1983 significantly below that level of wage expectations which the people advising the honourable member and his Government were operating on for 1983. As a result of our policies there will be a significant reduction in the level of wage increases that otherwise would have taken place and, yes, my projection of something like a halving of the inflation rate as we go into the early part of 1984 is based upon that proposition and a resumption of indexation thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Treasurer seen reports of a statement by the Queensland Premier in relation to his decisions concerning the involvement by a Korean company, ICC Construction Co. Ltd, in the Jackson pipeline consortium? The Premier has alleged that the Government has arbitrarily changed the foreign investment guidelines, set at 50 per cent equity. I ask the Treasurer whether this is true. Will he also comment upon the Premier's claim that that decision, along with other foreign investment decisions, is anti-Queensland?
—Order! The first part of the honourable member's question was in order, but he cannot invite comment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no change at all in respect of the 50 per cent rule to which the honourable member refers in regard to the foreign investment policy. There is certainly no anti-Queensland bias operating in this Government. I just make it clear that I felt that the language of the Queensland Premier and his Treasurer today was most intemperate in the circumstances. Indeed, what has happened here is that two Australian companies are perfectly willing and able to build an 800 kilometre pipeline to take the oil from the Jackson field across Queensland, yet it appears, at the insistence and only the insistence of the Queensland Government, that a Korean company has been asked to take up 25 per cent of that project. Of course, that company had no part to play in the discoveries at the Jackson field, or in the production of the oil. Today a statement on the matter has been published by a spokesman for the Jackson producers and the Jackson-Moonie pipeline partners. He said that the pipeline construction was already under way, the financial arrangements were almost complete and the Treasurer's decision would not delay the completion of the project. The spokesman said the pipeline consortium was able to finance, construct and operate the pipeline.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite obviously the test which has to be applied is the test of net economic benefits. It was the Government's view-I think it was the only view that could have been taken-that there were not sufficient net economic benefits for the loss of Australian control and ownership, particularly when the companies involved are also involved in the Jackson oil production facility and are well able, in a technical sense, to construct the pipeline and also to build and to finance it without the involvement of a foreign company. So, the test always has to be in respect of direct benefits. In terms of that test the direct benefits were not applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —No foreign investment will be allowed if any Australian interests want it.

—Let me make this point. I could not understand what the Leader of the National Party interposed. Without inviting an interjection, Mr Speaker, let me just say that there has been a lot of very loose talk recently about the so called change in the foreign investment policy and the fact that some instruction has been given by this Government to the Foreign Investment Review Board to harden the policy. I will soon be putting to Cabinet a review of the foreign investment policy and an examination of it as it operates to date. That has not happened at this point in time.

ANSWER.PARA: Two cases have received a lot of publicity. One involved Elders IXL Ltd and Unilever Australia Pty Ltd. It concerned the prospective purchase by Unilever of a significant element of the Australian edible foods market and the general products division of Elders. It was rejected by the Government simply on the basis that the concentration of the foreign ownership in respect of the edible oils industry, particularly in retail margarine, would have taken a combination of Unilever and Provincial Traders Pty Ltd, which is owned by Elders IXL, to well over 50 per cent of total sales. I indicate that, even in the event that the direct economic benefits were to be ignored, the matter still would have been subject to review by the Trade Practices Commission.

There has been a lot of speculation about the second matter in respect of the prospective takeover of Allen's Confectionery Ltd by Cadbury Schweppes Australia Ltd and Nelson Tobacco Co. Ltd. Let me just say about that prospective takeover that Allen's Confectionery is a strong profitable Australian-owned company. Under the arrangement proposed, Cadburys would have taken over the manufacturing end and Nelson Tobacco would have taken over the distribution facility. That would have meant a very substantial increase in the foreign ownership of the Australian confectionery industry. Cadbury already has a majority position in respect of chocolate. It would have had a dominant position in respect of the non-chocolate part of the confectionery industry and would have taken foreign control of the confectionery industry to about 60 per cent. Again, there was not a clear demonstration of net economic benefits for the loss of Australian control. Again, on that basis the Government rejected the proposals.

In respect of those two matters-I do not wish to comment and will not comment in the future about recommendations to me by the Foreign Investment Review Board -concerning Unilever and Cadbury Schweppes and Nelson Tobacco, the recommendation of the Foreign Investment Review Board was that the takeover should not be approved. I submit to you, Mr Speaker, that, contrary to statements by the former Treasurer that he would have approved these proposals, he would have received the same advice and, I believe, would have made the same decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to direct a question to the Minister for Aviation. In view of his statement that the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport will be relocated, can the Minister say what the time factor will be, keeping in mind that a new site has to be obtained and the airport has to be planned and constructed? Will it not take at least 10 years or up to 15 years to build a new airport for Sydney? Bearing this in mind, I ask: Will the Minister indicate what action is being taken at the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to overcome the present congestion which is taking place now and will take place over the years ahead? Will the Minister also give an assurance now to the House that there will be no diversion of intrastate or interstate passenger planes to other airports within the metropolitan area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the last part of the question first. Of course, there are frequently diversions of planes for a variety of reasons. But I do not anticipate any diversions on a regular basis.

ANSWER.PARA: Could I deal now with the first part of the question which dealt with the time scale for the selection of a site and development of a second airport for Sydney . I think the time scale mentioned by the honourable gentleman was roughly correct. We are looking at a period of 10 to 15 years. We are also looking at a very substantial time scale in relation to the development of any other substantial runway facility like that originally planned and now abandoned for Mascot. That would not have been a solution to any problems that are immediately occurring.

The actual selection of a site is, to some considerable degree, dependent upon the consultations that will proceed between ourselves and the Government of New South Wales. But I have said here and in other places that I hope that we will be able to arrive, after proper consultation with all potentially affected groups, at a reasonably rapid conclusion to that process.

As I have said before, I am as concerned as the honourable member about the capacity of rural commuters to Sydney to have an adequate service. In connection with the developments at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, the previous Government introduced air traffic control procedures which have been quite useful in achieving a degree of traffic separation which has improved the position.

The usage of Kingsford-Smith Airport sets an example for us in the difficulty of predicting the future of air traffic movements in an uncertain economic situation. All the various Major Airport Needs of Sydney survey statistics on Kingsford-Smith, including the most pessimistic of them, are overoptimistic, given the downturn which has occurred. This has afforded considerable relief. We are looking at other means of development at Kingsford-Smith Airport, such as fast taxiways and additional taxiways which will enable more rapid movement of aircraft around the airport and into a take-off position.

We will also be looking at the development of surface-controlled radar which will also improve the movement of aircraft on the ground. All these developments , as they take place and as they are contemplated, will be referred for consideration to various interested parties, including the airlines and the commuter airlines which operate the country services about which I am sure the honourable member is concerned. It will be also done in consultation with the local authorities in the area which have an interest to ensure that appropriate noise abatement procedures are maintained.

The management of Mascot will be in a fashion which is appropriate to an airport which, while serving the very considerable requirements of the Sydney region, is also one of the most difficult from an environmental point of view by a considerable margin indeed. I think the figures for Mascot show that about 78, 000 people are affected by excess noise levels compared to the figure for the nearest airport-these figures were revealed in a survey last year-which was about 17,000.

It is a matter which we take very seriously. On that basis we have decided that we will abandon the proposed parallel runway and agree with our predecessors that there is a need to select a second site and move rapidly to a conclusion on the matter.

But the honourable member may be assured, as I gave an assurance yesterday, that, as we go through this process, the needs and requirements of the country people in New South Wales will be given adequate attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Prime Minister. It deals with Australia's policy in the Middle East. Does the Government believe that recent adverse developments in the Middle East have killed the Reagan peace initiative? Does the Government continue to support efforts by the United States of America to bring about a peaceful settlement between Israel and its neighbours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that this very important issue raised by the honourable member is one upon which I will be able to speak substantially on a bipartisan basis. I believe that the views that I will express will be accepted by the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: I say unequivocally to the House that my Government attaches very, very fundamental significance to the attainment of a just, comprehensive and lasting peace in the Middle East on the basis of mutual respect, the right of Israel to exist behind secure and recognised boundaries and a recognition of the rights of the Palestinian people. We base our approach on an acceptance of resolutions 242 and 338 of the Security Council and on the Camp David processes.

We welcome the initiative that was taken by President Reagan, based upon those premises, we believe, to use the influence of the United States to achieve the objectives to which I refer. There is no doubt that that honourable process undertaken by the United States has suffered a set-back as a result of the failure of the discussion which took place between King Hussein of Jordan and Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organisation in an attempt to secure some involvement of the Palestinians in the negotiations to which I have referred. I do not believe that that set-back announced on 10 April should be taken as bringing to an end the processes to which I have referred. We hope and believe that the current visit of Secretary of State Shultz to the area will serve the purposes of hastening some of the more immediately obvious objectives which need to be achieved if the lasting and comprehensive settlement to which I have referred is to be capable of achievement.

Obviously the most immediate objective must be the attainment in Lebanon of a peaceful situation. I make it quite clear in that respect that it is essential that the troops of all foreign countries in Lebanon should be withdrawn-the troops of Israel should be withdrawn and certainly the Syrian troops should contemporaneously be withdrawn. I have indicated, and so has my Foreign Minister , our commitment to the achievement of these objectives. I repeat that we trust that the current visit of Secretary of State Shultz to the region will secure quickly the achievement of these immediate objectives which must be seen as a necessary step in the processes of the achievement of this comprehensive and lasting basis of resolution of the problems in this troubled area.

I am sure the House will agree with me when I give emphasis to the tragedy which has been suffered for so long and so deeply by the people of Lebanon. We commend the action of the previous Government in making available an amount of $ 10m for relief in the Lebanon. I am pleased that very recently $5m of that was handed over in New York to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund for these purposes. We applaud the action of the previous Government in this regard; we endorse it. I believe that the Opposition in terms of the answer I have given would share the view that what I am saying now is not merely a statement of position on behalf of the Australian Government but can be taken as a clear statement of a bipartisan position in these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the present shearers strike is causing great concern to primary producers and to the nation? Is it further a fact that telexes and telegrams have been sent to him from members of parliament and farming organisations? In view of this serious situation will his Government now intervene to enforce the decision of the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member. I would have expected the question to be addressed to the relevant Minister. However, if the honourable member desires me to answer it, I certainly will. I have been in constant consultation with my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and we have done what we can to ensure that this matter can be--
—Precious little.

—Relisted and reheard. As distinct from those on the other side of the House, who, in some perverse manner which always escapes me, seek to gain some political advantage out of industrial disputation and do their best to keep it going, we on the other hand are committed to using our forces to try to ensure that industrial disputation, as far as it is possible, is either avoided or, if it commences, brought to an end. What we have done has been constructive and directed towards that end. We have played our part in consultations with a range of people to try to ensure that that matter is brought on under the provisions of section 59 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, which provide for a hearing in these circumstances of what would in fact be a new industrial situation regarding the factors that have been covered.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make the Government's position in this matter clear. We will not be going into such a hearing to support the claims of the Australian Workers Union. That is quite clear. What we will be doing is supporting the utilisation of the procedures of the Act for securing an amicable resolution of this matter. We do that on two conditions, and let there be no doubt what those two conditions are. Firstly, the union would have to cease its industrial actions. Secondly, the union cannot expect to have, in this rather special way, the processes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission again available to it unless it gives the undertaking in advance that it will abide by the decision of the Commission. On the basis of those two conditions-that industrial action should cease and that the union will give an undertaking to abide by the decision of the Commission-this Government will support an application before the Commission that the matter should be reheard.

DEBATE.TITLE: PLAN FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE MUSEUM OF AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am taking the first opportunity after its presentation to table this fine report, entitled The Plan for the Development of the Museum of Australia', which was prepared by the Interim Council of the Museum of Australia under the chairmanship of Mr Alex Dix. The report gives us a fresh insight into the purpose that can be served by a national museum and the character that the Museum should have if it is to achieve its objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: The report pursues the original concept of a national historical museum first advanced in the report on museums in Australia by the Pigott committee of inquiry, which was established by the previous Labor Government in 1973. I supported on behalf of the Australian Labor Party the legislation which followed and this report now represents the next phase. I believe that the tone of the report is set by that section of the Museum's proposed charter which reads:

The Museum will reflect the development of the Australian nation in all its cultural diversity. In particular, it will create, through the Gallery of Aboriginal Australia, a focus for the cultural aspirations of the Aboriginal people.

The report recommends that the Museum be located in a magnificent setting on an 88 hectare site at Yarramundi Reach beside Lake Burley Griffin. Both outdoor and indoor displays are envisaged and all would be planned in a highly imaginative and informative manner such as to appeal to visitors of all ages, interests and personal tastes. It is planned as a major research centre, a great tourist attraction and, above all, a focal point for the expression of national identity .

The proposal-and I stress this-is not for a conventional museum. It is designed to show things uniquely Australian in a way not attempted anywhere else in the world. It proposes living and participatory displays of Aboriginal life and culture, prepared by the Aboriginal people themselves. It will demonstrate Australia's distinguished contribution to technology-for example, through radio astronomy-and will trace the development of our pastoral and mining industries. The concept of the Museum fully reflects the Government's objective of providing for the greatest possible access to and participation in all aspects of Australian culture by all people. It justifies the high priority of the Museum in our arts and heritage policies as recognised in our policy speech.

The report and its recommendations remain to be considered by the Government, and I cannot therefore commit the Government at this stage to the course or timing of action on them. I do, however, commend the report as an admirable contribution to public discussion and to the deliberations that must now take place. I take the opportunity to congratulate Mr Dix and his colleagues on the Interim Council of the Museum of Australia on their excellent report. In conclusion, whilst I know how many reports honourable members and Ministers receive, I hope they will take the trouble to read this one. I think they will find it very interesting and very stimulating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition welcomes and applauds the report from the Interim Council of the Museum of Australia. It is worth reminding the Parliament and the people that the Museum was established by an Act of this Parliament in 1980 and the Interim Council was established by the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr R. J. Ellicott. At that time the Council was instructed to advise the Government and the Parliament on a range of issues relating to the establishment of the Museum of Australia. In particular, it was to report to the Government within two years on the Museum's establishment, location and development. At that time the Fraser Government had previously laid down that the Museum should follow three main themes: Firstly, the history of Aboriginal people; secondly, the history of non-Aboriginal people; and, thirdly, the interrelation between people and the Australian environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairman of the Interim Council, Mr Alex Dix, and his colleagues must be congratulated for the excellent work they have done in putting before the Parliament a very worthwhile report that shows considerable imagination. If its recommendations are implemented it will ensure that the Museum of Australia will not be just of world class but, more important, a world leader in establishing a framework directed to encouraging Australians of today to have a better understanding of their national origins in a wider sense and thus develop a more sensitive approach to creating within our society a wider acceptance of our common destiny as a united people. I urge the Government to give serious consideration to the recommendations of the Interim Council.

The proposal to establish the history of the development of Australia in all its cultural diversities by establishing a gallery of Aboriginal Australia as a focus for the cultural aspirations of the Aboriginal people must be applauded. Similarly, the recommendation that the Museum emphasise the interaction between people and the environment also must be fully supported. There is no doubt that one of the very great challenges facing Australia and all Australians is going to be how we manage the maintenance of adequate standards for the environment's protection while at the same time being able to pursue rational policies of national development. It is often claimed that Australians generally are unaware of their past. If that is so, it is a fault of the education system but, at the same time, it is probably a reflection of the fact that we are more today than ever before a migrant society. That in no sense means that we should not seek for a common future and to draw from Australia's specific past as well as from the cultural strands from other societies which now make up part of the complexities of the Australian nation.

It is absolutely correct, as the report observed, that no action of any part, in either the past or the present, has been, or is, taken without an impact on the other parts-people on people, people on environment, and environment on people. The Opposition supports the proposal to build the Museum of Australia on land adjacent to Yarramundi Reach overlooking Lake Burley Griffin. We will continue to take a close interest in the development of the Museum. While time does not permit me to examine in detail all the proposals contained in the report of the Interim Council, nevertheless the Opposition supports, in general terms of course, the proposals outlined in the report.
