PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to add a bit of reason to the debate on the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill.
—That will be hard.

—I am glad to see that Government supporters have all come back into the chamber. There are two sides to this story and we cannot compromise on this Bill at all. We oppose it. It attacks a fundamental principle that a State should be able to be master of its own destiny and introduce a works program and be able to go ahead with it. I can understand the divisiveness, but there are two sides to the argument. On one side there is the Tasmanian Parliament led by Robin Gray. People can say what they like about Robin Gray, but he has done a dashed good job, far better than has that previous compromiser who is on the opposing side at the moment. Behind Robin Gray are his Parliament, most of the Labor Party except for a few, the majority of the people of Tasmania and a lot of other Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposing the dam there are, first, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government. Many groups have come out of the woodwork to support opposition to the dam-groups such as Save the Whale, Save the Cats and so forth, and the socialists and the communists.

This Bill attempts to stop the dam and to stop the works program. With all the fanatics who are opposed to the dam a lot of very good people have been conned. They have been conned by the left wing Press which is composed of trendies and which only gives a headline to certain things that suit it, not to a little bit of common sense. The Press developed it--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Ken Davidson?

—Oh, I will not talk about Ken Davidson from the Age. He called us gorillas or something today. Let him call us anything, I do not care. Anyway, all these types put up that argument. But they have missed the important point that the heart and the pulse of the small State-the 400,000 people in Tasmania- do not like the intervention by the Prime Minister and his Government. The people of Australia may have voted for them. It serves us right if they did because we stood up for a principle. If a government stands up for a particular principle, people will support it. But when some go in a different direction-I forgive them, it is their own business where they go-people think that we are a fragmented party which accepts all the fringe people that come in with their own ideas.
—Well, look who your audience is. Look whom you are talking to.

—Oh, you are here, Pick-a-Box-so shut up! Lots of people like that come in, but I warn the Prime Minister that he will be like Dorian Gray from the classics-each year he will be scarred by this decision and each year the people of Australia will realise more and more that he is a dictator. He wants to take over the small State of Tasmania. That is what he and the Government want to do. Why does he not concentrate on prostitution in New South Wales? What about the sex shops in Melbourne and all the other dirty things that go on in Australia? Government supporters talk about the wilderness. The wilderness is not just for a few cranks with haversacks on their backs. It is for some of the good people in my electorate who cannot afford it. Honourable members opposite are always against the rich. They always purport to be for the workers. What about the workers who are employed in Tasmania and the poor people there? Of course we are going to develop roads. That will open up the tourist industry. My colleagues and I will stand by this principle. One of my colleagues might not-that is his business. I do not care. When we fight we fight dashed hard. That is the only way to win. If we lose the battle we will win the fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: — After listening to the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) it is hard to get to grips with the purpose of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill. The purpose of the Bill is to provide for protection of certain property that Australia has identified as national or cultural heritage within the meaning of the international treaty known as the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. The sad thing about this Bill is that it should not be necessary. In a country such as Australia we should not have to bring a Bill like this into the Federal Parliament to try to achieve what is necessary for the best interests of Australia and the world.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, had the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) been consistent in what he has said in the past, we would not have to bother about this type of legislation, because people should be willing to support what the Australian Government is doing in this area. Indeed, my personal view is that the Bill probably does not go far enough in that no area is automatically covered. The proposed Act will apply only after proclamation is issued. In my view, world heritage areas especially should be protected in an unequivocal way regardless of what government is in power. I would be very concerned about the fate of this proposed Act if ever the present Opposition came back into government.

In the rather inflammatory statements from the Opposition, particularly from those members from Tasmania, we find the rather false argument about States rights as if Tasmanians were a peculiar group of people who were not Australians . They are not just Tasmanians; they are Australians. We are all citizens of this country. All Australians have a right to some say in what happens to individual parts of Australia.

During the last election, the people of Australia had a fair bit to say about building a dam in South West Tasmania. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) said that the fact that there were five Tasmanians in the House of Representatives meant that they have nearly unanimous support from the people of Tasmania for opposition to the dam. I remind the honourable member for Braddon, for instance, that in the last election the two-party preferred vote for the Labor Party in all the House of Representatives seats in Tasmania was 42.8 per cent of the total vote. We went into that election with an unequivocal anti-dam stance-and 42.8 per cent of Tasmanian electors voted for our point of view. Fifty-two per cent of them may have voted for the Opposition parties, but a vast group in Tasmania is not in favour of the rather narrow approach that has been taken by the Tasmanian members in this Parliament and by the Tasmanian Government, which is an extremely reactionary government.

In the Bennelong electorate, held by the previous Treasurer, the Independent candidate, Mr Milo Dunphy, got 12.7 per cent of the vote-the largest single vote ever given to an Independent in the electorate of Bennelong since it was formed. That is what people in various parts of Australia thought about the concept of dams in Tasmania. There is no doubt that this will continue to be a contentious issue and as such will become very important in national debates. Some time ago the Prime Minister said:
The Government's decision on this important question would not be supported by all sections of the community.
He went on to say:
We must, however, take decisions that will be to the lasting advantage of the entire community--

I do not suppose any of the Tasmanian representations would agree with that. They would think that that was a terrible thing to say. No doubt the honourable members for Bass and Franklin would think that was wrong. But it was not a Labor Prime Minister who said that and he was not talking about South West Tasmania. It was the previous Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, who said that about Fraser Island , which was one of the last big environmental issues we debated in this Parliament. The previous Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, went on to say about Fraser Island:
We recognise the quality of the environment is crucial for this and future generations of Australians.
People understand that many parts of this and other countries have been polluted and destroyed because man has not recognised his potential for environment change.

That was not our leader saying that. That was the leader of the previous Government. At the time honourable members opposite all sat over here on the Government side of the House and they said that that was pretty good. The hypocrisy of the present Opposition members has been shown by the stance they took then on what was supposed to be a States' rights issue and the stance they take here and now. The honourable member for Bass will not say anything because he knows what he said when he was Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development. Some of the things he said then do not sit very well with what he is saying now. Of course, Joh jumped up and down, spoke about States' rights and said: 'You cannot do this. Queensland comes first. Queensland is not part of Australia', just as Tasmanians are saying similar things now. But the honourable member for Bass ought to be reminded of what he said about Fraser Island when he was Minister for the Environment. It was a lot different from what he is saying now. In fact, the honourable member for Bass was quoted in the Sunday Mail, a Queensland newspaper, of 10 July 1977 as follows:

In Canberra last week Mr Newman said in an interview he hoped the Federal Government's decision to stop sand mining on Fraser Island would have left no doubt that the Government was determined to carry out its environmental responsibilities. Mr Newman went on to say: 'I reaffirm the Commonwealth Government's commitment to the conservation of our natural heritage and the protection of our environment'.

That was in 1977. He has had an instant conversion along the way. Indeed, that great Tasmanian newspaper, the Mercury-we have had the five Tasmanian representatives tell us ad nauseam about the Mercury-in an editorial on 12 November 1976 stated:
The decision of the Federal Government to prevent sand mining on Fraser Is. is a politically wise and environmentally sound move.
Nothing was said about the Constitution. The newspaper thought it was a politically wise and sound move. It went on to say:

The Fraser Is. decision probably is the most significant of its kind and is a fine example of how independent, expert analysis and political courage can produce a result that should be welcomed by the majority of Australians.
It is a pity these people do not have the political courage now that they had then. The Mercury article continued:
But not all governments, and certainly not all self-interest groups and unions, are willing to accept the verdict of qualified umpires.

We can see who is not willing to accept the verdict now. The Australian people gave a very significant verdict on 5 March and 42.8 per cent of the Tasmanian people gave a pretty significant verdict. But those people opposite want to go back into the past. Indeed, the honourable member for Bass, who is saying how terrible the World Heritage List is, was quite willing on 12 November 1976 to try to have Fraser Island put on the World Heritage List. Joh said he would not have it put on any list but the then Minister for Environment, the honourable member for Bass, who has discovered States' rights all of a sudden is reported as saying in 1976:
. . . the Federal Government had already said it would look at the idea of declaring Fraser Island part of the National Estate under the Australian Heritage Commission Act.

He went on to say that it should be put on the World Heritage List and this could be done under the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation's Convention to which Australia was a signatory. But those people opposite do not learn from history. Unfortunately for them they do not remember the history that they were part of. It is rather significant that they were putting forward that line five years ago. There is absolutely no difference between the environmental question of Fraser Island and the environmental question of South West Tasmania except that South West Tasmania is more important than Fraser Island ever was. But those people opposite forget what they did then and they now come in here and put up this extremely erroneous, selfish argument about Tasmania, States' rights and what people in Tasmania have to say. They mislead this Parliament and the Australian people in their attempts to make out that all Tasmanians are in favour of the dam.

I have been to Tasmania a number of times and I have been to the wilderness area. I can tell the House that it is frightening to look at the people who are supporting their point of view in Tasmania. They are people like the Tasmanian Premier, who is a political lightweight if ever there was one in this country. But, more importantly, there are organisations such as the Organisation for Tasmanian Development. If ever there was a rather threatening organisation in this country it is that organisation. It is centred in Queenstown-one of the environmental disasters of this country-and the members of that organisation make out that they are the people who should say what should happen to South West Tasmania.

There are only five sites in Australia on the World Heritage List. Of the 136 properties throughout the world that are on that list, five are from Australia. They are the Great Barrier Reef, Kakadu National Park, South West Tasmania, the Willandra Lakes region of New South Wales and the Lord Howe Island group. I have had the privilege of seeing two of those places-Lord Howe Island and South West Tasmania. It would be a terrible crime if any Australian government stood back and allowed a sectional group to change those areas irrevocably. The New South Wales Government has made it quite clear that it will never allow anything to harm the environment of the Willandra Lakes region and Lord Howe Island. The Commonwealth Government has care and control over the Great Barrier Reef and the Kakadu National Park-I might say that it did not get that care and control over the Great Barrier Reef all that easily from one of the Opposition's new colleagues in the States rights game up there in Queensland. If Bjelke-Joh had had his way, we would have oil rigs on the Great Barrier Reef now. The Minister for the Environment at the time had something to say about that. These people go in for rather selective reporting.

But the question before us here today is to take a decision to ensure that South West Tasmania, and those other four regions of Australia which are on the World Heritage List, are held for the good of all Australians and indeed, for the good of all people in the world. We must ensure that this legislation is passed through Parliament to protect those areas from the rapacious demands of certain small-minded State governments and their very small-minded supporters. Those people who support the building of dams in Tasmania are not looking to the future. My colleague the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) pointed out very eloquently in the Parliament last night the economic fallacies involved in building the dams. The absolute distortion of the use of public funds in Tasmania on hydro-electricity has destroyed the development of that State. The over-use of public funds on hydro-electricity generation in Tasmania has distorted the type of public sector infrastructure that has been provided in Tasmania to the detriment of all Tasmanians.

In my view, Tasmania's future lies in tourism. It is one of the great tourist destinations of the world. To hear those people over there-the honourable member for Braddon, the honourable member for Bass and his little friend, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who seems to have gone to sleep- say that tourism is not important in Tasmania shows obviously that they do not know what their State Government is doing because that Government spends more on tourism, on attracting people to go to Tasmania, than does most other State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member misrepresented what was said on this side of the House. That comment was quite incorrect. We support the Tasmanian tourist industry.
—There is no point of order.

—It is very difficult to misrepresent these people because most of the time they are not quite sure what they are talking about. The point about tourism is the most important thing for Tasmania. If the wilderness area in the South West is destroyed, the people who would normally come to Tasmania from Europe and parts of America will no longer do so. Tasmania and Australia will be seen as ecological vandals in the eyes of the world. This Bill not only will save this area for the whole of Australia and for all people to enjoy but also will go a long way to helping Tasmania survive as one of the great tourist destinations of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should put aside the small-minded political divisiveness that has allowed these people to ride back into this Parliament. This issue has been deliberately manipulated for their own personal political position. We should think of what is good for all Australians. We should think about the common good for Tasmania. Common good for all will be achieved only if this legislation is passed by this Parliament, and we stop the environmental banditry that is going on in Tasmania. One can only hope that the Tasmanian Government will take the very proper and forthright view of protection of the environment as the New South Wales Government has done with the Willandra Lakes region and with the Lord Howe Island Park, and indeed as the Commonwealth Government, even under the leadership of those opposite, did with the Great Barrier Reef and the Kakadu National Park.

For goodness sake, why cannot the Liberal Party be broadminded for once in its life and take a principled stand on Tasmania as it did on the Great Barrier Reef . Let us see some of the people in the Opposition who have some sense and principle stand up. There are many people on that side who do not want to adopt the bad position they are being forced into. To see those people having to stand up and vote for these rather repulsive types of amendments that have been put up is a shame. I commend the Bill to the Parliament. I know that the great bulk of Australians wish to see us pass this legislation.
Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Withdrawal of Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to withdraw a motion.
—Yes.

—This morning the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) gave notice of a motion which contains the word 'hypocrisy' and the motion appeared to have been accepted at the time. I gave notice of a motion in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House congratulates Mr Speaker on reversing the decision of the previous Speaker that the words 'hypocrisy' and 'hypocritical' were unparliamentary terms.

I have since been informed that this was done by mistake and that Mr Speaker still regards those terms as being unparliamentary. I therefore obviously withdraw my motion congratulating Mr Speaker and would like to substitute my original motion, which I moved on 4 December 1980, which states:
That this House is of the opinion that the words 'hypocrisy' and 'hypocritical' , defined in the Concise Oxford Dictionary as simulation of virtue or goodness, are not unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will accept the proposition that the honourable member has put to the extent that his Notice of Motion is withdrawn, but I am not prepared to permit the substitution.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill is an omnibus Bill with very wide and serious ramifications. It is a Bill which, as presented, is a poor Bill. The heads of power that it relies upon make it a bad Bill. The Government has introduced this legislation in pursuit of its determination to overrule and override the rights and responsibilities of an elected State Government. This objective has very far reaching implications for all State governments and for the whole foundation of the federal system under which Australia is governed. As the Australian Financial Review said a few days after the election of 5 March, a major constitutional crisis is really not a good way to kick off a government committed to consultation and unity. What irony it is that one of the first pieces of legislation brought into this House by the new Government is a Bill whose effect will be to drive deeper divisions into the Australian community, which is already divided over the Australian Labor Party's attack on the Australian Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: It should not be thought that this is a view held only by politicians on this side of the House. There are people with a long tradition of Labor support and involvement who share our concern about the damaging approach that the Government is taking. Many people in this House will know of a man who was the Labor member for Wilmot from 1946 to 1975, a period of 29 years. He was Whip of the Labor Party and a very respected member of the Parliament. I refer to Mr Gil Duthie. Mr Duthie made his views on the Tasmanian dam issue very clear in a letter which he wrote to the Bulletin magazine and which was published in the issue of 29 April this year, just two weeks ago. In this letter, after commenting on the devastation of the Labor Party in Tasmania at the election in March, Mr Duthie said:
As a life member of the ALP with 42 years membership it was heartbreaking to see what one section of the Party was prepared to do to another section.

He went on to say that the Labor Party's decision to stop the dam was one of the most provocative, unnecessary and divisive Labor decisions in his 42 years membership. Mr Duthie ended his letter with these words, which I hope all of his Labor Party colleagues will consider very carefully:
If the High Court decides against the dam, then all States beware. Their powers will be on the skids.

That is really what this debate is all about. If it were possible to look at this matter simply in terms of the rights or wrongs of building a dam, then I would say that my preference would be not to build the dam. I had the opportunity of hiking through at least 100 kilometres of this country with my wife a couple of years ago. I know, appreciate and love the environment.

I have said before that, as Acting Prime Minister, in January this year I went to Tasmania to see for myself the situation there. I visited with the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, the site of a coal deposit and had discussions with the company that held the rights to that deposit on the prospects for a coal-fired power station to be built in Tasmania as an alternative to the dam. I visited the South West of Tasmania and discussed the situation there with the Premier and with officers of the Hydro-Electric Commission.

The fact is that we are not involved in just an argument over a dam. We are involved in an issue which is of immense importance and involves the whole nation. It is a debate about the fundamental rights of the States and about an attack on those rights by the Hawke Government. In pursuit of that attack the Government, as we have seen and as we are seeing, is prepared to go to extreme lengths to bring in the use of powers which I think few people ever imagined would be sought to be used in the way in which this Government is using them. The tragedy is that, whilst this confrontation goes on between the Commonwealth Government and the Tasmanian State Government, nothing is being done about a joint program of management of this wonderful area. Nothing is being done to see that no more dams are built in the region of the Franklin River.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your fault.

—Our fault? Honourable members opposite cannot even get into dialogue with anybody. A couple of days before the election, in March, I said that the people who used their vote to try to stop the dam should realise that, while they might stop the dam, they could start some things that would be very hard to stop. We are seeing those words come true. We have seen the Government embark on a course which, if it succeeds, will convulse this nation. We have seen the Government, or some of its Ministers, taking the incredible step of using Royal Australian Air Force aircraft to gather evidence on what is happening in Tasmania. That is a step which I know the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did not agree with and which I am sure he was extremely annoyed about. In my comments before the election I said that few actions open to a government in Australia could be as divisive as the action which is now being contemplated by the Labor Party or could hold so much potential for conflict and damage to our system of Government. I suggested then, and repeat now, that heavy-handed intrusion of this kind by a central government could split Australia right down the middle. So much for all the Government's slogans during the election campaign about bringing Australia together! What is at stake now is much more than a dam, a small part of a river or even a very small part of the wilderness of Tasmania. If the basis of the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States is to be changed, there exist proper constitutional ways of bringing about such a change. If change is to be secured through resort to powers that were never intended to be used in the way in which this Government seems determined to use them, the result can only be very severe damage to our system of government and very deep divisions in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: As we all know, the Government, in its efforts to overrule the decision of the elected government of Tasmania, seeks to rely on the external affairs power. In fact, this Bill refers to several heads of power to which the Government seeks to resort, if necessary. The external affairs power is one of these. I think it is worth recalling the views expressed by the Chief Justice in the Koowarta case -views to which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) drew attention at the recent Australian Constitutional Convention. In referring to possible interpretations of the external affairs power, the Chief Justice pointed out that it is impossible to envisage any area of power which could not become the subject of Commonwealth legislation if the Commonwealth became a party to an appropriate international agreement.

It seems to me to be a very bad state of affairs when matters for which our States are constitutionally and historically responsible can be usurped in this way by a centralist government determined to trample over the rights and responsibilities of States. Because this Bill, in its present form, provides for such overriding of the States by the central government I cannot support it, nor will my party. I know that to some people these things do not matter. For them, legal and constitutional questions, even economic ones, carry little if any weight. They see the Tasmanian dam question, for example, purely and simply in environmental terms. But we cannot do that.

Those of us who are entrusted with shaping and safeguarding the system by which this country operates do not have the luxury of taking such a simple and uncomplicated view. I would have very much more respect for the Government if I could believe that the zeal with which it is pushing this legislation results only from its concern about the environment. But those of us who know and understand the fundamental principles and philosophies of the Australian Labor Party know that it believes in central government. We know that it believes that the powers of the Commonwealth, as derived from the Constitution, are an anachronism and should be changed. This was stated very clearly by the Prime Minister in the Boyer Lectures of 1979. I fear that that is the deep-seated core of the Government's stand on this issue.

Of course, it is very convenient for the Government to give the impression that it is pursuing this issue wholly and solely on environmental grounds. It can take the issue to the High Court of Australia and cite its concern about the environment. Then, if it loses, it will be off the hook; it will be an easy way to discharge all of its unctuous pre-election promises. If it wins in the High Court, the results will have enormous ramifications for the shift and transfer of powers to Canberra.

Tasmanians feel strongly about this issue and have made very plain their objection to the policies of the Federal ALP and the Hawke Government. There are Tasmanians who do not support construction of the dam, but the people of the State are united as never before in their determination to protect their rights and to make their own decisions rather than be directed and trampled on by Canberra. The arrogance, insolence and contempt for the fundamental rights of Tasmanians that have been demonstrated by the ALP Government in Canberra instinctively provoke the strongest reactions in Tasmania, and so they should for anyone worth his salt. This is a matter of great importance and every State, if it believes in preserving those areas of independence agreed upon at Federation, must react and fight against such encroachment. The legal, constitutional and economic considerations cannot be brushed aside as if they do not matter; they do matter. As I have said on other occasions, the real question that will remain is not as to the extent of the Commonwealth's powers but as to the justification for and the implications of their use.

The Bill seeks to bring into play not one but four heads of power which the Government might rely on in its determination to impose its will on Tasmania. I do not think anyone seriously suggests that we on this side of the House lack concern for the environment or are happy about anything that threatens it. Our record in government is clear. I remind honourable members of the ban on whaling , the establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, the preservation of Fraser Island and the establishment of the Kakadu and Uluru national parks. It was a Liberal-National Party Government that proposed the Tasmanian wilderness for inclusion in the World Heritage List. So, let no one question our commitment to the protection of the environment.

Similarly, let no one question our commitment to maintaining Australia's tried and proven institutions and constitutional framework until such time as the Australian people, through proper processes, decide that they want those institutions and that framework changed. The Bill can only be looked upon as one in pursuit not of genuine environmental interests but rather of powers to further centralist beliefs. It is that question of powers of which the Australian people should be aware. If there is to be a transfer of these powers, it should not take place by way of the High Court but by referenda. It is the people, not the High Court, who must decide whether they want a basic restructuring of our system of government by diminishing the powers of the States and moving towards the vesting of more powers in Canberra.

For my part, I am a federalist and believe in that system. I believe that a division and balancing of powers as between Commonwealth and States is the best way of preserving and protecting the rights of individuals in this country. Therefore, I strongly oppose any changes in the Constitution which are designed to vest additional powers in the Commonwealth-as this Bill is basically intended to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are today debating two issues of crucial importance, firstly, the most important conservation question that has come before this Parliament for a long time and, secondly, the crucial question of the Federal Government's ability to abide by international treaties in relation to matters affecting the environment. Both issues are of national importance. They affect not only our national heritage and pride as a people but also our international reputation as a nation concerned about the conservation of the world's resources. A rich area of natural beauty such as South West Tasmania is not the treasure of one State only, or even of one nation, but it is, I submit, the heritage of all humanity. Future generations, not only of Australians but also of people from all over the planet, are entitled to strong action on our part to preserve this heritage. It is because of this that both the previous Tasmanian Government and the previous Federal Government placed this area on the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been argued by the Opposition-especially by certain strenuous members of the Opposition-that, notwithstanding what the people of Australia believe, the people of Tasmania voted in the last Federal election to build the dam. I want to say something about the reporting of the facts in the Tasmanian media. Unlike the media of other States, the Tasmanian media are the subject of the biggest monopoly of any media in this country. The Hobart Mercury and the Launceston Examiner are the worst two newspapers that one could imagine in terms of fairness of presentation of points of view. Generally, the Tasmanian media have not presented to the Tasmanian people a fair and balanced presentation of the issues involved in the matter. If one read the editorials in the Hobart Mercury last year, for example, one would think they were nothing more than the views of the Tasmanian Government and of the Tasmanian Premier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever read the Mercury?

—I read the Hobart Mercury quite often, don't worry. I have visited that State quite often and have discussed these matters. So I ask the honourable member not to try to intervene on that score. The situation is that the people of Tasmania have been subjected to a propaganda barrage about this issue, but they have not been presented with the basic facts in regard to the matter. Let me look at these facts and let us go directly to one of the two matters mentioned by the Opposition. One wonders what the Opposition's position on this matter is because it is so totally confused. I will come to that point later.

SPEECH.PARA: One amendment to be moved by the Opposition relates to the supposed inadequate compensation being offered to Tasmanians. What have we offered? We have offered to supply all the power which this project would create by alternative power projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one? Name them.

—I am ready to name them. I will come to that. I will table a paper written not by any biased authority but by two economists from the University of Tasmania, Dr Rutherford and Mr Thretewey. It is called ' Compensation and the Dam'. It is a discussion paper. It shows that there are thermal alternatives for the creation of electricity in Tasmania. It shows that the cost of the thermal scheme or of an alternative hydro-electric scheme is such that it can be compensated for in the offer made by the Federal Government. So let us not talk about the provision of power. In order to save this dam we are prepared to provide power by alternative means. This point has not been prominently featured by the Tasmanian Press, to its disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us talk about the jobs involved. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that we will provide alternative job schemes to replace all the jobs which have been and will be created if the dam goes ahead. So, what is the argument for destroying this area of natural beauty and national heritage? It is not an argument based on a need for power because we will provide power in alternative ways. It is not an argument for jobs because we have said we will provide an equal number of jobs. What then is it? The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anthony ) said that we were provoking a constitutional crisis. Who is provoking a constitutional confrontation? It is, in fact, the Federal Opposition and the Tasmanian Government. They have adopted a bloody-minded attitude on this issue, to destroy an area of natural beauty for no reason whatsoever. As I said, jobs and power can be created by alternative means. What then is the reason? It is quite clear. The Opposition wants confrontation for none other than purely political reasons. This kind of bloody-mindedness is an absolute outrage when one considers the importance of that area.

Many previous speakers have spoken about the beauty of this area and its importance in terms of conservation. What about the Aboriginal relics in the area? Archaeologists are developing new techniques all the time. If we flood this area and destroy things of interest to archaeologists we will, in fact, do a great disservice to humanity because that area, important in terms of research , will be destroyed forever. Archaeologists and scientists will not be in a position to study this area and find out what it can tell us about primitive man and about the early Australian Aborigines. Of course, I know that honourable members opposite do not give a damn about the origins of man and other important scientific investigations. They are not concerned about that at all. They think that to provide a piddling amount of electricity is more important than the destruction of this area in terms of its archaeological importance, leaving aside its importance for conservation reasons.

Let me say this: This dam will not be built. The Australian people made their determination on 5 March. We are determined to use every possible means to prevent the building of this dam. As I said, there is no reason, in terms of power or jobs, for the building of this dam. The Tasmanian people are wonderful people. I have been down there and I have talked to them. They would take a different view had it not been for such a total exercise in propaganda and bias that was presented to them.

Let me talk a little more about the constitutional issues raised by the Leader of the National Party. He had the gall to tell us that, in fact, his party represents conservation issues. Was it not the Premier of Queensland, the most prominent member of that party, who wanted to drill on the Great Barrier Reef? Who was it if it was not him? Was it not the National Party that was concerned to destroy Kakadu National Park?

TALK.START.PARA: —Produce the evidence of this. You know it is absolute nonsense. There has never been such a proposal. Produce the evidence.
—Order! The honourable member for Hume will remain silent.

—Since the honourable member for Hume has been in Opposition, he has been very vocal, talks a lot of rot and interjects whenever anyone else presents an argument which he does not want to hear. The honourable member is welcome to bring Mr Bjelke-Petersen here and let him testify about this great conservation record. We are prepared to have a debate at any time on the conservation record of the Premier of Queensland.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I just had a telephone call from Tasmania and was told that the debate cannot be heard by listeners there. Would you please ask honourable members to be quiet?
—There is no point of order. The honourable member should not take a frivolous point of order.

—The Leader of the National Party referred to constitutional issues. He quoted a statement that we have heard read out here many times and which was referred to by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) at the Australian Constitutional Convention. But the Leader of the Opposition and other honourable members did not mention that the Chief Justice was in the minority in this opinion. He was not in the majority at all. He was expressing his own personal view and not the view of the majority of judges, who felt that the Commonwealth rightfully had the external affairs power. Who referred that issue to the High Court in the first place? Was it not the Fraser Federal Government that referred that issue to the High Court because it wanted to prove that it had that external affairs power? I ask honourable members opposite to answer that question. Of course it was the previous Federal Government. Honourable members who supported that Government now read to us a section of the Chief Justice's remarks supposedly to frighten the rest of Australia about the constitutional implications. I will tell the House about constitutional implications. What would be the position if a nation could not sign and be bound by international treaties? What would be the position if international treaties had to be torn up because of bloody-minded action, as I have described it, by one State in relation to matters of international importance?

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that honourable gentlemen opposite do not consider issues of the environment to be of international importance. If we were to adopt that attitude , where would we be in respect of the law of the sea, where would we be in respect of all of the other environmental issues that involve international agreements? Therefore, let us think about this. We need the power to make treaties in relation to the protection of the environment. The area which is the subject of this legislation was nominated by the Tasmanian Government for inclusion on the World Heritage List. That nomination was approved by the World Heritage Committee. We are bound by the international treaty which we have signed in relation to that listing. Therefore, it follows that constitutionally and in terms of the kinds of powers which every other nation has we ought to have the power to sign those treaties and to stand by them.

I want to make some remarks about the amendment moved on behalf of the Opposition. The amendment refers to the inadequacy of compensation. A table I have shows the relative cost of building thermal versus hydro-electric power stations. The difference in cost is given in terms of both the building and operating of these stations on the basis of an interest rate of 10 per cent. These tables appear in the report to which I referred earlier. According to the first table, the difference between building these two types of power stations is only $138m. In addition, a second table shows that the difference in terms of employment costs is $82m. I am using these figures as an example to show that options and alternatives are available. These considerations should be studied and worked upon and a reasonable attitude should be shown in respect of their development. The difference between these two alternatives in terms of total cost is only $220m.

The Government has agreed to offer much more than that. In fact, the previous Federal Liberal Government offered the Tasmanian people $500m. I am sure that if the Tasmanian Premier had taken a constructive attitude and had been prepared to negotiate to help develop alternative forms of power and create alternative jobs we would have been prepared to increase that figure in order to save the river which we consider to be one of the great conservation and heritage issues, but instead, what do we find? The Tasmanian Premier is not even prepared to talk about the matter.

Someone mentioned figures in excess of $2 billion to $3 billion. We might be prepared to negotiate on a reasonable basis by way of an independent expert study and even increase our offer substantially. But we are not prepared to give away the world to the Tasmanian Government because of its blackmailing tactics.

It has been supposed that the determination of the High Court will be the conclusion of this matter. It will not be the conclusion of this matter as far as many of my colleagues and I are concerned. As far as I am concerned, we will continue to try to fulfil our international obligations and our obligations to the people of Australia in relation to this area. I have shown that there are alternatives available in terms of power and in terms of jobs. There is absolutely no reason why this dam should proceed except for the purpose of political point scoring on the part of the Tasmanian Government and the Federal Opposition. We reject their arguments. We are ready to fight until we win victory on behalf of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity, Mr Deputy Speaker, to congratulate you on your election to the position of Chairman of Committees. The debate that is now ensuing over the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill concentrates on two things. First of all, there is the assault on our Constitution and the threat that that poses to our Federation. Secondly, and obviously this is very important to me and my colleagues from Tasmania, there is the threat to stop the Tasmanian people from building the Franklin Dam.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleagues the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and the Leader of the National Party (Mr Anthony) have more than adequately dealt with the first issue-the threat to the Constitution that is posed by this Bill. Therefore , I will concentrate purely on the Tasmanian issues. I do not think I can recall such a vicious attack on members of parliament, both Federal and State, or such an unprecedented attack on the people of a State. Speaker after speaker has abused the Tasmanian State Government, the State Premier and the State's newspaper and other media outlets. Overall there is an assertion that Tasmanians are barbarians, vandals or simpletons and do not understand the debate that they have been listening to for the last three, four or five years.

To begin with, I just want to make this very clear: There are many people in Tasmania of both political persuasions who have very strong views about the environmental problems posed by the construction of this dam. Many people-I suppose they include members of my own family-have agonised over the decision that has to be taken as to whether we save the environment or provide Tasmania with its energy needs. It has not been an easy decision. It is not simply that people do not understand or that somehow they have been subjected to a barrage from a biased Press, as the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) would have us believe. Honest people have made honest decisions. However much honourable members opposite might like to interject now, to continue to downgrade this debate into an attack on personalities and an attack on a State, that happens to be the fact.

The crux of the argument is this: How is Tasmania going to meet its energy needs in the 1990s? The fact is that this has been conveniently overlooked or ignored by every speaker opposite, except the honourable member for Burke and he is so far off the track it does not matter. I will deal with him in a moment. The fundamental issue is this: Where is the energy to come from? Unless there is some addition to the generating system that exists now, there will not be enough electricity to meet the needs in the 1990s.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true. You know it is not true.

—That is the situation. The projections that have been made for the construction of the dam are based on a 2.7 per cent increase, which is a very conservative estimate. The construction of that dam, based on that appreciation of energy needs of 2.7 per cent, will provide Tasmania's energy needs only up to the year 2000. With that assessment it is important to recognise, because a lot of claptrap has been spoken about the use of this new increment of power, that the facts are that 70 per cent of that power will go to commercial, light industrial and domestic users. Only 30 per cent of the allocation will go to heavy industry. Of that heavy industry, presently 19 users of that power will be bidding for that 30 per cent. The honourable member for Burke wanted some facts. The Government Whip wanted some facts; so let them digest those facts so that we can have a balanced view on this argument.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Burke is the only one who has tried to tackle the question of where the alternative power will come from if this dam is not built. He has proposed a thermal station. That reveals a very interesting situation in the Government because I thought it had its act together on this. It speaks so confidently about it. The Government tells us: 'Stop the dam. It won't be built. Don't worry, everything is all right. We will provide the jobs and the power'. The honourable member for Burke says that a thermal station will provide the power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I did not say that a thermal station was going to be provided. What I said was that it was one of the options.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Bass.

—I do not really care what he said exactly. Let us deal with the position in the way he has now put it. He suggested that a thermal station would be one of the alternatives. I might add that it is the only one he gave. He did not mention a single other alternative. Let us deal with the thermal alternative . I have a letter from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Let us hear what he has to say about the matter:

SPEECH.PARA: First, the Labor Party is committed to an all Hydro policy for energy development. Coal fired thermal power stations in Tasmania have been rejected as unsuitable.

Not only did he write that letter to the people on the west coast of Tasmania during the election campaign, but also he appeared on television and spoke on radio programs in our State and rejected that time and again. So we have a situation where these people in the Government are determined to stop the construction of the dam but do not have a policy for what is going to replace it -not a single policy. If ever there was an argument for the devolution of power in this country, if ever there was an argument that it is necessary to have State and local governments so that they understand the local situation and can provide policies to meet the local situations, whether they be in local government areas or in the States, it has been presented in this debate. Canberra, the fount of all knowledge, is going to produce the policies for this State, overriding what the State Government wants and overriding what the people of the State want. What have we got? We have a debate characterised by an honourable member who does not even know the policy of his own Government, characterised by other Government members who have never produced an alternative to the scheme that has been promoted-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is the second time I have been misrepresented by the honourable member and I demand-
—The honourable member will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

—The honourable member for Burke is being condemned out of his own mouth. Apart from that, this debate has been characterised by honourable members and Ministers who are totally insensitive to the Tasmanian feelings. We have seen their arrogance to the democratic process which has taken place in Tasmania as speaker after speaker has sought to reduce it or to put a misleading slant on it. I refer finally to the gross stupidity of most of them in not understanding what the issues are all about in the debate in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things which characterised most of their speeches was how terrible it was that three members from Tasmania could come in here and stick up for the rights of their State. Somehow this seemed to be anathema to them. But they conveniently forget that we do not just represent the States' rights argument in here. It is an argument that has been put by Labor governments and Labor oppositions over the years that this debate has been going on. It started with the famous Premier Lowe himself. I ask honourable members to read what I hold up here. The headline is: 'Lowe tells Canberra: Stay out of S-W issue'. The article states:
The Premier, Mr Lowe, last night told the Federal Parliament-including the Labor Opposition-to keep its nose out of Tasmania's business.

That sort of comment has been reflected time and again by the current Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, Mr Wriedt. When this policy was first produced at the Labor Party State conference he fought against it principally on the basis that it had nothing to do with the Labor Party nationally. We are only acquitting our responsibility to our people in our State, and it is a responsibility, thank God, that the Labor Party members in the State also recognise.

I now deal with some of the comments made by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), the Mr know-all of this Parliament. I think it is the contribution that he made to this debate that offends me most of all. His speech was vindictive, condescending and gratuitous. For one who prides himself on knowing everything and who can suggest policies for other people-I might say he also pretends to be a rationalist-it is a disgrace to him. I am sorry that he is not in here to listen to the debate. At last I am glad to see that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) has stopped being a will-o' -the-wisp and has had the decency to stay in here and listen to the debate for five minutes. Why do I say what I have about the Minister for Science and Technology, the Minister for know-all? On the surface it may have been a smooth little speech full of all the good buzz words. It had a few comments to ridicule Tasmanians and he had his sycophants behind him having a bit of a giggle about it. But when his speech is analysed it will be seen that it got down at best to a gross distortion of what the basic problems are in Tasmania. There was no analysis of energy use. He knows well what the assessments were in Tasmania for the projections to the end of the century. He conveniently forgot that while he busily got about ridiculing me, other honourable members and Tasmanians. He gave absolutely no clear understanding and exposition of what the manufacturing problem is in Tasmania. He was trying to pretend that heavy industry has no more use for energy in Tasmania. I demonstrated that there are 19 heavy industry users queued up to try to make use of the last 30 per cent of the increment in power that will be available from the dam. As usual he trotted out the fact that 16 industries are waiting to go in Tasmania. We interjected and asked him to tell us what those 16 industries are. He has promised to table them in the House . We look forward to the tabling of the list of those 16 industries. I hope it will not just be some more vague descriptions of the sorts of things he was talking about last night. We want to see 16 industries specified by name and by type when he tables that list which he says he has.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tourist industry is one.
—The honourable member should keep quiet. He is making a fool of himself. The only good thing about the speech made by the Minister for know-all was this-

—The Minister for Science and Technology; I stand corrected. The only good thing about the speech by the Minister for Science and Technology was that, thank heavens, he gave it in Tasmania and people heard him. SPEECH.PARA: The second reading speech of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment was one of the most disgraceful speeches to have been made in this Parliament. It was mean, insensitive and deceitful. If I have the time I will go through it paragraph by paragraph and point out what leads me to make that criticism. First of all, I refer to the question of co-operation. We have these great conciliators on the Government side. The honourable member for Burke accuses us of promoting the argument on this issue, but it is the Government which is promoting it. It is causing this confrontation, and that flies in the face of what it has been claiming since 5 March. The Minister said in his speech:

I want to stress at this point the importance we attach to State and Territory co-operation in this area. Nominations by Australia to the World Heritage List have been made in a spirit of co-operation with State authorities. . . It follows that there would normally be consultation with the State or Territory.

What a spirit of conciliation and co-operation we have seen in this House over the last 24 hours. Member after member of the Government, without arguing the case, has been content to be vindictive and insensitive and to offer gratuitous insults to me and the other people of Tasmania. It is the same sort of thing that we have heard time and again. At the Adelaide conference the Prime Minister -I bet he regrets the stupidity of ever getting hooked on this issue-said:

The new Commonwealth Government is committed as a responsible federal partner to approach the use of the external affairs power as indeed it approaches all Commonwealth powers-in a spirit of consultation and co-operation with States wherever appropriate.

What a hollow, hypocritical statement that is. What has been the co-operation or the attempt at co-operation with Tasmania? The Minister has never been down to investigate the issue; he has never been down to consult-

TALK.START.PARA: —How much would you like to bet?

—Let me make that statement perfectly clear: He, and every other member of the Government, Minister or otherwise, may have been down to consult with the conservationists, but I am getting at this spirit of consultation with the States. Not one member or Minister has spoken to his counterpart in the State Parliament, asked the Hydro-Electric Commission to give its view or tried to go to the areas they have never been able to get into. If that is a spirit of consultation then it can only be one of the most hypocritical efforts ever made in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the basis of this consultation, this attempt to talk to us? The bottom line in the whole issue has been repeated by the Prime Minister time and again. It is this: I will come down and talk to you and consult if you agree not to build the dam'. That is the bottom line in the attempts at negotiation. What a negotiator! That is like the burglar putting the gun to the poor would-be victim and saying: 'Hand over your money; I will start negotiations with you but I will pull the trigger if you don't'. That is the basis of the consultation. Again we have the claim that has been trotted out by so many members of this Parliament that somehow the Federal Government has a mandate for what it is doing. That was repeated in this mean speech by a Minister who cannot even be bothered listening to the debate. Part of his speech says:
. . . the Government is fulfilling a commitment given to the people of Australia and is supported by the overwhelming majority of the Australian people.

Where is this mandate? There has never been a fair dinkum debate on this matter on the mainland. It is sad to say that where there was a debate the members on our side who tried to join in abused the then Government for its actions. They were running scared because of the Tasmanian Wilderness Society's operations against them in their electorates. Had they understood the debate in Tasmania and put it to their electorates and had we had the chance to put it to the rest of Australia I am certain the mainland States would have understood the real issue. But it has never been put; there has been a vacuum on mainland Australia. There is no doubt about that. Anyway, I do not believe that even that vacuum of a lack of understanding really adds to the Government's mandate.

Let us compare that to the situation in Tasmania. There have been referendums and State elections and independents who stood on anti-dam issues. Dr Bob Brown and an Australian Democrat, Dr Sanders, stood on this issue. There has been a Federal election also. In each case those independent members have been defeated on an anti-dam issue. People have spoken in a solid way, as indicated by their election of the State Government and their voting for the five Tasmanian Opposition members of this House. That is the mandate which the Government accuses the Premier and the Opposition of abusing. The State Government has a clear mandate to build the dam, and, thank heavens, it will. Unless the Government is prepared to give me an extension of time I will have to stop going through these points.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have gone five minutes over the agreed time now.
—Will the Minister give me another five or 10 minutes now?
—No.

—No, he is not game to take it on. This dam should be built. The State needs the development because it provides the energy it requires for this generation and other generations to come. The issue has been debated in Tasmania for years, and the Tasmanians have made a decision. They have given the Tasmanian Government a firm directive to proceed with the construction, and that work is proceeding. Equally important is that this legislation strikes at the heart of our federal system. It is bad enough that the Federal Government should try to stop a project in Tasmania which the people of Tasmania have voted on but it is even worse that it will now impose its will on the rest of the States of Australia. This Bill, as it stands, achieves everything that those who wish to centralise power in Canberra want. I oppose the Bill but support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly).

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept that the Tasmanian Government or Tasmanian members opposite are protecting the interests of other Tasmanians.

—I rise to support a point of order that the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) was trying to make. He was anxious to table a letter. Mr Deputy Speaker, I wonder whether you would give him the opportunity to do so.
—I think the honourable member for Burke is quite capable of seeking to attract the attention of the Chair. He did not effectively do so.
