—I repeat that I do not accept that the Tasmanian Government or Tasmanian members opposite are protecting the interests of other Tasmanians. In the House this morning, an Opposition member, the very honourable and very independent member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), supported the Government's stand, particularly in the first half of his speech. I agree with his statement that if the project should go ahead 'it will be the most perverse and expensive make-work program which could be conceived'. The principle of States' rights, as I have seen it manifested in this House, has nothing to do with protecting the rights of people within our States. All it has to do with is the division of power-governmental power and party political power. It has to do with people and members-in this instance members of the Opposition who wish to get a little publicity and keep their seats secure-and it has nothing to do with getting information through to assist the people in that area. This was most obvious last week in Adelaide when I attended the Australian Constitutional Convention. During that week I was obliged to see previous Government members who, when in government--

—I raise a point of order. A few minutes ago the honourable member for Burke indicated that he was tabling a letter. I have just inquired as to the whereabouts of that letter and apparently it is not on the table at the present time.

—Order! The honourable member for Braddon need not have interrupted the honourable member for Lilley on that point of inquiry. It is not a point of order. The processes should apply. I have no doubt that the letter as presented is in safe custody.

—The type of process that is occurring in this chamber typifies what I am trying to say-pity the people from Tasmania or any State who become entangled in this childish game of whether we table or do not table a document. The so-called argument on States' rights will strangle the people in that area with misinformation and through the party political parading that is going on here.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Constitutional Convention which was held in Adelaide last week, the States of Queensland and Tasmania thoroughly abused the system. The whole idea of that forum was to ensure that there was an objective apolitical background to what has become party political government in this country. One would have to be naive to think that we could get rid of party politics from government. It makes it all the more important that a Constitutional Convention, where we look at reform of the Constitution, be objective. During that week we saw the spectacle of Opposition members repeating their behaviour in the Parliament by getting up and voting against propositions which they themselves had proposed to the last Convention while in government.

Most particularly I think of the Family Law Act, changes to which should have the agreement of Opposition and Government members. In the past, certain changes did have the support of Liberal-National Party members, but last week those people got up and voted against them. This means that the children whose parents are subjected to marital break-ups are still torn between State and Federal courts. Such families are having to wait for as long as 12 months before they get justice. I think it is worth putting the basis on which all this nonsense is founded and the hole in the argument of States' rights.

It is not in Tasmania's interests to spend a large amount of money building a huge status structure and employing a small number of people to generate electric power which will not be needed in the near future. The initial strategy of the Tasmanian Government was to attract industry to Tasmania, using cheap power generation as a carrot. But with the development of new power plants in New South Wales and Victoria the strategy is looking sick. The fact is that Tasmania's entire power grid produces one gigawatt while the Eraring power plant in New South Wales alone has added one gigawatt and the Loy Yang power station in Victoria has added a massive 2.5 gigawatts to that State's output. The point is that Tasmania has unequalled natural assets which would attract world-wide interest. If the South West Tasmanian wilderness area is protected, tourists should be drawn to the area in their thousands, particularly if some of the money saved is injected into the tourist industry. The fact remains that Tasmania is no longer the only State which can offer an abundance of cheap power to industry. Therefore, Tasmania no longer has comparative advantage over other States in terms of attractions it can offer to industry: Hence, the Hydro- Electric Commission's strategy for the development of Tasmania needs to be re- examined, as does the rationale for the Gordon below Franklin Dam, and any other dam.

Another point to note is that, even if Tasmania were successfully to attract manufacturing industry to the State, the chances are that employment in manufacturing industry in Tasmania would decline. The assumption that increased electricity consumption leads to more jobs is not a valid one. Tasmania's manufacturing industries are energy intensive industries. They use 60 per cent of Tasmania's electricity but employ only 6 per cent of the work force. During the 1970s, energy use by those industries has increased by 26 per cent compared with only 6 per cent for the Australian manufacturing industry as a whole. But over the same period employment in the manufacturing sector in Tasmania fell by 16 per cent compared with only 9 per cent of Australia as a whole. In other words, the more power that was used by industry in Tasmania the more jobs were shed. This is not an attack on the manufacturing base but it is an appeal for objectivity in using the resources of that State effectively and efficiently, which must be done if the people in the area are to be protected and if they are to have a decent usage of their tax money.

The situation whereby the Tasmanian manufacturing industry uses six times the amount of electricity per output and two times the amount of other fuels per dollar of output can no longer continue. What has happened is that over the 1970s increasing use of electricity in industry in Tasmania has paralleled a decline in employment because electricity is used as a substitute for labour. That is all right as it stands but it is absolutely essential that we get job creative industries into Tasmania. The most job intensive industry is the tourist industry. What beautiful potential that wonderful State has. That resource should be exploited. Tasmania should be better represented by Opposition members in this House. I do not suggest that the existing power base industry should be discouraged but that the Tasmanian Government should consider the most efficient way of managing the States resources to the benefit of Tasmanians while retaining the unique wilderness area for all Australians and all people in the world, including the Tasmanians.

In this context I would question the efficiency and the motivation of the Tasmanian Government in considering the feasibility of alternative energy forms. There are many options which should be investigated. I state here that I am proud to be part of a government and a party which encourages initiative and thinking on the part of back benchers as well as members of the front bench. We do not have to sit here gagged by our own Government and our own Ministers before we can say something which has not yet been formulated fully in policy, as was suggested by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) today-which is why I say that.

There are a number of options which could be looked at. The one that I mention, because I am concerned about the lack of response by the Tasmanian Government, is that of wind power, which has much going for it. In fact, there is much generated in this chamber. In 1982, following a call for tenders to provide wind power on King Island, the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission claimed that wind energy was still too expensive. However, the HEC has been strongly criticised for the very limited advertising of the call for tenders and the short period permitted to supply a new turbine of quite detailed specification. More recently , a private company, Tasmanian Wind Enterprises, has asked the Tasmanian Government for permission to interconnect two 55 kilowatt Danish wind turbines to the King Island supply. The Tasmanian Government has approved the project in principle and has given the HEC responsibility for negotiations. The company aims to sell the wind generated electricity to the HEC at a cost of 90 per cent of the value of the diesel fuel saved, and it expects to make a profit. That is the type of efficiency at which the Tasmanian Government should be looking. That is the sort of alternative.

A recent survey by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in the north and north-west of Tasmania has found these areas to be endowed with winds with high and consistent speeds. The CSIRO has rated the sites examined as very favourable by world standards. The region also appears to be well suited to the use of wind power from environmental perspective in that it comprises largely cleared sheep pasture and heath country. No trees would need to be removed, and the provision of access tracks is not seen as financially or environmentally significant. Sheep grazing could continue beneath the towers and several landowners have expressed interest in a wind power project. It is a pity that while people are playing party politics, this sort of alternative and these facts are not considered, so that we can maintain a unique and necessary area in an age when so much destruction of the natural environment has been taking place and, at the same time, create more jobs and produce the power which is necessary.

The case for the preservation of South West Tasmania as it stands is beyond dispute. In fact, some feel that we are 10 years too late and that the real integrity of the South West of Tasmania was lost when Lake Pedder was flooded and enlarged, taking a large chunk out of the very centre of the wilderness. What remains may yet become a marginal wilderness area if proposed plans by the Tasmanian Government to exploit the South West area for minerals and timber get off the ground. More dams are also planned. If we are fair dinkum about preserving South West Tasmania as a wilderness area, work on the Gordon below Franklin Dam must cease immediately while that wilderness which remains can still justly lay claim to the description. There is no reason to bulldoze into the area and move with such haste, unless it is true that the Tasmanian Government is holding a fiat grasp on the people. It should be able to wait, so that the area is not destroyed, until some solution is reached between the Federal and State governments, both of which represent the people in the area.

In the whole of the Southern Hemisphere-one half of this entire planet-there are only three genuine wilderness areas which do not consist of desert, ocean, jungle or ice. These areas are found in western Patagonia, at the southern tip of the South American continent; Fiordland, in the south-west corner of the South Island of New Zealand; and South West Tasmania. In relation to the size of the total land mass of each of these continents or islands, these wilderness areas represent an infinitesimal proportion of the whole. Their economic worth, aside from tourism, is negligible. Their value, then, is not measurable and clearly depends on the viewpoint of the observer. However, one thing is certain. If properly cared for, they will increase in many types of values over time. South West Tasmania's worth in an increasingly urbanised, polluted and treeless national and world landscape will then be truly immeasurable. People will have something to be proud of, both as Tasmanians and Australians, because Tasmania, and the South West wilderness area included, will in effect be priceless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to enter this debate briefly, if only to indicate my support for what the Tasmanian members of this House have been saying here this afternoon. Because, understandably, most of the speakers from the Opposition side have been Tasmanians, one could be excused for thinking that they are carrying this issue and burden alone. I want to indicate quite clearly that that is certainly not so. I am speaking not only for myself but also for the great majority of Australians on the mainland. There may be many people of the mainland who do not understand the issue and have an emotional feeling that the dam should not be built. However, if one asks those people, as I have on many occassions, whether, the dam aside, they think this is something that Tasmanians should decide, one finds that overwhelmingly they put up their hands and say yes. So I am speaking not only for myself but also for them as well.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many genuinely and firmly held views on this matter, but there are some that are not so genuine. It was seen as a popular cause about two months ago by the Australian Labor Party, something to hang one's hat on, something on which to campaign. One member of the ALP in another place has said, quite glibly , 'It seemed like a good idea at the time', and now the ALP is stuck with it. It is not just a Tasmanian issue, as many speakers have already said. It affects all Australians, because if the Bill goes through we shall rue the day in the upset of the balance in the federal system under which we have lived successfully for 83 years. It is an attack, the right honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) said a short time ago, on the very structure of the federal basis of our political system. It is worth while saying a few words on that basis, because what we are seeing here is an attempt to centralise the administration of Australia in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish. What about the United States?

—It might be all right in other countries under a different system. Someone mentions the United States. I have no doubt that someone will mention Britain. They have different systems. We have a federal system, to which we on this side of the House will very strongly adhere. That is why many of us oppose Bills such as this. I dread the day when we shall have a decision in Canberra, overriding the State Government decisions, which will make the same laws that pertain to the people in South West Tasmania applicable equally to the people of Torres Strait or of the Kimberleys. What a hopeless situation that will be if the Government continues this centralist role.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to quote from something that was said in the Senate just before lunch. It indicates that it is a populist view-something which was good at the time-on the part of many members of the ALP. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in answer to a question said:

I simply reiterate the point I made in answer to Senator Chipp when he first raised this question. Matters relating to the administration of justice within New South Wales and involving no larger national issues or allegations about breaches of federal laws are and must remain properly a matter for the State concerned.

They are matters for the State concerned-notwithstanding that the matter concerned the Australian Broadcasting Commission and a very proper matter of justice in Australia. The Attorney-General went on:

I do not believe and the Government does not believe that it would be appropriate in the circumstances to which Senator Chipp referred for the Commonwealth to involve itself in a matter which is . . . one of States rights.

Senator Gareth Evans said that some hours ago in the Senate. So he wants to have it both ways. One of the other things which amuse me and annoy me to some extent in this debate is that the people who make the most outlandish and emotional statements on this issue have never been to South West Tasmania. I do not know whether the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) has been there. Having listened to her speech and some of the rather foolish things she said about wind power as a substitute for hydro-electric power, I cannot believe that she has ever been there.

Apart from talking about wind power, the honourable member for Lilley and three or four other honourable members opposite have today referred to tourism. They have asked why the Tasmanian Government does not do something about tourism. My God! If they had been there they would have seen that the creation of this dam will do more for tourism in Tasmania than any other single thing that has been done for 50 years. So I ask honourable members opposite not to talk about tourism when they do not undertstand what they are talking about. They can hold their views--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I want to put the record straight. I was saying that we would like more of this money to go to tourism. It is not a question of what is being spent.
—Order! The honourable member is free to take a point of order but she is debating the matter. The honourable member will resume her seat.

—They can hold their views about whether the dam should be built, but they should not say that Tasmania should be encouraging tourism by not building the dam. If honourable members opposite had been there they would realise that the area to be flooded is a very remote area. It cannot be reached by road. It can be reached only by rafting down the Franklin River. Fewer than 2,000 people a year would go there.
—You do not know what you are talking about.

—As it is a very important issue and concerns State rights, some weeks ago I took the trouble to go and have a look. I went by road as far as I could; then I went by helicopter; then I went by boat; and then I walked. So I happen to know something about what I am talking about, which is in stark contrast to a lot of the nonsense and emotionalism that has been talked here today by supporters of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the worst speeches I have heard was that by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), to which the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) referred. The Minister usually takes a fairly rational approach to most matters. Yesterday, in the most pompous and condescending speech that I think I have ever heard in this House, he proceeded to talk down to some 400,000 Tasmanians in a way that I should think will preclude his visits to Tasmania forever, because if the Tasmanians have any sense they will make sure that what he said is broadcast throughout the length and breadth of Tasmania. I hope that it has been broadcast by today.

No one denies that the area in question is a beautiful part of Australia and that it is a very wild and beautiful river. The problem is that there is no access to the area. The Tasmanians propose to dam part of it so that people- apart from the power suppliers-can get in and have a look at this part of Tasmania. Australia is a young, developing and expanding country. I ask whether it is likely that in the years past, when some of our major projects were built, such an attitude existed? Is it likely that the Snowy Mountains scheme supplying power to all Australia would ever have been completed if we had an attitude similar to that of those people opposing the dam? The answer is no. It would have been stopped by emotional issues being raised falsely by members of the Australian Labor Party. There would never have been a hope of building the Snowy Mountains scheme if the Australian Labor Party had carried on then as it is now. No doubt there will be people who will be raising these issues about the Burdekin Dam in North Queensland.

I have not heard too many people in this House complaining that we are ripping the top off a hill a few hundred yards from here to build a new Parliament House that will provide us with a lot of comfort. No doubt it could be argued that that hill is part of the inalienable heritage of the Australian Capital Territory. There is not a whimper about that sort of thing. It would be better if we could all go ahead and not destroy any of the environment, but how is it possible to achieve that in an expanding, developing country? It is just not possible.

On balance, I very much oppose this Bill. I oppose it because of the implications for the federal system of government. I oppose it because the Tasmanians have decided after four popular votes on the issue that they want the dam. I support the dam basically because in my view the advantages will outweigh the disadvantages. That is always a decision that has to be made. I think it is a very sorry day and that we will all regret in the long term that this Bill has come before the House today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin Ms W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the debate today the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) said that the Hawke Government, by introducing the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill, was taking something precious away from Tasmania. I suggest that he and his party are trying to take something precious away from Australia. What kind of issue are we debating here today? Are we really here to talk about States' rights or are the issues more subtle? It is interesting to remember that the Fraser Island debate was used by the Premier of Queensland to defend what he said were his State's rights. The Fraser Government then demanded the right to overrule that claim and it did so. Why then does the Opposition claim that the Hawke Government has sinister motives when it demands that right also?

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me and to many others who are concerned to protect the South West of Tasmania that the real issues are in danger of being submerged by the inflated rhetoric emanating from here today, and from the Premier of Tasmania and his power-hungry advisers. During the last few months we have been subjected to a confused and blustering attempt by Mr Gray and the Opposition to conceal the real economic and environmental conflict surrounding the dam controversy. In addition, the Opposition in this Parliament is intent on capitalising on the issue in the most blatantly misleading fashion. As a recent correspondent to the Australian noted:
. . . if a dam is ever built it will be . . . a monument to an exercise in cynicism and cheap politics.

Let me refer briefly to the economic aspect of the scheme to flood the Gordon below Franklin. If the work on the dam goes ahead it will provide approximately 890 jobs. These jobs will be short term. They will be almost exclusively jobs for men who will be working in extremely isolated and unpleasant conditions. The Tasmanian Government has ignored this Government's offer of a much larger number of jobs. The 890 jobs provided by the building of the dam are therefore to be created at the expense of a much larger number of jobs elsewhere. But the final economic irony is that in the long term, once the dam is completed, the scheme will provide only 29 jobs.

The United Nations Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage lists several criteria which an area must meet to merit a place on the World Heritage List. Only one criterion must be satisfied to merit a listing. Such is the significance of the Franklin valley in South West Tasmania that the World Heritage Committee judged that the region met all four criteria of outstanding universal value for natural properties and three of the six criteria for natural properties. The South West of Tasmania is one of only 38 world heritage areas which have qualified in terms of natural areas. The natural richness of the area has been well documented. Preliminary investigations into a small part of the threatened district have revealed several shelters and caves which show evidence of human occupation. Scientists estimate that the area was inhabited by humans more than 20,000 years ago at the peak of the last Ice Age. The special climatic features of the area have preserved, in quite astonishing detail, the evidence of the way those first Tasmanians lived. A massive amount of data is available to scientists in the more remote areas of the Franklin valley. Huon pines still growing in the area are estimated to be nearly 2,500 years old. A fallen trunk of a Huon pine was recently established to be 7,500 years old and another fallen tree has been dated to almost 12,000 years old.

The valley is also a stronghold of rare marsupials like the Tasmanian devil which is extinct on the Australian mainland. It also hosts many rare birds and plants, many of which were in grave danger of extinction even before the Tasmanian Government determined that they should meet their end sooner rather than later. No scientific survey has ever been made of the reptile life but the Hydro-Electric Commission's environmental impact study found 269 invertebrate species, a quarter of which were new to science. What do these figures mean? Are the advocates of the 'No Dams' campaign merely concerned to have a few fluffy animals, an old tree trunk and mouldy human relics? Our opponents on the opposite side of this House seem to think so. What they completely fail to understand is the whole concept of a natural national heritage. They entirely miss the point that as human beings we have a responsbility to ourselves and to others beyond that of immediate economic advantage. They fail to see that we are responsible to the world at large for part of our common heritage. We owe it to our children and our grandchildren not to deprive them of the unique opportunities for understanding offered by areas like the South West of Tasmania . If we permit this area to be destroyed, we will brand ourselves in the eyes of the world as red necked philistines, as having sold out to technology and economic interest to satisfy an immediate and ill-considered need.

One of the defining characteristics of a wilderness is that it cannot be evaluated in economic terms. I urge this House to show Australia and the world that we are capable of justifying the saving of the Franklin on human, aesthetic and environmentally responsible grounds and are not bound by the mentality of galloping economism to which various groups and governments in this country seem to have succumbed. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for giving me an opportunity to speak in this debate. Honourable members will know that from time to time I have expressed quite severe reservations about this particular dam-the Gordon below Franklin Dam-as a proposal. I am not against the building of dams per se-in fact I was discussing this a few moments ago with one of my colleagues -but I have been persuaded by my concern about some of the archeological aspects of the caves on the Gordon River likely to be affected by this particular development. Other members have quoted in some detail from the views of people whom I respect very much-people like Professor Mulvaney, Professor Rhys Jones and others who have been involved in research in this area and who have detailed the importance of the sites in this region not only for Australia but also internationally. From time to time I have stated my concern to my constituents who have approached me about the building of this dam on this site.

SPEECH.PARA: Per se, I am not against the building of dams. I certainly understand very much the States' rights argument. I suspect that, if there were an argument in New South Wales over the building of a dam similar to the Warragamba Dam, New South Wales people who might be deprived of water and other facilities-perhaps electricity and the like-might well feel as hostile as do Tasmanians to other people intruding into a decision that they traditionally have thought was one which they were entitled to make. But for all that, I believe that, I, as an Australian, as are others, am entitled to express a view on the matter and entitled to put that view as frankly as I have to constituents and as frankly as I have here today.

Some people have said that one has to visit the site to be able to make an assessment of whether the arguments are justified. That is a view that I do not accept. I have often been known, like many other members of this House, to express a view on the Soviet Union and on the virtues of communism. The fact is that I have never been to the Soviet Union but I have never shirked from expressing a view on that matter and, I suspect, nor have many others. One does not need to have been to a particular place or location to be able to express a view or to have read the opinions or to be aware of the matters and the issues involved. On this matter one is entitled to form a judgment on the information that is publicly available. But I am concerned-I have expressed this view to my constituents-at the pace with which the Federal Government has proceeded to intervene in this matter. I want to see the dam stopped. I do not want to see this dam proceed. But I believe that the Federal Government by its action has heightened the possibility of the dam being built. In my judgment, pursuing in a cavalier and reckless way Commonwealth power assumed to exist is likely to lead to a situation in which we will find that that power will not be upheld. I would put it on the basis that there is possibly a 50-50 chance that the Federal Government may well lose. If the Government has the view that there is a prospect of losing the case before the High Court and it proceeds to put the arguments in the Court by the pursuit of legislation, it will only drive deeper and deeper divisions between the Tasmanian Government and the Commonwealth Government. Any prospect of stopping this project in a negotiated way is lost. All honourable members will be aware that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote a couple of letters--

TALK.START.PARA: —Three.

—He wrote three letters to the Premier of Tasmania after the election and then proceeded to introduce certain regulations under the National Parks and Wildlife Act in an attempt to stop the dam. Now the Government is proceeding with this legislation. The reason it is proceeding with this legislation is that the advice it has received-I imagine it to be proper advice-is that it is unlikely to have its position upheld on the regulations. The regulations are most likely in excess of the power given under the National Parks and Wildlife Act. The Prime Minister wrote three letters. The Government has introduced these regulations and it has lost the opportunity to sit down in a calm and considered way, after the election, and in a non-confrontationist atmosphere in an attempt to negotiate an alternative approach, in an attempt to pursue another solution. I very much regret that because I think there is an enormous lost opportunity. In the post-election environment, the willingness-
—You can't be serious.

—Yes, I am very serious and it is the strongest view I hold. The real chance of stopping this dam with certainty would have been a negotiated solution . As a result of the legislative solution, the prospect that the Government has now of stopping the dam is at best 50-50. I say to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) that in my judgment, having put aside the opportunity to negotiate and being seen to negotiate, he has it on his head and the head of his colleagues if this dam is built.
—It will be called the Cohen dam.

—Perhaps I should suggest that to the honourable member's colleagues. In my judgment, the prospect of going before the High Court of Australia on the bases that are available, and losing, must be at least 50-50.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would behove me at least to take honourable members through the powers that the Government might be seeking to rely upon in this Bill. Mention has been made of section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution, the external affairs power. Under the external affairs power people are relying upon the judgment in the Koowarta case for an assumption that the Court will willingly extend that power into this situation. A number of reasons exist, and because of the federal clause in the agreement that has been negotiated, because of the unique circumstances in this case and because it is a very marked extension, I believe- and the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) highlighted this in a letter that he wrote to the newspapers before the election-that the extensions of the external affairs power, having regard to the great variety of possibilities that might exist in terms of treaty arrangements, will prompt the Court to put a fence around the external affairs power and limit it.

It has been suggested that section 51 (xxvi) might be able to be used. Some people call that the power to make laws for Aborigines, but it is not that. It is the power to make laws for people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws. I suggest that if that clause is looked at, bearing in mind the extent to which archeological relics are involved, it is very unlikely that it will be deemed to be a special law for people of any race. To suggest that relics of 20,000 years of age are making special laws for people of a race seems to me to be stretching the incidental nature of any extension of that power quite beyond that which is reasonable.

It has also been suggested that the trade and commerce power might be able to be used. But because of the qualification in section 100 of the Constitution, in my judgment it is most unlikely that the use of the trade and commerce power would be upheld. Honourable members would be aware that section 100 of the Constitution states:

The Commonwealth shall not, by any law or regulation of trade or commerce, abridge the right of a State or of the residents therein to the reasonable use of the waters of rivers for conservation or irrigation.

I think that particular qualification would certainly limit the extension by any court of the trade or commerce power to stop the building of this particular dam . Finally, it is suggested that the inherent nationhood power that was used to uphold the Australian Assistance Plan might well be properly extended in this case to enable intervention. Whilst I recognise that there is an inherent nationhood power I think that in these circumstances one is very much more likely to find the High Court building a fence around the nature of that power and the natural extension of it as well, because really what we are about when we extend these headings of power quite unnaturally is undermining the very federal nature of this Constitution.

I want it to be understood that I am not a States' righter; but I am not a centralist either. I think people have to understand that there is a different position, and that is of a federalist, a person who believes in the nature of our federal compact and what it is all about. We cannot deny the Constitution. It is there. It is a federal Constitution and I do not believe that the courts of this land will lightly put aside that document, the very fundamental nature of the federal compact, to allow these unnatural extensions of the four powers that the Government is purporting to extend in this statute.

I go back to the point. If we believe that this dam should not be built, as I do, then one would not, I suggest, want to rely upon an Act of parliament which so unnaturally extends some sections of the Constitution in the hope that one might win because, in my judgment, that is a very significant doubt and a risk that I would not be prepared to take until I had exhausted in every possible way every attempt to negotiate a solution. Clearly, also under the Constitution, and this Act has it in mind, there is provision for the acquisition of land or property. The Constitution clearly lays down that the acquisition of property must be on just terms. I understand that there is an argument that when one purports to say that a State cannot deal with its territory in the way in which it might ordinarily deal with it, one is, to all intents and purposes, acquiring its property, and that means that compensation on just terms will be required for any intervention. I suggest that when this matter gets into the courts the compensation that is likely to be payable will be a very significant amount of money.

Therefore I would say that it was incumbent upon the Government, having regard to those provisions dealing with compensation and to the doubts about the extent of its constitutional power, to negotiate realistically with the Tasmanians in an attempt to stop this dam proposal. Until those steps were taken, I do not believe this legislation was proper. I do not think it should have been introduced into the Parliament. I would even suggest at this late stage that it should not be proceeded with and that the Minister should endeavour to negotiate further for a solution. That is not to say that at the end of the day legislation of this sort is something that I might not have looked seriously at supporting. But I cannot support it at this time, and I want the Parliament to know that I cannot support it at this time. I think it is precipitate, and I have made that very clear. I do not think the Bill should be supported for that reason. The Minister should go back and attempt to negotiate realistically in a non-confrontationalist atmosphere and be prepared to pay compensation as the Constitution requires on just terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in this debate and to express a disappointment at the way in which the Labor Government has attempted to protect an area on the World Heritage List and a disappointment at the way in which our Tasmanian colleagues have failed to appreciate and understand the great significance of the area in the South West. Having said that, might I also say that I appreciate and understand the deep, heartfelt feelings of the Tasmanians. I also appreciate and understand the deep and heartfelt feelings of many other Australians about the significance of South West Tasmania. Two issues exist in this debate, one being the significance of our federal system and the other being how, within that federal system, we can protect not only State and national assets but also world assets. But the Bill that has been introduced here represents an attack on the very fabric of the federal system. It is one that does not address itself merely to the five properties listed on the World Heritage List. It would give to a Minister of the Commonwealth Government powers far in excess of those that relate only to properties that are, or might be, on the World Heritage List. It is a back door method designed to centralise power in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall a debate that took place between 1972 and 1975 when the same sorts of issues arose. At that time the Labor Government, under Mr Whitlam, moved swiftly to destroy the federal system. It did not succeed and the Hawke Labor Government will not succeed either. Labor's objective was then, as now, the ultimate establishment of a unitary, unicameral system of government with one Australian Parliament vested with plenary powers. As an Australian and a South Australian, I do not believe that a unitary system of government would be in the best interests of Australia. I believe that people want parliaments and local government that are closer to their day to day needs and which have responsibility to handle policy matters related to those needs. I also believe that a system of government that divides sovereignty, that divides legislative capacity as well as administrative responsibility, is one that prevents from arising the circumstance whereby all power is in the hands of one or a few and thus can be abused to attack the Australian democratic system of government.

Therefore, because this Bill is drafted so widely, because it will enable the Minister to do far more than simply protect the world heritage items referred to , I find myself unable to support it. However, I wish that the Government had been more sensitive to the concerns of Australians of all political persuasions and had directed this Bill to the central issue confronting us: How are we to protect Australian assets that have been identified as of world significance? This week the 1982 report of the Australian Heritage Commission was circulated. In the report the commissioners state:

The dominant issue, in a public sense, over the past year has been the proposal to dam the Franklin River in Tasmania. This river is listed in the Register of the National Estate and the area has been proposed, by the Australian Government , for the World Heritage List.
Of course, since the report was written, that area has been so listed. The commissioners continue:

There is no doubt in the mind of the Commission that this river and its surrounds constitutes a place which has ' . . . aesthetic, historic, scientific or social significance or other special value for future generations as well as for the present community'. The Commission is of the view that there are ' feasible and prudent' alternatives to the project and that these should be investigated.

I agree with both aspects of what I have just quoted. I agree as to the aesthetic, cultural and environmental significance of South West Tasmania. I also agree that there should be a full and proper investigation of the alternatives. When a body set up under legislation of this Parliament-one which has been in operation for a number of years and has established a high reputation for identifying places and properties of significance to all Australians and in some instances to the whole world-makes a report such as that from which I have quoted I believe that the Parliament should take special note of it.

My statement that I cannot support the legislation as it comes before us does not mean that I do not believe that we in this Parliament should not examine ways and means whereby items of the national estate should be protected. I was Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment when the South West Tasmania area was proposed for listing by the World Heritage Committee. At that time I said that the nominated area of Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks covered approximately 769,355 hectares and was one of the last remaining temperate areas in the world; that it contained the South West National Park, the Franklin-Lower Gordon Wild Rivers National Park and the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Claire National Park; and that the area had a wide and outstanding range of geological, landform and vegetation characteristics. All of those parks were declared under legislation of the Tasmanian Parliament.

I went on to say that in the nomination the site had been described as a large, primitive area with its land and waters and its native plant and animal communities substantially unmodified by humans and their works. I added that it was large enough to survive as wilderness and to maintain genetic diversity, despite influences from surrounding areas, and to permit the experience of solitude. That nomination went forward at the request of the Premier of Tasmania and was accepted by the World Heritage Committee. I believe that governments have a right to deal with other governments-from Premier to Prime Minister. Once they have so dealt and have requested action by another government, which takes action in circumstances which then subject it to a set of political pressures, the government and the Parliament that made the original request are estopped from denying the consequences that flow from that request.

That request went forward to the World Heritage Committee on the basis that a dam was to be built in the South West. The property was listed by that Committee which, as was its right, listed it with a commentary-not a qualification-that the Australian authorities should do whatever they could to protect the South West. That was addressed to the Commonwealth Government and to the State Government because between them they have legislative power to provide the necessary protection.

I support the amendment proposed by my colleague, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), insofar as it looks to the future. There is no doubt that, under the Commonwealth Constitution, this Parlaiment has power to act. Section 51, placitum (xxxviii) refers to-

The exercise within the Commonwealth, at the request or with the concurrence of the Parliaments of all the states directly concerned, of any power which can at the establishment of this Constitution be exercised only by the Parliament of the United Kingdom or by the Federal Council of Australasia.

That placitum of the Constitution would give power for legislation to be jointly implemented by a State parliament and the Commonwealth Parliament in order to protect an item on the World Heritage List. The problem with which we are confronted today is that there are already five items on that list. I believe that two are under the complete legislative control of the Commonwealth. I refer to the Great Barrier Reef and the Kakadu National Park-

TALK.START.PARA: —And Lord Howe Island.

—That would come under New South Wales, I believe. Two come under direct Commonwealth control and three under the control of States. The vexed problem is as to how a Commonwealth Parliament, having initiated action at the request of State Premiers, governments and parliaments-under informal arrangements, because this is the first time that we have had this experience of processing some of our great world treasures in this way, by having them listed on the World Heritage List-can then protect them in the future. I hope that, if this Parliament, as I would like it to do, passes the amendment proposed by my colleague, the honouraable member for Bradfield, the Parliament of New South Wales would immediately seek to consult with the present Commonwealth Government and devise matching legislation so that those two areas can be protected. We may well find that the only way in which the Commonwealth has the legislative capacity to protect a World Heritage item is in that way, in concert with the State in which the property is located.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, I think it is a great pity that this legislation is so wide and covers properties other than those on the World Heritage List. It will be a massive intrusion on State sovereign powers in a way which I think is beyond the capacity of this Parliament. Therefore, I am not disposed to vote for legislation, which I believe is beyond the legislative capacity of this Parliament in circumstances where the proposed legislation goes much further than I would want it to go if there were a capacity. I would have liked to see an amendment to this legislation to include, in addition to what my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield has proposed, a proposal in these terms: ' That the Commonwealth has, pursuant to a request by a State, submitted to the World Heritage Committee under article 11 of the Convention, that the property is suitable for inclusion in the World Heritage List and it has been so included before the commencement of this Act'. There is no doubt that the property was listed as a result of a request of the Tasmanian Government. That request was conveyed to the Commonwealth by the Premier of Tasmania at the time. It is irrelevant that that Premier was not Premier at some later date.

What we need to do in regard to this legislation is to recognise that there are two fundamental issues. The first relates to the question of the integrity of our federal system and the division of power and the right of people of States to determine their own future in areas that are of State legislative capacity. I will fight to defend that right. But, at the same time, I believe that there are circumstances where our great national assets need to be protected by a mechanism that entrenches that protection. Preferably, that entrenchment of protection should be as a result of the agreement between a State government and the Commonwealth Government, each passing legislation which reinforces the enactments of the other. If we did not do that we would find that some of our great national assets would be under threat at any time according to the whims of our politicians. I think there are assets that the majority of Australians will identify from time to time as being something that Australians want preserved for all time. That we have not had this proper consultation with Tasmania since the Hawke Government came to office is a tragedy, for it may well have been that by careful and sensible consultation some solution to this problem could have been achieved. But that it has not been achieved is no excuse to play constitutional brinkmanship; it is no excuse to threaten States in relation to the areas of their normal responsibility. The freedom and the security of the Australian democracy depend upon the strength of a co-operative federal system, not upon one such as we had between 1972 and 1975 which was described as a coercive federal system.

We need to recognise also that the present Labor Government has indicated that it will coerce States in other ways. I am reminded that prior to the election date the man who is now the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that he would withhold section 96 grants from a State that did not bow to his requests. He said he would withhold grants not in relation to the area in which there was a disputation between the Commonwealth and the State but generally, by blackmail, to force a State into doing what a coercive federal government required it to do . Yet, he sought election and claimed election on the basis of consensus. How can it be described as consensus if on the public record, a Prime Minister, during an election campaign, holds above every State the Damocles sword of a threat of withdrawal of every section 96 grant if that State fails to do what that centralist coercive Prime Minister wishes it to do?

The other interesting aspect that I believe should be drawn to the attention of the House in the closing stages of this debate on the second reading of this very bad Bill is that the Prime Minister's predecessor as Leader of the Australian Labor Party made it clear in correspondence that he believed that Tasmania should make decisions for itself as to what it did in relation to the South West. More importantly he went on that the more fundamental matters of concern are very much a State responsibility and, he said, outside the constitutional authority of the Commonwealth. Now, presumably, he made that statement on advice. If he made that statement on advice, one wonders why we have before us a Bill with no explanation as to the full justification of its constitutionality and no explanation as to why this Bill, instead of addressing the central issue that should be before this Parliament-that is, the protection of items on the World Heritage List-gives to a Commonwealth Government the right to intrude into a whole range of areas such as a centralist Commonwealth Goverment would like to have available to it. But I, as one who believes in co- operative federalism, who believes in the division of powers, who believes in the balance and distribution of responsibility that presently prevails in this Commonwealth, do not wish to see the Parliament pass such wide legislation.

I oppose the Bill. I would like to see mechanisms developed that would enable the protection of all Australian properties in the future listed on the World Heritage List, and where possible and where constitutional and in co-operation with the States, to achieve the same thing in relation to the five items already listed on the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is a tragic culmination of four or five years of unbelievable bungling, stubborness and politicking by both State and Federal politicians. It now appears that this issue will be resolved only by the High Court of Australia. It should never have reached this point. The opportunities to resolve this impasse have been many and varied. They have all been lost. The debate which originally started around the question of Tasmania's need for more energy and the value of preserving the South West Tasmanian wilderness area has been lost as Tasmania's Liberal Government and the Tasmanian representatives in this House rage against the rest of Australia about States' rights. I have been a member of this Parliament for nearly 14 years. If there is one thing that I have grown to despise more than anything else it is those politicians who use this forum as a means of whipping up the people they purport to represent into a frenzy of rage against Canberra or the rest of Australia. It is cheap, populist regionalism and is the grubbiest form of politics available to man.

SPEECH.PARA: I bow to no one in my concern for the electorate I represent, the Central Coast electorate of Robertson. But before anything else I am an Australian; I am not a Gosfordian or a New South Welshman but an Australian. I believe that the overwhelming majority of members of this Parliament feel the same. Unfortunately , the majority of the Tasmanian members of parliament know how easy it is to play regional politics, to inflame the people and play on their prejudices and feeling of isolation. The Tasmanian members of parliament had the opportunity to do one of two things. They could have taken a courageous position and called for a full disclosure of the facts by the Hydro-Electric Commission. They could have called for a public inquiry similar to those carried out under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Two such national public inquiries were called by the Whitlam Government on Fraser Island and the Ranger uranium project . That was the only way in which this nation could have been given the opportunity to hear all of the facts about hydro-electricity and Tasmania's future power needs. That is the only way in which it could have been judged impartially. The other option was to do nothing, say nothing for years and let the Hydro-Electric Commission and the Tasmanian Government have all the running on the issue.

Let us not forget that all of the Tasmanian members of parliament with one exception-the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr)-refused to commit themselves for a long time, preferring to wait and see which way public opinion in Tasmania was going, without trying to inflame it. They sat on their hands waiting to see which way they should jump. When they saw the pro-dam argument was winning they jumped on the bandwagon. I have no doubt that the Tasmanian people favour building the dam-no doubt at all. We do not question that the majority opinion in Tasmania is in favour of the dam, probably by a ratio of 6:4 . But let us not forget that there is a very sizable minority, probably 30 per cent to 40 per cent of Tasmanians, who are just as strongly opposed to the dam, and they too are Tasmanians.

As the debate gathered momentum it was clear that it would be a courageous politician who took a contrary point of view. The Tasmanian members of parliament, except for the honourable member for Wilmot, could have played a real role and called for a genuine open inquiry. They chose the coward's way out . They tested the wind and they went with the mob.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. I would like the Minister to withdraw the remark 'cowardly'.
—It is true.
—It is not true. He knows it is not true.

—Order! The honourable member for Franklin has made his point. He will remain silent. I would require the Minister to be a little more selective in his words. I will not require a withdrawal because I do not see the word as being unparliamentary in the context of the debate.

—I take a point of order. You said, sir, with the greatest of respect, that the word was not unparliamentary. I take offence to that word being used with particular reference to me and my colleagues who are not here. I ask for that word to be withdrawn.
—Order! The honourable member has quite clearly-
—No one calls me a coward twice.

—Order! The honourable member has clearly expressed his view. The Chair in its comments to the Minister conveyed its displeasure, if you like, at its use but did not feel required to insist on a withdrawal. However, I am sure that the Minister would be responsive to the honourable member for Franklin 's distress and withdraw the word.

—I was referring in the broad to Tasmanian members of parliament. If the honourable member for Franklin considers that the word is personally offensive, I will withdraw it. The tragedy that I referred to earlier is that national debate is now impossible. People within Tasmania in particular are becoming so entrenched in their views, pro or anti, that even to raise the subject is to run the risk of getting a punch in the nose.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to go back to 1980, when as a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation I visited Tasmania-one of the many visits I have made to Tasmania-to carry out an inquiry into a proposal to dam the Franklin River. We met with the Hydro-Electric Commission in Hobart and discussed the proposal. After an hour or so it became patently clear to me that the HEC was primarily interested in how to find work for the 1,000-odd workers who could be put out of work if the dam did not proceed. When I put this question to officers of the HEC, they replied: 'That certainly is a major consideration'. In my view, it was the only consideration, with the possible exception of their own jobs-no dams, no engineers; no dams, no growth, at least for the HEC. I then asked the question: 'What will the dam workers do in 10 years when the dam is finished?' They said, 'We will worry about that in 10 years time'. Every single inquiry outside Tasmania by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation and the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania has given the thumbs down to the project-and remember that both of these committees were not controlled by the Australian Labor Party and its members. The Fraser Government instructed its departments to inquire into both the economic and environmental aspects of the project. All opposed it.

Let us not forget that the Fraser Government opposed the building of the dam, and it is obvious in this debate that there are many Liberal and National Party members who still do. There is one major difference, and I take up the comments made by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). The one major difference on this issue between the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government is that we believe that the South West is so important to the people of Australia and the rest of the world that we are prepared to take every legal measure at our disposal to stop the dam. The Fraser Government made the right noises. It even made the right offers. But when those offers were stubbornly rejected for purely political reasons it went to water, if honourable members will excuse the pun.

Let us take up the question of offers. We are told that this is a matter of power and jobs and Tasmania's future prosperity. Without going into all the facts about Tasmania's declining industrial activities so superbly argued by my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), I would like to remind the House of the unbelievably generous offers that both the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government have made to Tasmanian Premier, Mr Gray. I refer first to Mr Fraser's offer. The offer by the Fraser Government on 9 January this year was a grant to cover the full capital cost of a modern environmentally clean coal fired power station in Tasmania to generate an amount of electricity equivalent to that which would be generated as a result of damming the Gordon below Franklin. The Commonwealth also guaranteed to provide on an annual basis a share of the cost of coal for the life of the power station , if necessary to reduce the cost of thermal power to that of hydro-power. The $ 500m offer comprised an estimated $250m capital cost and $212m over the life of the power station for coal.
Now, look at the offers of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In his letter to Premier Gray on 30 March the Prime Minister wrote:

We have stated repeatedly we will assist in developing alternatives which guarantee your energy supplies to cover both the present and future needs. We are not opposed to the development of hydro-electricity to meet Tasmania's future energy needs.
We are opposed to the Gordon below Franklin Dam.
We have made it clear we will assist those directly affected by stopping work on the dam and in the transfer of employment from that site to other projects.
We are committed to achieving equivalent employment opportunities for those working on the current project.
Further, we will assist in developing a long term economic package for the benefit of all Tasmanians.
We acknowledge and accept our responsibility to do all that is possible for those currently unemployed within your State.
Finally we have many times stated our commitment to healing the divisions in this society. This issue clearly divides Tasmania.

Surely anyone who claims to have a basic understanding of the English language would realise that these are unbelievably generous offers. We have said in no uncertain terms that we recognise Tasmania's fears and that if the Australian people want to save the Franklin River and the South West they, the Australian people, must be prepared to pay for it. At no stage have we suggested that the Australian people should demand that Tasmanians should be the only ones to pay for our wish to preserve the South West. We have said: 'You save it, we will pay for it'. Premier Gray was virtually given a blank cheque.

Tasmanians could have had the best of both worlds. They could have had the South West preserved and all the benefits that would flow from that. There was an unequivocal guarantee that their future power needs would be met and an assurance that every person's job was safe. What could be more generous? What more do they want? Those 1,000-plus workers who were not going to be working on the dam would have been employed on a whole range of projects, including other hydro projects, major roads, environmental improvement and tourist attractions. What sort of stubborness, what sort of politicking, what sort of madness rejected this offer?

Finally it came down to the HEC, backed by the politicians in this House, whipping up a fury amongst their constituents that no one on that other island was going to tell them what to do. States rights, not energy requirements and environment protection, became the issue.

During this debate one of the silliest comments emanating from some of the Tasmanian members was that members on this side hate Tasmania. Nothing could be further from the truth. On the contrary, it is because we love Tasmania that we do not want to see this project proceed. I have visited Tasmania on many occasions, including camping in the upper reaches of the Franklin River and canoeing some 16 kilometres down that river. I know of no other place in Australia, with the possible exception of North Queensland and the Northern Territory, that has such enormous tourist potential. I speak with some knowledge of the subject because during the thirteen and a half years I have been a member of this House I have devoted a large part of my time to the tourist industry. I was instrumental in convincing Mr Malcolm Fraser to set up a select committee on tourism and for three years I was shadow Minister for tourism, sport and environment. If a fraction of the money-I repeat, a fraction of the money-now being proposed for the Gordon below Franklin Dam were to be expended on tourist infrastructure, Tasmania would become a tourist El Dorado. At the time the previous Tasmanian Government was hoping to spend $453m-at 1982 prices-on the dam, the Labor Government was planning to spend $70,000 on tourist infrastructure. Tasmania's great charm, alongside its natural beauty, is that it has not had the massive industrial development, the massive population growth and urban restructuring that all of Australia's other cities have had. There has not been the pressure to pull down the wonderful old colonial buildings in Hobart, Launceston, Richmond, New Norfolk and other areas of Tasmania. It is a traveller's paradise. All it needs is the investment in tourism to ensure its economic prosperity. Time does not permit me to go into great detail but I refer honourable members to the new tourist village now being constructed at the Uluru National Park at Ayers Rock. It is an excellent model for the future development of tourism in Tasmania.

I want to deal very briefly with the question of States' rights and the Constitution. The main line taken by the Opposition, commencing with the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), is that the Bill is a devious plot to subvert the Constitution and establish central control in Canberra. If indeed this is a view held by the Austraian Financial Review and others, one can blame only Mr Gray and the honourable members opposite from Tasmania. Their refusal to negotiate has led this Government, as a last resort, to use its full powers. There is no such thing as States' rights; only people have rights. States have powers. This Bill is careful to respect the powers of the States. It does not and cannot take from the States those powers that exclusively belong to them.

I draw the attention of honourable members to clause 6 (2) of the Bill and the careful way that it is drafted so that the Governor-General in making a proclamation under the section, may make a proclamation only in relation to an identified property that is in a State when one of a number of conditions which attract the Commonwealth powers apply to the property. I also draw honourable members' attention to clauses 7 and 8. These clauses allow the Governor-General to make proclamations which we based on the Commonwealth foreign corporations and trading corporations powers and its powers to make special laws in respect of the peoples of any race respectively. The Commonwealth has responsibility to implement the provisions of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage and must implement them as required by the Convention. If the States generally were so worried about this legislation why have New South Wales and Victoria intervened in the case in the High Court of Australia to support the Commonwealth? I am sure that if they were truly concerned about their rights they would not have let political affiliations influence their action. Western Australia, a State not well known for its centralist views, will not intervene but has said that the Commonwealth is on sound legal grounds in taking the action that it has taken and that Western Australia does not agree with those who say a move like this constitutes the end of all States' rights. Western Australia has said that it does not follow that success by the Commonwealth in the present High Court action will mean the end of all States' rights, as is being claimed by some people.

The Bill is the embodiment of this Government's commitment to protect South West Tasmania, for which we have a mandate from the overwhelming majority of Australian people. The Bill is based only on the rights and powers that the Constitution grants to the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth cannot go beyond these powers and does not attempt to in this Bill. We are not seeking to change the Constitution, as the Opposition suggests. I note that the honourable member for Bradfield has suggested that we should hold a referendum. Apart from the practicality in terms of time lost while the HEC assaults the world heritage area, this does leave us with an interesting option to consider if necessary.

The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) stated that 27 per cent of Tasmania is either national park or conservation area. This sounds very commendable until one examines the range of activities the Gray Government has allowed in these areas. For example, logging and mining exploration are permitted in the conservation areas. When the HEC wanted to flood parts of the Franklin-lower Gordon Wild Rivers National Park and the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park, the Gray Government meekly revoked sections of the national parks so that the HEC could get its own way. This makes a mockery of the Liberal Party election promise to preserve our heritage.

The honourable member for Braddon also said that the Arthur River is Tasmania's great wild river. It is interesting to note that the ubiquitous HEC has two dams planned for the Arthur River. He said that 88 kilometres of the Franklin River will not be flooded by the Gordon below Franklin Dam. What he conveniently forgot to mention was that under the HECs proposed integrated scheme with a further dam upstream, 40 of these 88 kilometres would be flooded. The HEC has never deviated from its intent to construct the full integrated scheme and the Gordon below Franklin Dam is only the first cab off the rank in the South West.

I refer again to the speech of the honourable member for Bradfield. He referred to what one might call the 'Colonel Gaddafi syndrome'-a complaint new to medical science. It broke out in Adelaide last week, when Premier Gray became the first patient. It has now unfortunately spread to the mainland, as was seen in the House last night. The syndrome is evidenced where the patient demonstrates irrational fear that this country is in some way selling out to overseas interests by signing international conventions. The Opposition claims that Australia has signed 16,039 bilateral and international agreements, most of which would no doubt have been concluded when the current Opposition was in Government. The syndrome has, thank goodness, not spread to other countries with democratic federal systems that have signed the World Heritage Convention. Seventy-two countries in the world have signed the Convention, including the United States of America, Canada, West Germany and of course Libya. It is ludicrous to suggest that we are being taken over by foreign interests such as Colonel Gaddafi through our ratification of the Convention-and I am not one of his great admirers. Our powers and rights as a nation are in no way subject to the control of overseas powers. If honourable members use this as an example Australia would never sign any international agreements.

Finally I would like to table this article by Kenneth Davidson in the Age this morning. I do not agree with everything in the article but there are some excellent points that need to be made, particularly those about total Commonwealth net payments to or for the States per head of population in 1982-83 .

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2, line 10, after 'property' insert ', land or interest in land'.
(2) Clause 3, page 2, lines 16 and 17, omit sub-paragraph 2 (a) (ii).

The Opposition has moved this fairly simple but nevertheless significant amendment to ensure that the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill covers all possible interests by individuals, corporations or States in land which may be the subject of proclamation under this Act. For example, in many situations one can have a lease over land which may ultimately be the subject of a proclamation. Other situations could involve other legal interests such as joint tenancy. As the Bill stands at the moment there does not appear to be adequate protection for the rights of individuals, corporations or States whose land could be subject to proclamation under the Act. The second amendment is to delete clause 3 (2) (a) (ii); namely, the words 'has been declared by the regulations to form part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage . . .'. We doubt whether, within that context, we should also add questions of cultural heritage or natural heritage which are not necessarily involved in any way with registration under the world heritage properties conservation procedures. If the Government believes that there is a need for federal jurisdiction or for federal legislation covering the question of cultural heritage or natural heritage, by all means it has the power to introduce the appropriate legislation into this House. We simply emphasise the point that we do not feel that this Bill, at this time, is the appropriate vehicle for covering questions beyond and above the question of world heritage properties conservation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.
