SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment which the Opposition proposes to clause 6 is of a fundamental nature and goes to the very heart of this legislation. It is regrettable that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen), since he would not accept the very small amendment to clause 2, quite clearly will not support in any sense our amendments to clause 6 . Nevertheless, I hope that, at some future date, if the High Court of Australia judges the Government's position to be correct-there is certain doubt about that -he will reconsider the contents of our recommendations in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is very important to note that the essence of clause 6 sub-clause (2 ) and the subsequent sub-paragraphs going down to (e) are fundamentally directed at introducing into this legislation the external affairs power as the basis for the Commonwealth's action in the High Court against the State of Tasmania. It is worth emphasising that, under section 51 of the Commonwealth Constitution, the Commonwealth Parliament does have the power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to external affairs. It may seem a very simple phrase but in fact it is, has been in the past and no doubt will be in the future the subject of considerable legal debate with considerable political tones.

As I stated on behalf of the Opposition yesterday, we believe there should be most definite limitations on the capacity of the external affairs power because, as the Minister so rightly said-I re-emphasise his words-governments do not have rights; individuals have rights. The whole principle of the constitutional system, as we understand it to be, is that through the system of the States there is a better possibility of the majority of people within a State having a greater capacity to influence the affairs of the nation through the State than by simply working in a more centralised system of administration.

I think it is worthwhile noting that our views are shared not only by members on the Opposition side of the Parliament but also by people of some courage on the side of the Government. I draw the attention of the Minister to a letter to the editor of the Australian which appeared in that newspaper on 28 January 1983 . The letter stated:

Lawyers are arguing whether the High Court would grant the Commonwealth Government power to intervene and prevent the construction of the Tasmanian dam under the external affairs power of the Constitution.
May I, as one who tends to oppose increased government powers of most kinds, caution those Labor supporters who may approve of the extension of such power in this case.

What would prevent an Australian government signing a treaty with South Africa dealing with 'subversion?' Could an Act endorsing such a treaty then give an Australian government unlimited powers, denied to it by the High Court (and a referendum) in the early 1950s?

Before endorsing the use of the external affairs power to circumvent the Constitution let us remember that an Australian government could find a number of foreign governments prepared to sign all kinds of treaties conferring unpleasant powers on our government.

The letter was signed by Labor member for Prospect in New South Wales, Dr Klugman. He is one of the few people in the Australian Labor Party who on other occasions over the years have demonstrated that they are not only masters of their own destiny but also men of considerable courage. Nevertheless, the principle he has enunciated is one which is well worth looking at.

I made this observation yesterday. I am not, as the Minister suggested, trying to take up the Gaddafi syndrome. I did not even mention the question of Gaddafi, the State of Libya or anything related to it. I simply made the point that there is the risk, when one is dealing with external affairs, to work on the principle which has been used by constitutional commentators in the past, that is, the concept of international concern. The words 'international concern' also appear prominently in the sub-paragraphs of clause 6 which we recommend to the Committee should be deleted from the Bill. Incidentally, the question which came up in the Koowarta case in relation to human rights would fit that description of international concern. If it could be demonstrated that a convention had been signed by the whole world for example-that is, some 250-odd states which belong to the United Nations-in which a series of principles was agreed I would find some difficulty in seeing how the Government could relate that to the question of world heritage. At this stage at least the number of states which have signed the World Heritage Convention could not, by any stretch of the imagination, be regarded as an accurate indication of world concern in the widest sense. It is for that reason, among others, that we have suggested to the Committee that this sub-clause be removed from the Bill. It was put there for the very simple reason , as I said in my speech at the second reading stage, to create in the mind of the High Court the maximum number of headings of power by which it will be expected to make a determination as to whether the Commonwealth Government does have the power to involve itself in the questions which we believe are essentially the domestic responsibility of Tasmania.

As we are well aware, the High Court will soon be making a legal interpretation of the Constitution in respect of the application of the World Heritage Convention in Australia, but it should not be the Court's role to determine the future of Australia's federal system. There is no way in which we can avoid the fact that that role rests ultimately with the people of Australia and, through them, their elected representatives who take their place in this chamber. This legislation, like the regulations under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, ultimately will probably be taken to the High Court by the Queensland and Tasmanian governments. But it is important to remember that laws are made on behalf of people and that it is the role of the High Court only to interpret those laws and not to make them. Therefore, there is a pressing need for definitions of what constitutes an 'external affair' and for clarification of the extent to which the Commonwealth can enact legislation pursuant to the external affairs power.
The Chief Justice has offered some helpful criteria in this respect in the following terms:
A law which regulates transactions between Australia and other countries or between residents of Australia and residents of other countries would be a law with respect to external affairs.
I am sure that no one in this chamber would dispute that interpretation. Regarding the Koowarta case, he further noted:

If section 51 empowers the Parliament to legislate to give effect to every international agreement which the Executive may choose to make the Commonwealth would be able to acquire unlimited legislative power. The distribution of power made by the Constitution could in time be completely obliterated. There would be no field of power which the Commonwealth could not invade and the Federal balance achieved by the Constitution could be entirely destroyed.

The important thing which I say to members of the Government is simply this: Those were not the words of some politician who happened to be gracing the Opposition side in the Parliament or some megalomaniac, as some people on the Government side have suggested some of my colleagues might be; those are the words of one of the most highly respected lawyers in this land who has been given the function of the senior judge of the High Court of Australia. He made that judgment in the Koowarta case which has been quoted by many people on the Government side as the basis for claiming that the Commonwealth may have power in terms of the Tasmanian dams issue.

As I said in my speech yesterday, and as I reiterate today, these questions now rest with the High Court. We must not hide ourselves from the ultimate responsibility that the law is not made by justices of the High Court. The law is made by politicians and by the people through the system of referenda which has stood us pretty well since 1901. It is for these reasons, therefore, that we ask the Committee not to support the inclusion of the external affairs head of power as part of this legislation, knowing full well, of course, that the Government will naturally oppose our recommendations.

I refer briefly to the second proposal. We believe there is a very strong case for including in law the provision that, in the future when States are prepared to make suggestions to the Commonwealth for the inclusion of items on the World Heritage List, those recommendations must be supported by the State parliaments and also by the Federal Parliament. My objective would be that over a period, because of the exclusive nature of the rare cases which go on the World Heritage List, each of them deserves a piece of legislation in its own right which sets down the provisions for State responsibility and the provisions for Commonwealth responsibility which would then be supported by both parliaments so we would obviate for all time the difficult situation which we have faced in recent months in terms of the Tasmanian issue. Therefore, I move:
(3) Clause 6, pages 2 and 3, omit sub-clause (2), substitute the following sub- clause:

'(2) A proclamation may also be made under sub-section (3) in relation to identified property that is in a State if the property, after the commencement of this Act, has been included in the World Heritage List by the World Heritage Committee, pursuant to article 11 of the Convention and the Parliament of the State and the Commonwealth have consented to that inclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself to the points made by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). He and his colleagues have argued consistently that what they are on about is federalism and the division of power, but when it comes to recognising the power of human beings or of humanity at large, or of the international community, suddenly they want to maintain their power centralised here in Canberra. When we want to pass a law which is to specify and spell out our commitment to the international community and to humanity at large, not to a particular government or State, the objection raised by the honourable member is that we are trying to legislate by an action of the court when it should be determined by the elected representatives of the people.

SPEECH.PARA: That seems to be a very convoluted argument. I should have thought the other way round: If we do not have this legislation, the courts of this land will be in a position of having to determine what the external affairs power is. If the elected representatives of the people want to spell out what they see as the external affairs power, that is doing exactly what the honourable member has been asking for-that elected representatives determine what is the wish of the people of Australia with regard to the external affairs power, and not what the courts wish it to be.

The issue of divided sovereignty as between a Federal and a State parliament is not one that is to be determined on tradition or on the intent of the framers of the Constitution, or indeed on the Constitution itself. If one is looking at the rights of individuals, one should be looking at them in the light of the moral principles behind those documents. We have advanced a little since 1901 when we adopted our Australian Constitution, and we have declared ourselves peoples of the United Nations. We have declared ourselves bound by international law in international matters. It was the late Dr Evatt and the late Right Honourable Frank Forde, whose memory we recognised this week, who were instrumental in drawing up that very document, the charter of the United Nations, which started with those words 'We the peoples of the United Nations'. If that document is to have any meaning or relevance at all, it means that we have acknowledged that there are rights and issues that are more important than national ones; that national, parochial and local issues and sovereignties must give way to higher and wider concerns. That is where Tasmania has fallen down, and it is where this Government would fall down if it limited its concern to what Australians only want and not to what the world at large wants.

I am not suggesting that Colonel Gaddafi is any wiser than Bob Hawke or Malcolm Fraser. I am not suggesting that South Africa's apartheid is the sort of thing that we ought to embrace in an international convention. What I am suggesting is that there is usually more wisdom in larger numbers in deciding what is best for humanity and for the larger group than in looking at the local and parochial interests. After all, the very principle of democracy is that there is some wisdom in numbers. Obviously there is also unwisdom. Populism is not democracy. Unless one has informed general discussion, consensus and acceptance developing in a community, something wider than just Tasmania and just Australia, one is not acting in the interests of humanity. The World Heritage listing is a recognition, not only by Gaddafi but by Australia and by the representatives of many countries with which we like to be associated in many international issues, that there is something more important than a national interest in a World Heritage listing. The Government of Tasmania itself has recognised this in applying for the South West to be listed an an international heritage, a world heritage-not a Tasmanian heritage, not an Australian heritage. The Government of Australia and the Government of Tasmania have responsibilities in these matters; they do not have rights.

Ideally, of course, all matters of international dispute ought to be decided at an international level. We ought not to have a debating club such as the League of Nations or the United Nations appealing for a gentlemen's agreement. We ought to be able to enforce international law on international criminals. We ought to have a means of arbitration and of policing, rather than the appeals which fall so often on deaf ears in an organisation such as the United Nations Security Council, in which one atomic power can torpedo any decision on security and can prevent any concerted action at all to enforce international law. We ought to have the rule of law among nations as within them. I have spoken to ambassadors from the United States, the Soviet Union and all sorts of colours in between. They all agree-yes, a great ideal. 'It will not come in our time', some of them say, 'but maybe in 2000 years', or they say: 'It will come in our time. We agree with it, but of course, the other side will not'. That is a counsel of despair and defeat which will lead us over the brink of atomic destruction if we follow it. We must start recognising that the body of international law ought to take precedence in international matters. To give Federal law precedence over State law is not a new concept of a Labor government. It is a centralist obsession. It is written into the Constitution. When those honourable members opposite who criticise the actions of this Government in adopting the power given to it under that Constitution and taking it to the High Court to determine that that power is given accuse us of torpedoing that Constitution, in effect they are saying that they do not believe the Constitution and they do not believe that powers were ceded to the Federal Government. If this is an international matter, then it is an external affair.

The determining factor in whether a centralised law or a decentralised law is a better one or a more democratic one is not whether it comes from a left wing or a right wing source, or whether it is from a dictator or from a democratically minded person; the determining factor is: What is best for human rights? There are some matters where the central government can best ensure human rights. There are other matters in which local government or state government can best ensure human rights.

There is a very strong body of opinion in the Labor movement that we would be best served by two levels of government in our federal system: A national government; and regional governments which would assume many of the functions of the States and many of the functions of local government. There is much opposition to that, from local government authorities which want to maintain their bailiwick and from State governments. But the argument is not that because States have existed, because some politicians in London a century ago drew lines on a map and declared what would be State boundaries, that is in some way a sacrosanct right. The argument is: What is the best distribution of powers between the central and the local or regional level to serve human rights? The human rights concerned in the case of the Franklin are international rights. They are not Tasmanian or South West rights; they are not Hydro-Electric Commission rights; and they are not Australian rights. They are international. That is what is to be made clear by the passing of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a very interesting contribution from the honourable member for Capricornia (Dr Everingham). As I understood his argument, he seemed to be suggesting that we should have a world government.
—A federal government; federalised not centralised.

—There is probably some consistency in our views then. But as I understood him, he was suggesting that the more people involved in a decision, the more valuable or appropriate is that decision. He seemed to be suggesting that the world should be involved in these decisions. It seems therefore-if he is honest and his argument is logical-that he should be looking to some international body to take total control over South West Tasmania. It is the ultimate sell-out argument.
—I am not totally committed to anything; I am dividing power.
—It seems to me, though, that the argument that the issue should be determined by the world community, because it is an international property, is the ultimate sell-out argument.
—A world heritage.

—If it is a world heritage, as the honourable member for Capricornia suggests, Tasmania has no rights, therefore Australia has no rights. But the kind of view that he puts is supported by some of the words in clause 6. I find the words in clause 6 (2) (d) offensive. It refers to when a proclamation can be made. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: the protection or conservation of the property by Australia is a matter of international concern (whether or not it is also a matter of domestic concern), . . .

The key words are those in parentheses. It seems to me that this is a clause which suggests that the international view is more significant than even the national view, let alone the view of ordinary Tasmanian people. It is suggesting that if someone like Dr Bellamy has a particular concern about this issue it does not matter what Australians think; it certainly does not matter what Tasmanians think. If Dr Bellamy is concerned, the Governor-General should act by proclaiming the area once it has been identified as an appropriate property within a State. In the second reading speech the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) praised Dr Bellamy. I do not recall his exact words, but he referred to him as a well known international figure in the scientific community and as an eminent botanist. He said that here was a man who expressed concern on behalf of the international community. But as my colleague the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) indicated earlier-in what I believe was an excellent speech and one that strongly defended the rights of his constituents, the people who elected him to this place-Dr Bellamy is the person who announced in Britain before he even came to Australia that he intended to come here and go to gaol and spend his fiftieth birthday in the clink in Tasmania. After his arrival he did that very thing; he made sure that he was arrested. The same man announced quite publicly that he was a publicist, that he was a television star in England.

TALK.START.PARA: —A self-publicist.

—A self-publicist, as the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) mentions. That was the purpose for which he came here. He brought a television team with him to take films of what he did in Tasmania. In relation to this clause it is worth while recalling that Dr Bellamy went up the Gordon River and sat in his aluminium dinghy and said on television: 'Look at this beautiful forest and this beautiful timberland in its natural pristine glory'. It so happens that that beautiful bushland which he said was to be damaged and destroyed by the damming of the Gordon and Franklin rivers would not be at all affected by the flooding. It was downstream on the Gordon towards Macquarie Harbour from where the dam site is. Yet he said that this beautiful bushland had not been touched for 40,000 years. Logging has been going on since the early 1880s in that bushland he was pointing to. The convicts of Sarah Island and Macquarie Harbour were involved as teams in taking all the good huon pine from that area from the early 1800s. I am sure that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), the well known quiz kid--
—King.

—King, I am sorry. I am sure that he could confirm that particular fact . Dr Bellamy also said that he had been through the forest in that area and had detected 40 new species of insects. This is absolute nonsense. He said that these were previously unknown to science. This really was a joke because teams of botanists and scientists have worked in that area. The Commonwealth Government financed various studies in the South West.
—I thought it was fauna generally.

—No, that is not right. One of the points made by a speaker earlier concerned the Tasmanian devil. He seemed to suggest that this was the last habitat of the Tasmanian devil, an endangered species. We have Tasmanian devils throughout Tasmania. This indicates--
—Order! I think the honourable member might try just a little harder to relate his remarks to the clause under consideration.

—I thank you, Mr Chairman, for bringing me back to the point. The main point I wanted to make was that I find these words an insult to the Australian community, in particular to the Tasmanian community. We have a Bill brought before our national Parliament which says, in effect: 'We do not give a damn about what Australians think; we are only concerned about people like Dr Bellamy who live in other parts of the world. If they are concerned, let us have a proclamation; let us make sure that we take over this particular part of the State and not give a damn for the people who live in that State'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take only a couple of minutes. I have no strong views on the Gordon below Franklin Dam one way or the other, but I would like to sound a warning on two issues. I feel very strongly on both of them. One is the making of a rod for our own backs by giving in to what I call single- issue fanatics. When I think of single-issue fanatics, I am not favourably impressed by the honourable for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). Single-issue fanatics to me include not only people from the Tasmanian Wilderness Society, but also the Right to Life crowd, the Festival of Light, the Defence of Government Schools, the Campaign against Nuclear Power and all the other single-issue groups which try to stand over us as politicians. In the long run, it is very bad for us if we cave in to those sorts of groups. I think that at least some of us have caved in. We can win one election on issues promoted by such groups and get beaten in two or three other elections on the same sorts of issues.

SPEECH.PARA: My second point is that I am basically a civil libertarian-or I hope I am-and I consider human beings more important than trees, flowers or vistas. Therefore, I again emphasise the point that I made in a letter which I understand somebody quoted from, either in toto or in part, earlier today. The letter I sent on 26 January refers to the external affairs power of the Constitution. In part, it reads;

May I, as one who tends to oppose increased government powers of most kinds, caution those Labor supporters who may approve of the extension of such power in this case. What would prevent an Australian government signing a treaty with South Africa dealing with 'subversion'? Could an Act endorsing such a treaty then give an Australian Government unlimited powers denied to it by the High Court and the referendum in the early 1950s. That referendum dealt with the Suppression of Communism Act. The letter continues: Before endorsing the use of the external affairs power to circumvent the Constitution, let us remember that an Australian Government could find a number of foreign governments prepared to sign all kinds of treaties conferring very unpleasant powers on our Government.

I emphasise that there can be lot of reasons for preventing the building of that dam-economic reasons, archaeological reasons, Aboriginal affairs powers-all kinds of reasons. But we open a Pandora's box once we say that a government can do something just because it has signed a treaty with one or a number of foreign governments. We give a government, which has a majority to endorse that treaty, absolute power on issues in relation to which I hope none of us-certainly none of us on this side of the House-would be prepared to give power to a government. On the questions of what one can read, what is subversion and the unlimited use of powers, at some stage I would like to hear people who defend the use of such powers justify the power in this case and show me how the use of that power would in some way be limited compared with the use of power if we signed a treaty with, say, South Africa or any other country to deal with subversion. I note that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) is at the table. He has some views on this and has some legal training. I hope he will reassure me on this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 6, as I think we would all agree, is the crux of this legislation. It contains the rules; the rest of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill tends to refer to that clause. When we have finished with this clause, we will certainly have finished with the principal part of the Bill. Of course, there have been plenty of honourable members who have said here today that they are interested in the rights of the individual and the rights of people. When we set out to protect those rights it seems amazing that we must have all these clauses which in truth seem to have nothing whatsoever to do with the price of fish. The honourable member for Capricornia ( Dr Everingham) talked about how governments make decisions and the types of government we should have. Of course, this Bill, as has just been said, is very much about those relative powers.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had a long period-some 16 years-in local government. I still hold to the view that that form of government is better able to recognise the day to day will of people than any other, and for a very simple reason. I had an electorate of 160 voters and I was able to chat with them on fairly frequent occasions. But naturally, on the other hand, I did not see them make the sorts of decisions that are being made today. There has been a lot of talk about the will of the people and what the people want. There is one other certainty. We have no idea whatsoever of the numbers in favour of this issue or this Bill. We can claim mandates from elections and yet we are all politicians. We all know that only a percentage of the populace swings from major party to major party and that percentage does not swing on the same issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not want to be unreasonable but will the honourable gentleman try just a little harder to relate his remarks to clause 6 of the Bill ?

—I believe that these clauses, and in particular our amendment, try to bring this Bill back to a situation where there is a chain of decisions all related to the rights of individual Australians, starting off with a voter, a State government and then the Federal Government. That is my understanding of our amendment and my understanding of why we want the other clauses removed that give those sorts of powers to, for instance, the lady who was out here recently running around with a photograph, which she parades around America, of a kangaroo that has been attacked by dogs. I see her as the type of lobbyist provided for in clause 6 (2) (d). It is all right for the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) to say that he has absolutely no intention of using sub-clause (d) in that fashion. The other certainty is that he will not be a member of this Parliament for the life of this Bill. Once it is enacted and entrenched, its provisions could apply for 100 years. In truth, this is what we are talking about. I think the previous speaker made that point.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about putting something into legislation and taking a punt on how other people will interpret it or use it. I included in an earlier speech which is recorded in Hansard the story that the politicians of the day told the Australian public when they sought the Aboriginal power. At no time was there a voter in Australia who thought that that power would be found to be used in this Bill in such a fashion. That is an absolute fact. I say to every one present that we can have a Bill to achieve what the Government wants, with one exception . The Government has to count the numbers. It has to find out, firstly, what at least the Tasmanian people want. We can do this either through their State Parliament or from the people themselves. I would prefer some form of referendum . That would be a great start because of the Tasmanian's great knowledge of this situation. Secondly, we need to know what the Australian people think of this type of legislation, with or without the dam thrown in. To me that is essential in an issue as important as this.

The great thing about our Constitution is the simplicity of its words. In fact I looked at an amendment yesterday and I am horrified by it because it will be a lawyer's dream. It takes five pages to say what is presently said in a few lines . I favour the Constitution as it was written originally. But all of these clauses are in fact unnecessary, except one, and I honestly believe that the general intention of a government that wants to bring Australians together could be met by the type of amendment that we have proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the Tasmanians is asleep.
—Cut it out; I am not even trying to get the honourable member angry. He should just listen. If one looks at the other sub-clauses, for instance sub- clause (b), it states:

SPEECH.PARA: the protection or conservation of the property by Australia is a matter of international obligation, whether by reason of the Convention or otherwise;
My side note there is: 'Who decides?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth.
—But that is not stated in sub-clause (b). What about sub-clause (c) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: the protection of conservation of the property by Australia is necessary or desirable for the purpose of giving effect to a treaty (including the Convention ) or for the purpose of obtaining for Australia any advantage or benefit under a treaty (including the Convention)

There was some talk this morning about a trade-off of coal sales for a pipeline or something. Is that the purpose behind this sub-clause? Will we do a deal with some other country and then say to Australians: 'Tough luck, mate. You are a very small voting section of the Australian public. We have just traded off your rights because we have done a big deal with some other country'. Can honourable members opposite tell me what those things mean and what purpose they serve? I do not think they serve a particular purpose. I have already mentioned sub- clause (d). The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) also mentioned it; so I will not worry too much about that. It is astounding that a piece of Australian legislation can give the right to the Government to act 'whether or not it is also a matter of domestic concern'. It is unbelievable to suggest that people from another country can apply pressures and that that can be used as an excuse. Let us be very careful. Some raving right wing group may decide that it will have some laws and rules of an intolerable nature that this Government would not like very much.

I have been in this place for just over two years and I am deeply concerned about some of the decisions that my Government took in that time-not on matters of human rights but on issues which I predicted at the time we would wear, and which we are beginning to wear. This is the message for the present Government. Some Government members are the greatest human rights advocates in this place- probably greater human rights advocates than me. But they are introducing a Bill that does not care about human rights. Honourable members opposite are saying, ' We have an obligation to meet on this. We think we picked up a couple of seats because we made a promise and let us not worry about anything else'. There are some people in another place who actually are the survivors of the sectional vote and who, strangely enough, also consider themselves great defenders of human rights. They have subverted completely their position in the expediency of supporting their voting bloc which does not want that dam. I refer of course to the flights of aeroplanes and the use of the military forces in Tasmania. There is no way that on any other issue and in any other place the Australian Democrats would not have brought the House down on that matter. It is another great tragedy to see people losing sight of the wood for the trees.

I ask honourable members, for goodness sake, to think about these clauses. I suggest to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) that he should ask himself whether he needs them or whether he can survive with a simplified clause of the nature we have put before him. The day may come when it will be his name that will be held up as a major person to take away from Australians something which I think we put above the value of all else. The checks and balances of the federal system are extremely good. They can be provided for in this particular Bill. If they were it would certainly have my support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prompted to make some remarks about clause 6 of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill by what has been said by the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman). Let me say that I agree generally with what he had to say and I thought it was very much to the point. The interpretation of the external affairs power has not stood still. We all know that, and we all know that now the High Court of Australia places a very different interpretation on it from that which was placed on it in 1901. That may be said to be beside the point because the Constitution has to be interpreted to reflect changing circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: But let us see where we are. By means of reliance upon the external affairs power, as the honourable member for Prospect has pointed out, it is quite possible for laws to be passed by this Parliament which otherwise would be quite beyond power. He pointed to the danger of single issue politics and I agree that single issue politics do present a great danger. If one is to deal with a particular issue such as whether the Franklin River should be dammed, whether drilling should take place on the Barrier Reef or whether anything else should take place which some would regard as an affront to the cultural heritage of this country and others would not, then it might be very much wiser to deal with each issue on a case-by-case basis because, if we go down this road, we cannot see where it will lead. If governments come to rely upon the external affairs power to pass legislation which at the time appears to be good, then this precedent will become or may become entrenched in the Parliament. The honourable member for Prospect put an instance of a government of a far right wing persuasion entering into an agreement with South Africa on subversive activities .

Let me put another instance. Let us assume that sometime in the future we found a government of an extremely right wing nature and one that none of the members on this side of the House would embrace. This could happen in politics. Let us assume that that government was deeply opposed to the union movement in all manifestations. It may not be difficult to find a country with which a treaty could be entered into, the effect of which would be to outlaw the union movement . That would be a very bad thing. But the posibility remains that the power can be misused. Some would say that these are mere possibilities. The answer that I put to honourable members is that they should consider very carefully where the use of the extension of power can lead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to comment on clause 6 of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill and to draw the attention of the Committee in particular to the proposal by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) on the need to include at the beginning of clause 6 this phrase:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and the Parliament of the State and the Commonwealth have consented to that inclusion.

I think that we are putting a very important proposition to the Government. I would ask the Government, and particularly the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen), to look very carefully at what the honourable member for Bradfield is suggesting there. I turn back for a moment to the Minister's second reading speech, just to illustrate the point. He said:

The nomination of the Western Tasmanian Wilderness National Parks was submitted by the Australian Government to the World Heritage Committee, at the request of the Government of Tasmania, in November 1981.
Later in his speech he said:
At the same time, a State Government, following the request by the State itself for nomination of the property now seeks to destroy some of its most important features.

I refer to the speech of the Minister in order to make a couple of points. First of all, the Minister was being a little mischievous there because he was implying that the State did not know what it was doing. But he well knows the fact of the matter. The second point I want to make in order to emphasise the point that my colleague has made in the amendment is this: In November 1981 the then Premier of Tasmania, Mr Lowe, was under siege on this issue, and under siege with a weak government that was divided amongst itself and which was floundering around trying to find a way out. He went to the Government and said: 'Put it on the World Heritage List'. His aim clearly was to try to find a course of action that would stop the problems that he had in his Government and perhaps persuade the people of Tasmania to go with him. He did not put it to the State Parliament. Rumour would have it that he did not really ever get the consent of his own party to do so. But the effect of what he did was probably what we are all now facing here in this place. What is being suggested by my colleague-

TALK.START.PARA: —And your Government accepted it.
—If you want me to argue that, I will. I am trying to be constructive.
—How did it get on the World Heritage List if you didn't do it?

—I will come to that later, if you wish me to. But let me finish the point I am making. The point which the honourable member for Bradfield is trying to make is that this sort of thing would not occur again. There would be no question of who had a mandate. There would be no question of whether the people of the State wanted something or not because the amendment would show that the State Parliament and the Government had agreed to the request to put the area forward for inclusion on the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of Mr Lowe's action in November 1981 is really very dramatic. I recognise that people on the other side of the House have strong feelings about the preservation of the wilderness area. Equally, people on this side of the House do too. But we have to understand that the action that the Government is taking tonight, the bungling that occurred over the use of the F111s and the way the Government tried to negotiate a position on this matter have meant that it has alienated the majority of Tasmanians. They truly and really feel alienated.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have aggravated that situation.

—Well, you have too. Both sides have. We have been trying to explain here that we have a responsibility to acquit the vote that we got and that is all we are doing, as well as sticking up for the State. If this amendment were accepted by the Government it would be a foolproof way of ensuring that the States rights are recognised and that there truly is a mandate for putting such an area on the World Heritage List. The Minister wanted to comment about the fact that we put the area on the World Heritage List. Let us come to the description of that by the Minister. In his second reading speech, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The World Heritage Committee had before it reports of the proposal for dam contruction in the area.

That must be the understatement of the year. It certainly is an attempt to distort the facts. Surely the Minister knows that the proposal to include the area in the World Heritage List was made against the strongest objections of the Premier of Tasmania. Up to the eleventh hour of the nomination going forward, the Premier argued that he had a strong mandate from his State to the effect that it should not go forward. That is the first point.

The second point-and this is why I say that portion of the second reading speech is misleading-is that the World Heritage Committee had before it not a report of the proposed dam construction in the area but rather a clear statement by the Federal Government that the dam would be constructed. It was a specific aspect of the application. Specifically, the policy of the Tasmanian Government was to construct the dam. It certainly was not just a case of reporting a proposal to construct a dam in that area.

Therefore, I urge the Government if it really means what it has been telling everyone in this country, that one of its objectives is national reconciliation, to accept this amendment. That may do something to repair the damage that the Government has caused in one little State of this Federation.

Finally, I pay tribute to my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) for the way in which he has produced these amendments and handled this whole matter for the Opposition. It is something that we from Tasmania appreciate very much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on this clause shows quite clearly that this Parliament, recognising the existence of the federal system, needs to work out a way in which State and Commonwealth Governments can appropriately protect items of our heritage that warrant inclusion in the World Heritage List. The amendment that has been moved by my colleague, the honourable member for Bradford (Mr Connolly), seeks to resolve that problem. As the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), speaking from the Government benches, said so forcibly a few minutes ago, we should have grave reservations about the use of the foreign affairs power in an extended form. There are also very grave doubts in the minds of many of us as to whether that power extends to the legislation that is now before us; whether it gives us the authority so to legislate.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, it is quite clear that we should be looking at this matter objectively and aside from specific issues, so that we can put on the statute books legislation that will avoid our getting into the sort of emotional debate in which we have been involved in respect of South West Tasmania. That is why the amendment of the honourable member for Bradfield should be supported.

As I indicated earlier, I would have liked the Parliament to go one step further and embrace an amendment that would cover the five properties currently on the World Heritage List. What the amendment before us proposes is that, in future, inclusion in the World Heritage List and subsequent protection of properties by the Australians authorities should be undertaken as a result of agreement between, and the passing of legislation by, the parliaments of the State concerned and of the Commonwealth.

The experience of the past few years in relation to items proposed for inclusion in the World Heritage List has left us with a major problem. We propose that in future the mechanism should involve action by the State Parliament. We had not thought of that before. But the issue has now arisen. The chronology of events has been such that we need to study carefully, and to understand, the implications for a Commonwealth Government, in the environmental or any other area, when it acts upon the request of a Premier. Must a Prime Minister, every time he receives a request from a Premier, send an acknowledgement and say: 'Mr Premier, I am not sure whether you have authority from your Ministers; could you please confirm that you have'? Or must a Prime Minister write to the State Premier and say: 'I am not sure whether you have the authority of your Ministers; I am not even sure that you have the authority of your Parliament. Please write again when you have put through a Bill'. Quite clearly, governments have properly acted upon the basis of requests made by Premiers.

In considering the chronology of events relating to South West Tasmania, we may go back to July 1980. Then, under Commonwealth legislation, the South West Conservation Area was placed on the register of the National Estate. On 8 December 1980, the Tasmanian Government recommended nomination of the South West National Park for world heritage listing. The World Heritage Committee rejected that application because, it said, the park that was then proposed for listing was unacceptable. On 28 March 1981, the Tasmanian Government proclaimed the Wild Rivers National Park, which included the Franklin River. Did the Premier do that in secret? Did he do it alone or did his Government do it? The National Park was created by the Government authorities of the day. On 22 September 1981, the Tasmanian Government proposed the South West National Park, the Wild Rivers National Park, and the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park for nomination for the World Heritage List. That area was to be collectively known as the Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks.

The Commonwealth Government then acted-in reliance upon the earlier declaration of the Wild Rivers National Park and the subsequent request by the Premier. In those circumstances we must examine how we are to protect the five areas that Australia has nominated and that have been accepted for listing on the World Heritage List. I believe that in relation to the South West, as in relation to the Willandra Lakes and Lord Howe Island, the procedure was necessarily different because we were feeling our way. In those circumstances, if this legislation had been narrowly drafted, if it had been confined to those five areas and was then tested to determine whether or not the Commonwealth had power to pass legislation to protect the five properties listed under the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage, the circumstances would be very different. Instead, we have before us legislation which seeks to confer on the Commonwealth Government an intrusive power, by the exercise, in a very wide and expansive way, of a foreign affairs power.

In that regard, I again draw attention to the comments made earlier by the honourable member for Prospect, who warned this House, including members of his own party, about the dangers of an expansive interpretation of the foreign affairs power. It will be for the High Court to determine how expansive that interpretation should be but I believe that it should be narrowly confined. If there be such a power-I hope that it is very narrow-so to enable the preservation of the Willandra Lakes, Lord Howe Island and South West Tasmania they should be protected. Because the Government of Tasmania is estopped by the actions of its Premier and the earlier declaration of the Wild Rivers National Park, we members of this Parliament should properly be concerned about the protection of South West Tasmania. It is a protection that we have been called upon to achieve at the request of the World Heritage Committee, following a nomination made by us on the basis of a proper request by a State Premier, presumably authorised by his Ministers. Certainly, that authorisation appears to be confirmed by the fact that he and his Government declared the Wild Rivers National Park which was one of the national parks to be incorporated within the area that was subsequently requested by Tasmania for nomination on the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly because I do not want to hold up the Committee for much longer. There has been a lot of talk about the future. The World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill is about the future. A lot of reference has been made by the Government to the planning, requirements and needs. I thought I might read from the National Economic Summit Conference the words of Sir Arvi Parbo. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is undoubtedly necessary to plan and to forecast to the best of one's ability. However, I would like to sound a word of caution. We should not overestimate our ability. It is an attractive thought that we should foresee and plan our future with assurance and confidence. However, it is a sobering fact that if anyone three years ago had predicted exactly what has happened since, that person would have enjoyed two distinctions. He or she would have been the only person in the country to do so and he or she would have been considered mad by all the experts.

TALK.START.PARA: —This proposal for the substitution of a different clause 6 (2) is unacceptable. It would make the coverage by the Bill of heritage property within a State conditional upon the parliament of the State consenting to the property being covered by the Bill. This would defeat the whole purpose of the Bill which is to enable the national Government to take action where a State has failed to take the necessary action. If the amendment were accepted the Bill would not be an effective vehicle for giving effect to the treaty because its effectiveness would depend upon State components.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). There has been some confusion tonight on exactly the content of Article 5 of the World Heritage Convention and how it should be interpreted. For the benefit of honourable members I think we should place in Hansard exactly what it says in terms of its opening clause. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: To ensure that effective and active measures are taken for the protection, conservation and presentation of the cultural and natural heritage situated on its territory, each State Party to this Convention shall endeavour, in so far as possible--
I emphasise those words-
and as appropriate for each country:

In a Federal situation, therefore, the whole question of the relevant division of powers between the Commonwealth and the States is the essence of the words ' appropriate for those countries'. What that means in terms of Australian advice is illustrated by advice given to the previous Government by its legal advisers which states: 'If the Australian Government, while unconvinced of Tasmania's case for the dam, believes that that Government entertains such belief and that in such circumstances Commonwealth intervention would harm the Federation or that the belief might be true or that for serious reason it should not intervene , the Convention does not oblige it to take any steps. This stems from the true construction of Article 5 of the Convention'. I rest my case on the simple fact that the Government has chosen to interpret Article 5 in a way which meets its political objectives but which are not consistent with the contents of the Convention nor with the social, economic or any other national realities of Australia.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal briefly with some administrative aspects of clause 8 of this legislation. May I say that, as one who has been to South West Tasmania and as one who would prefer that the dam was not built, it is of great concern to me that we are debating this Bill at all. The way to solve the South West Tasmania dispute in my view was through negotiation. I am very disappointed that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did not go to Tasmania in an effort to find a solution to the problem. Instead, we have this legislation which raises such fundamental issues regarding States' rights that the initial question of saving the Franklin River area has been lost in a debate which is now focused on the heart of our federal system of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Putting aside my disagreement with the Bill on the constitutional question, I refer to difficulties arising out of clause 8 should the Bill be passed. Clause 8 seeks to invoke the Commonwealth's constitutional powers relating to Aboriginal affairs. I think it was probably included in the legislation as a fall-back position in case the High Court of Australia rules that clause 6 is beyond the Commonwealth's external affairs power. Certainly it seems that clause 6 will be the real basis for action under this Bill if allowed by the High Court . However, if that fails, clause 8 may be used.

Clause 8 purports to give the Governor-General power to protect Aboriginal sites. Under the Bill, Aboriginal sites are those which fulfil two criteria: Firstly, they are within identified property-that is, if the area had been nominated for, or is on, the World Heritage List, or, the site has been declared to form part of the cultural or natural heritage; secondly, and as the Bill states, the site must be of particular significance to the people of the Aboriginal race by reason of the presence on the site of artifacts or relics or otherwise. I presume that 'otherwise' refers to sacred sites and the like. Clause 8 (3) requires the Governor-General to be satisfied that it is an Aboriginal site pursuant to the definition and that it is being damaged or is likely to be damaged. The question then arises as to how the Governor-General satisfies himself that the site is of particular significance to the people of the Aboriginal race.

The Governor-General would normally rely on the advice of his Ministers-in- Council. But we are still left guessing as to what criteria his Ministers are to use to assess whether a site is of particular significance. Identifying and protecting sites of significance to date has been undertaken mostly by the States.
Let me quote from page 4 of the 1976-77 annual report of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies, where some of the Institute's activities are dealt with. The report states:

Funding continued for 15 site recorders within State administrations; 3 site recording positions were funded in New South Wales, one in Victoria, three in South Australia, two in the Northern Territory, four in Western Australia, one in Queensland and one in Tasmania. In addition, the rock art conservation program at the Western Australian Museum, has continued under the conservator and his assistants. Aboriginal training programs provided for four trainees, two in New South Wales, one in the Northern Territory and one in South Australia. In addition, financial support was provided for the training program at the Western Australia Museum.

The Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies has established a national register of sites, and it may be that this would be used to identify sites and it may be that this could be used to identify sites of particular significance. Bear in mind that the Government has to advise the Governor-General as to sites- not just Aboriginal sites but sites of particular significance. Let us say it is going to use the Institute. Mr Walsh's report of the review of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies states at page 43:

The desirability of establishing and maintainng a national register of significant sites is not in question but the Institute has really achieved little more than obtain material for archival purposes. The Institute has adopted the practice of recording all Aboriginal sites as information becomes available, in order that their significance may be determined later.

I am not in a position to test the validity of that statement. However, it does clearly leave open the question as to the administrative arrangements that are to be made to provide the Governor-General with information to ensure he is in a position, in the words of the Bill, to 'satisfy' himself that the proposed site is of 'particular significance to the people of the Aboriginal race'. If satisfactory administrative procedures are not laid down and made public, clearly the Government will leave itself open to criticism and possibly further legal challenges from both the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities and perhaps State and local governments. I trust the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen), who is at the table, will inform the House of the arrangements which have been made to meet the requirements of this clause. Further, I trust that the Aboriginal people will have an input in that decison- making process. I hope that the Minister can provide the Parliament with details of the consultative arrangements which have been made.
Amendments agreed to.

Revocation of Proclamations under sections 6, 7 and 8

''15A. (1) Subject to sub-section (3), where the Governor-General is satisfied that there is no longer any threat of damage to, or of the destruction of, property in respect of which a Proclamation under section 6 or 7 is in force, he may, by Proclamation, revoke that first-mentioned Proclamation.

New clause 15A provides a special procedure for the revocation of proclamations of properties or sites that have been proclaimed pursuant to clauses 6, 7 or 8. The purpose of the new clause 15A is to place conditions on the power of the Governor-General-in-Council to revoke proclamations under clauses 6, 7 or 8. Before a proclamation may be revoked a resolution approving the proposed revocation must be passed by each House of Parliament.

The purpose of adding this requirement is to establish parliamentary control over the maintenance of protection where actual damage to or destruction of property or sites or the threat of such damage or destruction has been such as to justify the making of a proclamation. If such a serious situation had already arisen the government believes that protection should not be removed without the concurrence of Parliament. The requirement for a resolution of each House of Parliament follows the provision made in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, section 31, in relation to a revocation of a proclamation of an area as part of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

Clause 16 (Compensation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 16, page 9, line 12, after 'Constitution' add 'as extended by sub- section 3A'.
(5) Clause 16, page 9, line 15, after '1975' add 'and any Regulations made pursuant to this Act'.
(6) Clause 16, page 9, after sub-clause (3) insert the following sub-clause:

'(3A) For the purposes of sub-section (3) property shall be deemed to have been acquired from a person in accordance with the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 to the extent that its use or its enjoyment by a person has been affected by the operation of this Act or the Regulations.'.
(7) Clause 16, page 9, sub-clause (4), line 38, omit 'High Court', substitute ' Federal Court'.
(8) Clause 16, page 9, sub-clause (5), line 41, omit 'High Court', substitute ' Federal Court'.

The compensation provisions in this Bill, in the light of a deep examination of the question, have caused the Opposition very real concern. Apart from the basic principles of this legislation, with which we also have great difficulty and which we have already discussed, we believe that the essence of this legislation must never lose sight of the fact that where the Crown, for whatever reason, believes that it has to obtain access to property relating to world heritage, for example, or to the other matters covered by this Bill, attention must always be given to ensure that the basic rights of owners of that property-whether they be States, corporations or individuals-are adequately taken into account.

I regret to say that this is not the situation as the compensation clauses have been drawn in this Bill at this time. I suspect that one of the reasons this is so is twofold. Firstly, a policy decision has been taken by the Government that in the event of the High Court of Australia determining that Tasmania does not have the right to build a dam, in the sense that the Commonwealth has the right under one of those four heads of power to prevent it from doing that, the Crown- that is the Commonwealth-would like to be in a position to prevent the construction but at the same time not have to pay adequate and fair compensation to the Government of Tasmania for the loss of the usage of the facilities which would naturally come from the dam. This, of course, is a political judgment and one which any government is entitled to make. Whether, however, it is a fair judgment to make in terms of the implications of such a decision on any State of this Commonwealth is a matter of gravest concern to the Opposition.

One of the basic principles of justice in our society has always been that those who have rights to land, at whatever level that right may be, also have the right to due, fair and appropriate compensation if for any reason in the so- called national good it has been effectively taken over by the Crown. Therefore we, as I said, enter into this debate on this clause full of concern that the provisions, as they stand, are in no sense adequate to take normal cognisance of the real situation concerning the rights of individuals and corporations or in this case a State of the Commonwealth. For that reason we have put forward a number of amendments. I refer specifically to clause 16 (1) and the concept of adding the words on line 15: 'and any Regulations made pursuant to this Act'. We do that in the specific hope that, as I have referred to earlier, the Government will give serious consideration to utilising the existing formulas found in the Lands Acquisition Act 1955. That Act covers in every reasonable degree adequate compensation in terms of Crown land, State or Federal, matters to consider in the determination of compensation, agreement as to amounts of compensation for acquisition, determination of compensation by agreement after acquisition and determination of compensation both by a court and through the normal procedures of arbitration.

As clause 16 stands at the moment we have the interesting situation that the Government is putting to the House a proposal that there should be a fundamental division between claims for compensation exceeding $5m and those claims which are less than $5m. The implication appears to be that by utilising the concept of a commission of inquiry people will be encouraged to go by a route which is not necessarily going to give them fair and adequate compensation if they do not go through the traditional avenue under Australian law, and that is to seek the support or otherwise of the court system. Consequently, we are suggesting that the contents of the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 be used as the basic model in this case. The amendment I have moved to insert new sub-clause 3A covers this question adequately. The provisions for compensation should be in accordance with the Lands Acquisition Act to the extent that its use or the enjoyment by a person of that land has been affected by this Act or by the regulations which may in due course come from it.

The minor details also concern the fact that sub-clauses (4) and (5) of clause 16 also relate to the need to make application to the High Court. Again, this is a rather extraordinary situation because as we are well aware the High Court under present law is the ultimate appellate court of the Commonwealth. It seems an extraordinary situation that matters of compensation at this level should, on the question of first instance, be from the individual through the Commonwealth to the High Court. So what we have recommended is that the High Court be replaced, with a reference to the Federal Court, with the intention that should a person feel that he has still been wronged after having made representations to the Federal Court, he can still appeal to the High Court.

This is an important matter because there is already the difficulty that much legislation is now being referred to the High Court. Most of the courts of the Commonwealth are on appeal making reference to the High Court and unless this is merely another technique of the Government to create a situation where it has no alternative but to establish a larger bench-more of its own kidney, perhaps-on the grounds of its inability to handle the amount of legislation before it, then I and my colleagues believe that to enter into a situation where compensation claims also have to be to the High Court in the first instance would simply be a very dubious way indeed of trying to establish a case for more judges of that court.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments are all concerned with clause 16, which sets out elaborate machinery for compensation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments proposed by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) to clause 16. In doing so, let me say that that support can be regarded as support for the purpose of ensuring that the Bill, if it becomes an Act, operates in a more efficient manner. I am sure that none of us want to have legislation go through this House, regardless of our views on the legislation, which operates in an inefficient or cumbersome manner. Amendments (7), (8) and (9) as proposed by the honourable member for Bradfield would substitute the Federal Court for the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 16 (3) provides that where a person considers that the operation of the Act or the regulations has resulted in an acquisition of property from that person, he may give notice to the Minister. The Minister must then consider the notice to determine whether or not he considers that the operation of the Act or the regulations has resulted in an acquisition of property. If he does not consider that the operation of the Act or the regulations has resulted in an acquisition of the property in question then he is bound to send a notice in writing to that effect. The person who made the application- that is, in effect, the property owner-may then make an application to the High Court requesting it to make a declaration that the operation of the Act or the regulations has in fact resulted in an acquisition of his property.

The constitutional question that I would understand the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) has in mind is whether or not the operation of the Act can be considered to fall within section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution . This is a question of principle which no doubt would be considered by the High Court, and it would determine that question of principle. But the practical difficulty is this: There may be under the operation of the Act many cases where a property owner and a Minister would disagree. I do not impute any ill faith in advance to any Minister but there could be many such cases. When such a case arises the only procedure open to the property owner is to seek a declaration from the High Court. This could easily, in fact one would think almost inevitably, cause the High Court to be burdened down by applications for declarations which in effect are no more than factual disputes, because in the first instance all that needs to be determined is the applicable principle. While this may be a constitutional question, we are concerned here with a constitutional question of a limited kind. That constitutional question is whether or not the Act can operate, or does in any circumstances operate, as an acquisition within the placitum of the Constitution to which I have referred. Once that question is determined as a matter of principle, everything thereafter is really very much a matter of the application of the principle of law to the facts of the particular case. It would be a quite unnecessary burden on the High Court for it, in effect, to be put in the position of being the court to determine the application of a principle, which it has laid down and which it understands, to a wide variety of facts and possibly to a great number of cases.

The important thing which I say to members of the Government is simply this: Those were not the words of some politician who happened to be gracing the Opposotion side in the Parliament or some megalomaniac, as some people on the Government side have suggested some of my colleagues might be; those are the words of one of the most highly respected lawyers in this land who has been given the function of th senior judge of the High Court of Australia. He made that judgment in the Koowarta case which has been quoted by many people on the Government side as the basis for claiming that the Commonwealth may have the power in terms of the Tasmanian dams issue.

As I said in my speech yesterday, and as I reiterate today, these questions now rest with the High Court. We must not dulude ourselves from the ultimate responsibility that the law is not made by justices of the High Court. The law is made by politicians and by the people through the system of referenda which has stood us pretty well since 1901. It is for these reasons, therefore, that we ask the Committee not to support the inclusion of the external affairs head of power as part of this legislation, knowing full well, of course, that the Government will naturally oppose our recommendations.

I refer briefly to the second proposition. We believe there is a very strong case for including in law ultimately the provisions that, in future when States are prepared to make suggestions to the commonwealth for the inclusion of items on the World Heritage List, those recommendations must be supported by State parliaments and also by the Federal Parliament. My objective would be that over a period, because of the exclusive nature of the vary rare cases which go on the World Heritage List, each of those cases deserves a piece of legislation in its own right which sets down the provisions for the State resonsibility and the provisions for Commonwealth responsibility which would then be supported by both parlaiments so we would obviate for all time the difficult situation which we have faced in recent months in terms of the Tasmanian issue. Therefore, I move:
(3) Clause 6, pages 2 and 3, omit sub-clause (2), substitute the following sub- clause:

'(2) A proclomation may also be made under sub-section (3) in relation to identified property that is in a State if the property, after the commencement of this Act, has been included in the World Heritage List by the World Heritage Committee, pursuant to article 11 of teh Convention and the Parliament of the State and Commonwealth have consented to that inclusion.

I understand that the Minister may not at this stage be in a position to give a final view upon this amendment but it is, as I say, an amendment of a technical nature which is designed to make the Act operate more efficiently. One can easily see that all rights would be adequately safeguarded if, in place of the High Court, one substituted the Federal Court since where it was necessary for an aggrieved property owner to contest a Minister's decision, he could in the first instance go to the Federal Court. If he or the Minister was dissatisfied with the determination of the Federal Court, which would be a determination at first instance, there would then be an appeal procedure open from the Federal Court at first instance to a full court-that is to say, a court of appeal of the Federal Court. If there was any outstanding matter of legal principle of such importance that the High Court's determination was desirable, there would then be open, with the leave of the High Court, an appeal to that court. But to burden it in the first instance with the jurisdiction of being the recipient of applications for declarations, is, I would put to the Minister, most unnecessary and indeed cumbersome and inconvenient.

I can well understand how in the preparation of legislation such as this one may look to the High Court as the court to determine disputes. But this overlooks entirely the fact that what one must pay attention to is the fact that the principle will be laid down and it is the application of that principle to many cases which will be the burden of the work under this clause if, and when, it becomes a section. Therefore, I ask the Minister to reconsider the mechanisms which are in place and to substitute the words 'Federal Court' for the words ' High Court', recalling that, in any matter of great constitutional difficulty, the High Court would, in any event, be the ultimate arbiter of that question.
