SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up some of the observations of my colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) and re-emphasise the point I made when we started discussing this clause. The question of compensation is of fundamental importance to the Opposition. What has been stated by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) in response to my earlier comments has merely confirmed my worst fears. He effectively said-as we already knew and as I stated in my speech yesterday at the second reading stage-that this is a piece of legislation which does nothing more and is not meant to do any more than provide a key which the Government can use in the constitutional sense through its four heads of power to get a judgment out of the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: A favourable decision will result in the Government being able to prevent certain activities taking place in Tasmania. I think it is a travesty of justice -it is certainly a travesty of the normal procedures of legislation in this Parliament-that even questions of compensation have been linked in every single element of this exercise by the Government with that judgment it hopes to obtain .

I remind honourable members that, whatever the decision of the High Court is, this Bill will still stand. The provisions for compensation contained within it will be the basis against which in future years, whenever this Government or any succeeding government wishes to bring forward world heritage property proposals, the judgment will be made as to whether compensation will be payable either to the States-as I said earlier-to corporations or individuals. Earlier at this table, the Minister made the observation that we are not talking about laws for governments; we are talking about the rights in relation to laws for individuals . That is what we stand for in this Opposition. Above all, we stand for the rights of individuals. It is not satisfactory for the Minister to come in here and simply to tell us, through his advisers, that nothing can be done on the question of compensation because the whole thing is locked up with his total strategic approach to the Government's handling of the case before the High Court. The amendments which the Opposition has put forward are quite simple, straightforward and absolutely in conformity with existing constitutional principles. In this respect, my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) referred to section 51 placitum (xxxi) of the Constitution which I read for the benefit of honourable members:
The acquisition of property on just terms from any State or person for any purpose in respect of which the Parliament has power to make laws:

There is no question, therefore, that the Commonwealth does not have power to acquire. There is no question under constitutional situations as the Constitution stands at the moment. Yet this Bill is again trying to reinvent the wheel in that area for somewhat nefarious purposes. It is for that reason that we have recommended, and we stand by our recommendation, that the whole question of utilising, for example, this two-tiered approach in this Bill-as I said earlier with reference to compensation which is under $5m or is over $5m-should be linked to the basic principle that a person who feels he has been wronged under the proposed Act in terms of the provisions of compensation offered by the Minister at the first instance has the right to take the case to the Federal Court for judgment. That is a perfectly simple observation.

What the Government has done in this Bill is to go a step further. The Government has established a most intricate arrangement by which the Governor- General may establish a commission of inquiry. Apart from the fact that it is to have three members, one of which may be appointed by the State Government, the Government tells us nothing about the conditions and nothing about whether these people should have adequate qualifications, and it gives no details as to the operations of these commissions of inquiry. I shall make one certain prognostication, and it is simply this: Such commissions of inquiry will add yet further delay to the question of whether the individual will ever get his money, in terms of his rights to compensation. The estimates which I have worked out, which I included in my speech in the second reading debate, are that in most cases, and especially those of any complexity whatever-and let us be frank; in some cases there will be complex issues to be settled-there could easily be delays of between five and six years if those concerned are going down the road of having to make reference to Ministers, then reference to commissions of inquiry and then reference to courts and God knows what else.

But we have had the most interesting observation of all: Once one has gone through this most intricate and complex procedure, the Governor-General, who appointed the commission of inquiry in the first place, does not have to obey or accept the recommendations that the commission has made. So the poor frustrated individual who has lost access to his property finds himself in the unique situation of being right back at stage one, regardless of the number of days or years lost and the amount of time it has cost him to go through the procedures or anything else. The Minister says that he represents a party of compassion and concern for the little people. Little people can own land just as anyone else can. They have just as much right as anyone else to have reasonable access through the courts to get just terms where compensation requirements are made. That is why we return to what I said previously. The Lands Acquisition Act, which has been accepted in this Parliament, and which is a product of this Parliament, which has been accepted by Liberal and Labor governments alike for many years, should be the basis of the compensation mechanisms which should be in this legislation.

My final observation relates to sub-clause (6) of clause 16-I omitted to refer to it earlier-on the question of the payment of interest. Some members may be aware that the Fraser Government, in the last two years, introduced a very worthwhile amendment to the Income Tax Act in relation to the question of the payment of interest where there was a significant delay in settlement of the question of what level of taxation was due when a case was taken before the various inquiry mechanisms. What we are simply suggesting for this legislation is that a similar provision be introduced so that interest shall be payable on the amount of compensation determined by the Governor-General or the Federal Court as the case may require; that such interest is to be calculated from the date of the acquisition up to and including the date of payment at a rate that is fair and just in the circumstances. Again, a provision of that nature is also to be found in the Lands Acquisition Act.

Again I emphasise the point: We are talking about the rights of individuals who , through no fault of their own, may well find themselves owning property or having a right of interest in property which has been claimed by the Commonwealth under this legislation, especially in terms of its very wide coverage, as we saw in the first clauses of the Bill, in relation to cultural heritage or natural heritage. We are not just talking about the Sydney Harbour Bridge; we are talking about the rural properties of Australia; we are talking about potential Aboriginal sites which people may own without any knowledge of their historical or cultural significance. Yet under this legislation as it stands the future rights of those people to access to adequate compensation are by no means secure.

For example, under this Bill, which the Minister is so skilfully presenting to the Parliament, it is provided by clause 9 that there are a variety of unlawful acts, and that one may not, except with the consent in writing of the Minister-and one wonders how much consent would be forthcoming from the Minister, who I know would administer the legislation in the most just and fair manner-carry out any excavation works, carry out operations on it, erect a building, damage or destroy a building, or kill, cut down or damage any tree.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us ponder upon that for a minute. Let us assume that one has a property of, say, 40 or 50 hectares and, stupidly enough, one has bought this piece of property before this Bill is brought before the Parliament, and one suddenly finds, as a result of the operation of the Bill when it becomes an Act, that one cannot cut down a tree on one's own property, that one cannot construct any road or vehicular track, and indeed, if the Minister comes on to the property, one is not even entitled to use explosives. Is that not simple justice and, as the honourable member for Bradfield said, is it not important that the little man, or any other man, be given compensation in those circumstances, or is this Government looking for the cheap, the easy and the unjust solution?

TALK.START.PARA: —I address myself briefly to clause 16, the compensation clause, and the amendments proposed by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). It is important in this debate to understand that the clauses dealing with compensation deal with the compensation to be paid in any of the circumstances on which this legislation provides that the Commonwealth may intervene. Of course, it needs to be understood that the Commonwealth has not only provided a basis for intervention where an international treaty is involved by using the external affairs power but also in circumstances where it is necessary or where it is declared to be necessary to enact the terms of the proposed section as a special law for people of Aboriginal race. Where that particular power may have been used to protect a particular area, or a corporations power may have been used, it needs to be understood that this legislation and the compensation provisions that will flow from it not only are intended to operate in relation to Tasmania but also may have much wider operation in any of the circumstances where this legislation is used for the purposes of protecting property.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the draftsman was not able to avoid the effect of section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution. The most disappointing part of clause 16 of the Bill is that what the draftsman has tried to do is to limit compensastion to only those circumstances in which the Constitution would provide compensation. So what he has endeavoured to do, by defining acquisition of property in this clause and providing compensation only when an acquisition of property is involved, is to ensure that section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution applies but compensation will not be applicable in any further cases. Of course, one of the amendments that we have proposed is to ensure that the operation of this clause is much wider than the Government's intention.

Clearly, individuals may own land that is in some way affected by an appropriate declaration under this Bill. A company may own land that is affected by an appropriate declaration under this Bill and, of course, States-as in the case of Tasmania in its situation-may own land that is affected and for which compensation may be required. Any individual in Australia would be concerned that his property, or another interest that he may have in property, or an interest that is in any way affected by the operation of this legislation-the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) identified the extent to which actions might be affected-might be interfered with and that compensation might very well not be available. The operations of clause 16 which is designed to postpone possible inquiries for compensation might well be involved. In sub- paragraph (10) of clause 16 provision is made for a commission of inquiry to be established. That is a special form of commission of inquiry to be initiated in relation to the acquisition of property under this legislation. It needs to be understood that that form of inquiry and the compensation that might be assessed as payable under that clause is very much more limited than the rights that are given to people generally under the Lands Acquisition Act of 1955.

It is of the utmost importance that people understand and know that the Commonwealth, when it was established, was in an unusual position. The early framers of the Constitution wanted to be sure that the Commonwealth, when it acted to acquire property from Australians, would not acquire property unjustly. Section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution was a very special provision. Of course, people realise that States, when they acquire property, are able to do so on terms which are often quite unjust because there is no similar provision binding them. It needs to be understood that if one attempts to write out the effect of this section of the Constitution or limit it, that is a very important matter. It is a new principle because the Commonwealth is the one government in Australia in relation to which people knew in the past, as a result of section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution, that they would be entitled to compensation on just terms.
I wish to read to honourable members that section of the Constitution because I think it is important that everybody is aware of it. Section 51 (xxxi) states:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:-
(xxxi) The acquisition of property on just terms from any State or person for any purpose in respect of which the Parliament has power to make laws:

It is those words 'the acquisition of property on just terms' that are so important. Of course, people who have looked at this section from time to time are aware that some effort has been made by the courts to look at what the words 'just terms' mean. I suggest that it is most undesirable to take out of the hands of the Government departments the right to negotiate with people and then take out of the hands of the courts the right to deal with the assessment of just terms.

When a commission of inquiry is established to make special and unique inquiries with procedures to be gone through, procedures that might take quite a deal of time, procedures will be established which can limit people's rights to compensation on just terms. People will be aware that the cost of money is significant these days. Where interest is payable at very high rates the longer a person or a State is denied compensation under this legislation, the amount of compensation that that State or individual would receive would be substantially reduced and, of course, some savings may be involved for the Commonwealth. But that is a new principle so far as the acquisition of property is concerned. I would not want to give up lightly the right to compensation on just terms in legislation such as this. I think the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) ought to consider very seriously the amendments that have been painstakingly developed by the honourable member for Bradfield and which are designed to ensure that a more appropriate system of compensation is available- one which will ensure that not only for States, including Tasmania, but also for any individual, any company or any corporation that might be affected, the compensation will be just and appropriate and that people will not have to complain about the Commonwealth.

I am sure that, like me, honourable members would have been approached from time to time by people who have been affected by resumptions or have been affected in situations where their properties have been acquired by government. I have been approached on a number of occasions by people who have had property acquired by States and I know what a tremendous feeling of loss and deprivation they feel. Very often there is tremendous emotional uncertainty as a result of the loss of their home. It is not a matter that can be taken lightly. People's livelihood can be very much affected, people's property can be affected and it can affect their whole lifestyle and their whole being if they are dealt with unjustly in circumstances like this.

It is for this reason that section 51 (xxxi) was included in the Constitution. It is for this reason that we have been painstaking in developing over a long period, under the Lands Acquisition Act, procedures which ought to apply to ensure that people are dealt with justly and properly. I am sure the Minister would not want to be known as the Minister who introduced legislation that dealt unjustly with individuals and under which proper compensation was not payable. I am sure he would want to take away this Bill, consider these amendments and bring it back in a form that will ensure that justice is done to all Australians .

Earlier this evening we covered a range of matters that were of particular relevance to the question of compensation. Firstly, the Opposition has found, on the part of the Government's spokesman, an utter inability to provide satisfactory answers to the very legitimate queries that Opposition members have raised. There is no question that, in terms of rights, the average Australian citizen likes to know that in the event of his property being taken over, for whatever reason, by the Commonwealth he will be entitled to receive fair and just compensation terms. The most critical and difficult situation that would be created by the Bill is that we would now have two classes of Australians, those fortunate enough to enjoy compensation under the conditions of the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 and those who will have the misfortune of trying to seek compensation under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. It produces great depression in us to find that, in relation to legislation which has been held up to the Australian people as an example of the pristine honour and integrity of the Government, when one actually gets down to the debating stage it is seen not only as not well thought out but also as having such an influence and effect on the rights of ordinary Australians that they have simply been ridden over.

It is fundamental that the owner of territory or property in Australia that for any reason is taken over by the Crown may expect, as a right, to receive fair compensation. Amendment (9) relates specifically to interest payments. I have already made general observations about that and wish merely to repeat that the mechanisms established by this Bill are so bad that they delay the individual obtaining a determination through the court system or via the Governor-General- depending on whether one is talking about compensation in excess of $5m or less than that figure, a most extraordinary division that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) has failed utterly to explain.

We come back to the fundamental question: If the people's rights are to be held in such contempt, if property is to be taken over by the Crown, what will the Government do to make some small recompense to those who lose access to property for a period which I estimate, on the basis of the Government's arrangements, could be between five and six years? The only sensible approach is to return to the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act. That is the basis of our amendments .

If the Minister is not prepared to do that the next most simple and obviously fair alternative is to propose the payment of interest rates on fair and just terms under the circumstances. This provision is again contained in the Lands Acquisition Act. I ask the Minister for about the third time: Why is it that in this case you are trying to create two types of Australians? The first is those who can expect and would receive due compensation on fair and just terms under the Lands Acquisition Act which covers Commonwealth purchases under virtually every other aspect of Australian law. Yet in this situation, in terms of this legislation, the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill, if the property is taken by the Crown for whatever purpose, the result will mean a significant delay in payment if one is lucky enough to get it at all. The second type is the person to whom interest is due, but the Government has advised already it is not prepared to pay it on the value of that property for the period that it has effectively frozen it from use and from enjoyment by the legitimate owner.

These are questions which the Opposition rightfully asks. I ask the Minister these questions on behalf of the Australian people because every person in this country likes to feel that the property he owns is his just reward for the hard work and the effort that he has put into saving the money to obtain the capacity to buy land for whatever purpose. Anyone who owns a house had better start checking the foundations to see whether he can find an Aboriginal axe or something because under this legislation he would find himself in the situation of the Crown simply saying: 'Hard luck, Fred, your property will now be taken by the Crown because it is part of the natural heritage or part of the cultural heritage of Australia'. That will be fine for the Government sitting in Canberra . What I question is this: What are the people of Australia going to think when the draconian implications of this legislation are brought home to them in very cold hard facts? The ultimate fact of course is that they will not get access to compensation and will not get access to interest which they have the right to expect for the period that they have lost access to their property and everything else that goes with it.

Again, for the fourth time, I ask the Minister seriously to put his mind to answering the very serious questions that my colleagues on this side have put in this debate. We have done our best tonight not to hold back the Bill. This is the first division we will call. It was my original proposal that we would not be dividing on this legislation because I am well aware that some Government members have yet to make their maiden speeches. I also understand that some have even issued their Press releases. I only hope that their speeches are not libellous because we may be here for some time, until the Opposition has received an answer, which we have a right to expect, from a Minister to legitimate questions which we have raised in the Committee stage of this Bill. This is not a second reading debate. The Bill has not even reached the third reading stage yet. The delay is in the Government's hands, not in ours.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now considering the Opposition's amendments (9 ) to (13) to clause 16. These amendments are very important because they go to the nub of the argument raised by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) on the question of compensation and the need for such compensation to be fair and just. In relation to the question of interest that might be payable in circumstances where the legislation will operate, he has moved an amendment to add a clause. I will read it to honourable members because I think it is important that they understand the nature of the amendment. The amendment is to sub-clause 9. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Interest shall be payable on the amount of compensation determined by the Governor-General or the Federal Court (as the case may require), such interest to be calculated from the date of the acquisition up to and including the date of payment at a rate of interest which is fair and just in the circumstances.
That provision is of the utmost importance because we were faced with the problem that interest would not be dealt with in this case. Sub-clause 9, as it was proposed, stated:
Where-

(a) the Governor-General has, pursuant to sub-section (8), given notice of his intention to establish a Commission of Inquiry to inquire into the compensation payable in respect of an acquisition of property from a person; and
(b) the person and the Commonwealth have not reached agreement as to the compensation payable . . . .

Of course it then dealt with other matters as to the way in which the Governor- General would act. Honourable members appreciate that no provision was made for interest to be payable in a case where compensation had been provided. I find it quite extraordinary that, in the same week when notice is given by the Government of its intention to provide that interest would be payable in circumstances where a person has had a dispute with the Commissioner of Taxation and where certain moneys have been paid to the Commissioner to satisfy a demand for tax interest would be payable on those funds where the taxpayer wins, in another Bill which is introduced dealing with compensation the question of interest on the amount of compensation payable is not addressed. Obviously, in these days when we have had very high rates of interest and high levels of inflation, the extent to which people are without their money that they have an entitlement to can very much affect the value of that money. In the circumstances where compensation might have been appropriate to be paid, the longer the person can be denied that compensation and denied the interest that would ordinarily be payable in any other circumstances, the more he suffers. He suffers considerably. I cannot understand why any government would want to resist an amendment of this sort which provides for the payment of interest, particularly when, as I have said already, the Government has this week introduced legislation recognising that principle in other circumstances.

I just want to reiterate what our amendments to clause 16 are about. We are faced with a situation in which the Commonwealth is endeavouring to limit the circumstances in which compensation would be payable to people whose property has been affected by the operation of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill. The Government's intention, of course, is that this Bill should operate in the widest possible circumstances. The Government declares that it should operate in the national interest, where sites have been identifed as Aboriginal sites, where properties have been registered under the world heritage treaty and in a wider set of circumstances. I think it is necessary for the Government under clause 6 of the Bill to deal with a wider range of properties for conservation purposes than properties registered under the world heritage treaty . The Bill refers to a property that is part of the heritage distinctive of the Australian nation by reason of its aesthetic, historical, scientific or social significance or its international rating or national renown. That is a very much wider description of property which under this legislation may be declared to form part of the cultural or natural heritage. Those terms are not defined in the legislation. If someone owns an old property which he wants to declare to be of aesthetic, historic, scientific or social significance the provisions of this legislation dealing with the activities that might be undertaken in relation to that property would apply.

I think people need to understand that these compensation provisions are, therefore, of very much wider significance than just the national park in South West Tasmania. We have provisions that relate to properties that are deemed to be of significance to Aboriginal people. Similarly, people might not know whether or not their property is affected in that way and whether a declaration is going to be made under those provisions. Again, the question of compensation might arise in such cases. It is very important, therefore, that the compensation provisions in clause 16 are put right now.

I cannot imagine that any Minister would want to have his name associated with these draconian provisions which limit the effect of section 51 (xxxi) of our Constitution, which I read earlier in respect of other clauses that I discussed. That provision of the Constitution is of the utmost importance. It goes to the very character of Australia. It states:
The acquisition of property on just terms from any State or person for any purpose in respect of which the Parliament has power to make laws:

I reiterate the words 'just terms'. When the Commonwealth was established it was recognised that the Commonwealth would only acquire property from people or deal with people's properties on just terms.

Very important legislation has been passed through this Parliament which has been designed to entrench in our system of government fair provisions for payment of compensation. Interest is a natural corollary of this. When people have a property acquired by government, as property might be acquired after a declaration under this Bill when it becomes an Act, they are entitled to believe that they are going to be dealt with in the way in which people have been traditionally dealt with when their properties have been affected by a Commonwealth law. The fact of the matter is that the Lands Acquisition Act has essentially been accepted by Australians as having been a fair and proper way for compensation to be assessed.

When we have in an innocuous Bill such as the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill provisions which are of very much wider effect and which are designed to alter the very basis upon which compensation might be paid and the steps that have to be gone through, we have to ask ourselves why in this instance these amending provisions to the Lands Acquisition Act have been included. I can only believe that the provisions in clause 16 have been included in this Bill with only one purpose in mind, and that is that this is a cunning and devious scheme on the part of the Government to avoid, so far as it is possible, the provisions of section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution, which provide for the Commonwealth to compensate on just terms. I think when people recognise that this is a cunning device which is designed to avoid the payment of proper compensation on just terms to Tasmania in this instance and has very much wider implications for all Australians they will be calling upon all of us to repeal this proposed section if the Government sees fit to proceed with it tonight. I am sure that this provision will be very carefully examined by all our colleagues in the Senate, the House of review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr. H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hesitate to delay the Committee further on this matter. However, it quite beggars the imagination, it is beyond my understanding why in a Bill which is designed for the purposes of preserving world heritage properties and in particular the South West Tasmania wilderness area-and I argued very strongly this morning that one ought to attempt to preserve this property-the Government should choose to introduce such provisions in relation to compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have proposed a relatively simple amendment in place of the very complex clauses in the Bill. The procedure which is set out in the Bill could take a very long time to complete. The legislation provides for negotiation with a Minister about a request for compensation. In the event that a claim is rejected there is provision for an application to be made to the High Court for a declaration. The Minister is again involved if the Commonwealth and the party cannot agree, and the Governor-General convenes a commission of inquiry. The commission has to give a written report within up to 12 months of its being convened. The Governor-General then determines what is fair and just compensation. To crown it all, if the party affected considers that the Governor -General's determination is not fair and just the Federal Court comes into the picture to determine the issue of the amount of compensation. So a whole string of procedures are contained in the Bill. Affected parties who are lucky enough to proceed under the long standing Lands Acquisition Act can get a decision within a reasonable time and be paid reasonable compensation in accordance with the Constitution. However, the whole situation is different if they come under this legislation. In such a case they would be subject to a significant delay. Also, no provision has been made, as we would seek to make, for the payment of interest on the funds so tied up. It defies my understanding why all this should be so. I hope the Minister can do a lot better than he did earlier this evening in giving us, on this side of the House, some explanation as to why this complex procedure should be adopted when there is an accepted and established procedure available, and I ask him to do that.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Mr Speaker, no government that I know of has been more generous in regard to the debate on any Bill than we have been on the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill. The stage we have reached now is like the two Ronnies- honourable members opposite keep saying the same thing. They have been saying it for three days. The Opposition knew the situation when we allocated time for debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, in relation to what the Leader of the House has been saying. If the Minister would answer the questions then we would stop asking them.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—This Government, with its first Bill, has given more time to the Opposition than any government has done in the nine years I have spent in this Parliament. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) have spoken four or five times. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) has spoken, as has the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). Everybody on the Opposition benches has had the opportuntiy to speak, including a number of honourable members who actually support the Government's position. Unfortunately the honourable member for Bass is suffering the frustration of being put from the front bench to the second row, and he does not suffer that gladly. We have to conduct the business of the Government of Australia, and we have given the Opposition almost unlimited time in which to debate this Bill. I told the shadow Minister early in the week that it was our intention that this Bill be completed tonight, and it will be. Members of the Opposition have had more opportunity than any Opposition has ever been given by a conservative Government to debate a Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a pathetic performance, with respect, from the so-called Leader of the House (Mr Young). He gives us 10 minutes and uses up almost half of it. He called a division, as well. He says that the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill is a Bill of great importance. In doing so, he took up another 10 minutes of the time of this House . I had only two more small amendments to this Bill to propose and we could have gone through to the third reading. Instead of that, we were fiddled around for 10 minutes. Let us get down to the fundamentals. Nobody in this House realises any more than we do that this is not just an act in a passing phase of interest on behalf of the Government. This is a constitutional Bill; the whole basis of the Bill is to change the Australian Constitution. If we have been given by the Government a few extra hours as if we are the poor men to whom the crumbs from the rich man's table are thrown, so be it, but there are still a lot of people in Australia who are concerned about their Constitution. Many people in Australia are concerned about their property rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bradfield will be heard in silence.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I seek your indulgence for protection on occasions. We are concerned about those people who voted for us to come here and , on behalf of all Australians, ask the Government exactly what it means to do with this legislation. We set about going through to the Committee stage of the Bill without dividing the House. We did divide the House for one fundamental reason: The legitimate questions that my colleagues asked of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) did not receive a single answer. Furthermore, to add insult to injury, the Government then admitted that it had not thought out the compensation procedures in this Bill. The Government had ignored the traditional compensation arrangements which are covered in the Constitution and which do not require any further constitutional change. It ignored the provisions of existing legislation which covers the purchase of land by the Commonwealth. We have now set upon this extraordinary new route through the jungles of the Australian Labor Party's progress to the future where we are going to have two lots of Australians-those who are protected under the traditional constitutional provisions and those who are not. The Government may think that that is bringing Australia together, but it will not convince us and most certainly it will not convince the Australian people. We want legislation which will stand up to the closest scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: It is our function in the Committee stage of the Bill to bring to the attention of the Government matters of concern to members of both the Government and the Opposition. It is not satisfactory for the Minister simply to say 'I don't know the answers'. I suppose if he shot his cat he would say he did not know the gun was loaded. It is the Australian people who will have to be on the receiving end of this legislation. It will not be the State of Tasmania; the provisions in this Bill go far beyond Tasmania. Whether one wins or loses one certainly cannot draw and neither can the Australian people when it comes to the fact that the individual has to have his rights protected. How can he have his rights protected when he has to face up to a piece of legislation which is a sham? In my speech last night during the second reading debate I emphasised on behalf of the Opposition one key question: If the Government wants a piece of legislation relating specifically to world heritage properties, so be it; if it wants specific legislation relating to the Tasmanian dam, so be it. But, no, it was not satisfied with that. It had to have an omnibus piece of legislation which covers all sorts of things, whether related or not. Then when we ask questions about it, all we are told is 'I don't know'. It is an absolutely ridiculous situation. I have been here for nine years and I have never heard a Minister of any party say 'I don't know the answers'. I have seen a few filibusters over the years but nothing quite as extraordinary as that.

Let me get back to what I wanted to say before the Leader of the House (Mr Young) cuts me off. The procedures for compensation in this Bill are grossly unsatisfactory. We ask the Government to take them away and redraft them, to reconsider exactly what it is trying to achieve. For goodness sake it should relate the Bill to the Constitution as it stands, to the legislation already on the books which has been accepted by all parties over many years. In that regard I simply make this final observation: Why establish a committee of inquiry when one is not needed, when the law is there?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, we are brought here for the purpose of considering the Government's first major Bill. It brings us a Minister, the Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment (Mr Cohen), who is incapable of answering the most fundamental questions. One of the questions put to this Parliament was what should be the just terms of compensation. What does the Minister do? He has amendments and questions put to him but he ignores the questions and does not understand the amendments. He turns to his advisers, walks back, gets a piece of paper, turns around and after a while reads that piece of paper. He does not understand what the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill sets out to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: The compensation provisions provide that the Government can close down the rights of Australians to deal with their properties; it can close down the basic rights of any citizen just so long as it can bring the case within one of the provisions of the Bill. Then what? Does a person have any rights? He does not. One cannot build, put in a road or cut down a tree. As I put to the Minister, a person cannot even cart explosives onto his land for the purpose of blowing up the Minister should he presume to come on to it. What answer do we get to that? 'Well, that is all right because that is the way the Australian Labor Party operates'. It operates on the principle that justice really is our view of the world and not justice according to the views that all Australians have, which is a fair go for people whose rights are going to be affected.

It has been said here by those who seek to confine and narrow the debate that we are dealing with the dam in South West Tasmania. We are not. We are dealing with a Bill the provisions of which will operate throughout Australia. If it becomes an Act, it will enable this Government, by advice given to the Governor- General, which he would be bound to follow, to say for example that all the foreshores of Sydney Harbour come within the Act. In that situation, one could not do anything at all with the land and one would not be entitled to any compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us reflect on some of the provisions in the Bill which need to be considered very carefully. If the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) would bend such faculties as he can on to the subject he might learn something. If honourable members go to the provisions in this Bill concerning compensation and look back to the provisions which deal with what can be done to the property, they will find that, for example, where a proclamation is made nothing in effect can be done with the property concerned. As I said to the chamber, one cannot even cut down a tree.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the kinds of provisions which can bring to bear the issue of a proclamation? Let me give one example. Sub-paragraph (e) of sub-clause 2 of clause 6 states:
the property is part of the heritage distinctive of the Australian nation-
(i) by reason of its aesthetic, historic, scientific or social significance;

God almighty! What does that cover? Who understands that? What does the Government mean by 'social significance'? Does the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) understand that? He most certainly does not. Could he give us a dissertation upon the meaning of that provision? He most certainly could not and he most certainly would not. It can be said that the property can be closed down by reason of its international renown. Sydney Harbour, Brisbane and Perth could be closed down by reason of their international renown. Now who is going to be a judge of the international renown? The Government is. Is that a judgment which is appealable? No, it is not.

In the end, what compensation do we get? We get no compensation at all if a property is closed down. What does this Government do? It deliberately avoids identifying what constitutes an acquisition for the purposes of the Act. It deliberately leaves in limbo the rights of the many people who could be affected by the operation of this Bill if it becomes an Act. It does that because it is not in the least bit concerned with the rights of the average Australian. The Minister seems to have an absolute incapacity to understand the legislation that he is seeking to put through this House. If he did understand what the legislation--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It disturbs me greatly that tonight in the first full week of the parliamentary sitting the Government has moved to apply the guillotine to the first piece of legislation that we have debated. This is the attitude with which the Government is dealing with the Tasmanian people. The Government has introduced legislation which will deny States' rights, which is so broad that it will allow the Government's interpretation of the Constitution to be applied to give it powers that will trample over traditional understanding of Commonwealth powers. The Government is treating this Parliament in the same way as it is going to treat the Australian people should this legislation succeed through the High Court of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unbelievable that a party which recently went to the people of Australia claiming consensus, claiming that it wished to work with all sections of the community, state governments, local authorities, business and unions, can come in on the first full sitting week of the Parliament with the first piece of legislation that comes before the House for debate and cut off debate by the use of the guillotine motion. The Government is seeking to deny the basic democratic process of the Parliament. I can remember the present Leader of the House (Mr Young) complaining on many previous occasions when debate was slightly curtailed . I can remember when late in a session which lasted for many weeks he complained that there was haste in decisions and debate on legislation. He is absolutely hypocritical. On those occasions the present Leader of the House complained that the process of haste was being used. Yet here in the first week in relation to the first Bill to be debated the Leader of the House decides to apply the guillotine. It is a shameful display.

—Many of us on this side of the House-in my case not as long as most honourable members-have sat through year after year of the most arrogant behaviour by governments in the history of this Parliament. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1983).

The Customs Tariff Proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. Proposals No. 1 (1983) introduce into the Parliament, as required by law, tariff changes published in the Australian Government Gazette following the dissolution of Parliament on 4 February 1983. Many of the changes have been in operation for a considerable time, some as far back as 27 May 1982. These changes arose from Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 16 to 26 (1982) which proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966, and which were introduced into the House of Representatives during the last Budget sittings. These proposals were not embodied in the Customs Tariff Act 1966 and have since been translated into a simplified format to meet the requirements of the Customs Tariff Act 1982 which has operated since 1 January 1983.

In addition, the Proposals also contain a new schedule of rates of duty for certain New Zealand goods following the introduction of the closer economic relations trade agreement with New Zealand and a number of changes in order to ensure the correctness of the new simplified Customs tariff. Honourable members will recall that yesterday I introduced a Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. The subject matter of these proposals is also contained in that Bill. The Proposals simply allow the collection of duties to continue until the Bill completes its passage. A summary setting out the nature of the changes has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Proposals to the House.
