PROCTEXT.PARA: Address-in-Reply
Debate resumed from 3 May, on motion by Ms Fatin:
That the following Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Petrie and I remind honourable members that, although the hour is rather late, this is the honourable member's maiden speech and he should be extended the usual courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by thanking honourable members for taking the trouble to attend my late night maiden speech. It is one of the congenial courtesies of this place that honourable members cancel other commitments to attend maiden speeches. I would also like to thank those many people in my electorate who I know have stayed up to hear their new member. I am sorry they were kept waiting by the mindless filibustering of certain honourable members opposite and their time wasting division calling. Mr Speaker, may I now congratulate you on your election as Speaker. It greatly adds to my pleasure in being able so to congratulate you to reflect upon the fact that my personal association with you has been a long and happy one. To think of a parliamentarian better suited to the office than yourself, Sir, would require a considerable effort of the imagination. In this context it is noteworthy that the Opposition parties allowed you to be elected unopposed.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be appropriate to remark upon the legacy of your predecessor, the retiring right honourable member for Bruce. The former Speaker's departure from this House was a triumph for a great principle. This in itself does not distinguish him from dozens of his colleagues whose careers were terminated by the last election. The difference was that the right honourable member for Bruce was retired by his own hand. The former Speaker's decision to retire from parliament was, we were told, part of a package of Opposition measures aimed at establishing a new practice concerning the Speakership.

The proposal is that the Speaker should be above party politics. The suggestion is that the Speaker should be a person acceptable to both sides of the House. The Speaker, in their suggestion, would therefore be elected to his position without opposition in this House. From the time of his election to the Speakership he should, they say, retire from the policy and tactical deliberations of the party which supported him into Parliament. In consequence, his exalted station, high above the machinations of this place, would endow him with a loftiness of vision and an immunity from reprisals that would guarantee that his determinations in this place would be objective, fair and without hint of preference to any party. In fact, Mr Speaker, what your right honourable predecessor is seeking to establish by the supreme sacrifice of his retirement is the Westminster convention concerning the position of Speaker. For those of us on this side of the House, it is a refreshing change to see the men of 1975 trying to establish rather than destroy Westminster conventions. So, while they are in the mood for it, let me remind the few of them who remain of a few more good ones that they might like to observe this time around. There is a constitutional convention that the upper House does not block Supply. There is a constitutional convention that the Government is drawn from the party that has a majority on the floor of the lower House. There is a constitutional convention that a government resigns if it loses a motion of no confidence. Finally, there is a constitutional convention that the Governor-General acts only on the advice of Ministers who command majority support in the lower House. Its corollary is that Opposition members act improperly if they collaborate in the Governor- General's unconstitutional proposal to do otherwise.

While we must applaud the Opposition's new found zeal for Westminster conventions, I urge Opposition members to pause in their exuberance to establish new conventions to reflect upon those that they trampled upon in their seizure of power in 1975. Nevertheless, to give credit where it is due, the composite gesture from the Opposition benches consisting of Opposition members refraining from opposing your election, Mr Speaker, and their former Speaker offering his resignation is a gesture which has, whatever its motivation, much more than a merely economic significance. But if the Opposition really wishes to establish the Westminster convention concerning the Speakership, I must tell them that the next step also is up to them. According to Westminster practice, the Speaker is not only unopposed in the House at his election to the chair; in addition, he is not opposed in his constituency. In other words, if the Opposition really means business in its attempt to establish this convention, it will not run a candidate against you, Mr Speaker, in the next general election. The fate of the proposed new convention will be written on the ballot papers in the electorate of Scullin when next those good people go to their polling places.

I hope that the Opposition does make this next necessary move. It would be a pity, Sir, if the final parliamentary gesture of the retiring right honourable member for Bruce were wasted. His departing speech was gracious and, not to denigrate his other achievements in this place, nothing in his parliamentary life became him like the leaving of it. He will be much more kindly remembered on this side of the House than the man who replaced him as leader of the Liberal Party, the defeated Prime Minister, the retired right honourable member for Glamis.

I would like now to say a few words in honour of the gentleman who preceded me as the representative of the people of the electorate of Petrie. Mr John Hodges is a man who has exerted himself with courage and conviction in both the local and the national arena. He spent more than seven years as an alderman with the Redcliffe Council, including a period as vice-mayor, and nine years as a member of the Australian Parliament including almost one year as a Minister of the Crown. At the local level he will justly be remembered for a number of achievements.

John Hodges was involved in a number of community fund raising endeavours. He was active in the Salvation Army appeal, he contributed to the fund raising effort to establish the pensioners' hall at Redcliffe and he was chairman of the fund raising appeal for the Blue Nurses centre on the peninsula. He was and is patron of the last mentioned establishment, and when I visited that centre recently I was impressed by the extent to which he was held in esteem.

As would be expected, Mr Speaker, I disagreed with my predecessor on a wide range of issues and indeed that is the very reason that my constituents chose to send me here to represent their attitudes. However, I never at any time doubted the sincerity with which my opponent held the views he expressed during the election campaign and I wish him well in his return to private life. I have read in the newspapers that Mr Hodges intends to seek an important position within his party organisation. I wish him well in that arena also.

I should now like to inform the House of the political philosophy which motivates me. I believe that the purpose of government is to secure the greatest wellbeing of the greatest number of citizens. By 'wellbeing' I mean that condition of a person in which he or she is able to realise to the maximum whatever capacities he or she might have. Happiness is part of what constitutes human flourishing, but so are many other things without which that state of mind can still exist. People have been known to be happy although they were in ill health, impoverished and deprived of any outlet for the development of their talents. But a government would be a poor one indeed if it settled for that. Governments should strive, therefore, to create a situation in which their people are not merely happy but also healthy, prosperous and able to express and develop their talents and creative potential; and I do not mean health just for those who can afford the medical bills or prosperity just for those who inherit or claw their way to prosperity. Nor do I advocate only the self-expression of those whose abilities and talents are so outstanding that they are able to draw public attention. What my political philosophy requires is that governments should act so that every citizen has an equal opportunity to make of himself or herself the very best that he, or she, can.

It is quite obvious what governments can do in this respect. Governments cannot make people happy. That is not part of their business. But they can maximise their citizens' opportunities for finding happiness for themselves. They can, or could, eliminate poverty, minimise disease and fear of financial ruin caused by disease, and make education and training and satisfying leisure available to all . But in Australia today, more than anything else, an accident of birth determines a person's path through life. If you happen to be born into the right family in the right suburb, you will have at your disposal every ease and convenience of the post-technological elite. You will have excellent medical treatment and attend the most expensive school where you will meet all the 'in' people. You will meet those people again later, in boardrooms, at champagne breakfasts or perhaps at Liberal Party functions.

But if you, like most of the people in my electorate of Petrie, do not happen to be born into the right family and the right suburb, you will be up against it for most or all of your life. If you are lucky you will be struggling to pay off a mortgage, the payments on which get larger while the family housekeeping budget is eroded by uncontrolled price rises. If you are not so lucky, it is the rent that you will be worrying about rather than the mortgage and you will be wondering how long you will have a job to pay for it. If you are unluckier still , you will be a pensioner trying to make ends meet, while the uncontrolled price rises of the previous Government eat into the diminishing size of the fortnightly instalment of the insult you receive instead of the living wage which should be just reward of a life of service to Australia. And if you are unluckiest of all, you will be young, jobless, possibly homeless and surrounded by people who preach the virtues of hard work in much the same way as Marie Antoinette might have spoken of the delights of cake to people who did not even have bread.

Mr Speaker, the people of my electorate of Petrie know very well what I mean. My electorate has the largest proportion of home buyers in Queensland. Most of them have young families. In the suburbs of Arana Hills, Ferny Hills, Everton Hills, Albany Creek, Kippa Ring, Bald Hills and elsewhere in my electorate of Petrie, there are 22,240 young parents in traditional dual-parent households alone. Many have large mortgages and are struggling to give their children a decent life. Those children, Australia's greatest natural resource, will in future years be the backbone of this nation. They attend 47 government schools and 14 private schools in my electorate. But they are tomorrow's taxpayers and not only will they be paying the inflated retirement benefits of the former Prime Minister, whose life was obviously meant to be easy; they will also have to pay indirectly for the gracious living of every luxuriant speculator and every superannuated executive in the country, not to mention Australia's tithes to the multinational corporations that are bleeding the country dry. Yet these very children live with the insecurity of their parents who, under the policies of the previous Government, did not know how long they could afford their investment of a home. I promised these home buyers, in the name of the party I am proud to represent, that their conditions would be better under a Labor government than under a continuation of Liberal policies. I promised them that we would stimulate the housing industry and control interest rates. I look forward to telling them that that promise has been fulfilled.

In the suburbs of Scarborough, Clontarf, Redcliffe, Margate, Woody Point, Wavell Heights, Chermside and elsewhere in my electorate of Petrie there are, according to Social Security Department statistics, based on returns of the Redcliffe and Chermside regional offices, 17,293 age pensioners. The total figure for all pensioners in my electorate is 24,059. These people have suffered a shocking decline in their living standards over the past seven years. Age pensioners saw their income fall from nearly 25 per cent of average weekly earnings during the previous Labor Government to, at one stage, hardly more than 21 per cent. They are justifiably anxious to see this situation redressed. Many of these people voted for me because I promised them, on behalf of my party, that we would, within three years, restore their incomes to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

I believe that a decent retirement income is a right deriving from years of service to the community and in no way should it be seen as a gift of a charity. I am anxious that whatever the nation's deficit, and even if a consensus were achieved to the contrary, my constituents should receive their rights.

Especially in the suburbs of Aspley and West Chermside, and also in the suburbs of Geebung and Zillmere, as well as everywhere else in my electorate of Petrie, there are vast numbers of young people in their late teens and early twenties. According to the same Department of Social Security statistics that I quoted before, 6,616 people in my electorate do not have jobs. Most of them are young. They are intelligent, sensible and willing. They are unemployed because, at the Chermside Commonwealth Employment Service office, there are 9.6 registered unemployed for every job and at the Redcliffe CES there are 21.8 registered unemployed for each job. That is the worst ratio in the Brisbane metropolitan district. They, more than anyone else, are suffering from the former Government' s 'fight inflation first; unemployment last' policies. In almost every street in my electorate of Petrie there would be one young Australian whose reasonable demand for a job has not been met, and whose reasonable hopes for a career have been shattered. I am glad to be here supporting a Government that gives the very highest priority to job creation. But the scars of these last seven years will remain on the lives of thousands of my constitutents. This massacre of youth aspirations must not continue and it must never be repeated. As a Government we must appreciate, and this social system must learn, that we must either provide jobs for everyone who is capable of work or at least provide them with dignified and undenounced leisure.

Several of the maiden speakers so far have stated that they expect to serve the Parliament for many years to come. Considering the demography of the places that they represent, I believe that their expectations are justified. I will not make any extravagant predictions about my own tenure in this place, but I will say this: By the time I reach the age at which I would expect to enter retirement, we will be approaching the end of the first quarter of the twenty-first century. By then this Parliament, if it has not actually been replaced by a committee of survivors meeting in a radiation shelter, will be dealing with very different business. The Minister for Aviation will not, as he has been this week, be making announcements directed at improving the competitiveness of Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas. It is far more likely that the announcements will concern Australia's participation in inter-planetary travel. By then the Minister for Health will no longer be exerting himself to introduce a universal health insurance scheme. That will be an achievement of the past. It is possible that the issue will be the distribution of a medication which will halt or reverse the aging process, providing the possibility of indefinite youthful, fit and healthy life for all, without fear of death from diseases associated with advancement of age.

By the end of the first quarter of the twenty-first century, the news bulletins will not be full, as they were this week, of news of the first implantation of a freeze-thaw human embryo. By then it is more likely that we will be hearing reports of the first ectogenetic human birth, that is, the birth of a baby gestated and brought to developed human form in an artificial placenta entirely outside its mother's womb. Whether this-forgive the pun-ulitmate labour saving device is first announced in Australia or elsewhere in the world will to a large extent depend on the determinations of this Parliament.

By the end of the first quarter of the twenty-first centry, it is unlikely that this House will be smarting from the fact that the Premiers of Queensland and Tasmania chose to frustrate constitutional reform by stacking a constitutional convention. By then communications technology will have made us so completely one people that, apart from strong local government, this Parliament will be the only significant representative voice of our nation. Paradoxically, it will also make us so much part of the global community that we will at once be more closely in touch with both the sources of our heritage and the international forces shaping out destiny. The Premiers of Queensland and Tasmania, if such expensive and anachronistic sinecures are still held, will be of about as much interest to the twenty-first century as R2D2 to Darth Vader.

It might be thought odd that, in the middle of the worst depression since the 1930s, I am speculating about the future of the new world ahead; but it is not odd. The vision that we adopt as we emerge from the depression will help to determine the structure of the future. And the vision splendid of a new life in the space age full of excitement, fulfilment, human achievement and satisfying recreation, will be next to worthless unless it is a vision of a future in which all will share. Whatever gadgets, trinkets, frolics and prosperities the twenty- first century may deliver, it is our task to ensure that we do not repeat the injustices of the past and make them the privileges of an elite.

Mr Speaker, just as our planet is anchored in its orbit by the gravity of its whole mass, and would be thrown out of that orbit if any part of it were lost, so our nation is anchored in history by the contributions, passive as well as active, of every one of its citizens. In this metaphor, every individual is equally important. I have a vision of the future in which every individual has an equal opportunity for happiness in life. At present we are far from it. The world we live in at the moment is much bleaker.

The lives of the people I represent could well be much less stressful and much more fulfilling than, through no fault of their own, they are at the moment. To ask for a satisfying career, a secure home, or a dignified retirement is not, I would have thought, an unreasonable request. But these are the very things that many of the people of my electorate of Petrie do not have. It was precisely because their very reasonable desires were not being met that they voted to send me here. My constituents seek only those things which should be the birthright of every Australian. Mr Speaker, I will not rest until they have their birthright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — This Government has been in office for just over two months-not very long, but long enough for us to see how it operates. I invite honourable members to look at what we have. We have an Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) and a Defence Minister (Mr Scholes) who send Royal Australian Air Force fighters to spy on a sovereign State of the Commonwealth. We have an Attorney-General who dismisses his actions by saying: 'It seemed a good idea at the time'. We have a Defence Minister who does not know what he is talking about, wastes the time of the Parliament during Question Time and then has to come back later and say: 'I did not know what I was talking about'.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the extraordinary situation that, on the one hand, the Government promises that the Australian Broadcasting Commission will become more independent while, on the other, one senior Minister, Senator Button, makes an outrageous attack under privilege on the integrity of the Chairman of the ABC, and the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) leaves the future of the ABC board in doubt. We have a Special Minister of State (Mr Young) responsible for the Australian Federal Police, who was too busy to bother about representations for increasing the strength of that police force, but who comes in here and uses the Government's numbers to deny us the democratic right to talk about legislation. Quite obviously he is old blucher boots himself.

We have a Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who goes around the country denigrating the status of our capital cities and of our national emblems. We have classic bungling in administration, with the permanent head of the Department of Territories and Local Government being transferred without his or his Minister's knowledge. We have a half-baked wages policy that tells the unions they cannot have wage rises beyond those set in the national wage case, but can make up the losses by increased allowances. We have also a Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who extols the virtue of consensus and co-operation but cannot deliver the goods.

We have a Minister for Communications and a Minister assisting him, Senator Button, who do not communicate with one another. One had only to look at the television program Nationwide tonight to know that. Mr Speaker, quite obviously the only thing that the Government has going for it is you. You have done very well and I congratulate you on your election.

The Government's record is not very impressive. Where is the evidence of consensus and co-operation in the Government's decision to scrap pre-Budget consultations with all interested sections of the community, in favour of its Economic Planning Advisory Council? Where are the constituents about whom the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells) spoke-the women, the children, the unfortunate in society? At least the last Government gave them the opportunity to come along and talk to it and acted in regard to their wants in its Budget.
Where is the evidence of consensus and co-operation in the building industry or the shearing industry? The Prime Minister, in his rural policy speech on 20 February, said:

I have committed my Government to industrial relations policies which I believe will vastly improve the general industrial climate in Australia; and in putting those policies into effect, we will be particularly mindful of the interests of primary producers.

What about the interests of primary producers in the current shearers dispute? What about the interest of our $2 billion a year wool export industry, which accounts for 10 per cent of our total export earnings? What has the Government done to protect these interests? Virtually nothing. I will return to the shearers dispute in a moment. Firstly, however, I want to look at this Government's agricultural policies and where they currently stand. I must say it is a pity that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is overseas and will miss these first two weeks of parliament because there are several important questions that need urgent answers.

Throughout the election campaign, the Australian Labor Party issued promise after promise for primary producers. But the vast majority of its proposals were unspecific; they were more like first drafts than finely tuned policies. Since the election we have heard nothing more about some very important aspects of these policies. For example, let us look at drought. There is still a very serious situation in Australia despite good general rains in recent weeks in the eastern States. But the effects of the drought will be felt for a very long time to come. Farmers need to know now where they stand in terms of what continuing assistance they might expect from the Hawke Government. The Prime Minister said, again in his rural policy speech, obviously before the election:
A responsible Australian government should be looking beyond the present devastating drought.

I could not agree more. But what have we heard from this Government about drought aid since it came to office? Absolutely nothing of any consequence. The Minister for Primary Industry announced that pumpkin and citrus pulp would be eligible for the fodder subsidy. The Prime Minister, in answer to a question in the House on Tuesday, said only that his Minister was preparing a review of drought relief measures for early consideration by the Government. That is simply not good enough. There is the prospect of drought declarations being lifted in some areas in the near future. Farmers need to know what assistance they can expect in those circumstances. In particular, I ask: Will the Commonwealth continue the fodder and interest payments subsidies beyond the lifting of drought declarations? Farmers want and need to know these answers now . There is not time for the Minister to come back from overseas and prepare a review for government consideration.

What has happened to the specific promises on drought made by the Labor Party during the election campaign? We were promised additional drought aid measures. Where are they? What are they? When will they be introduced? What about the promise to utilise a range of tax rebates to encourage producers to protect themselves against drought? Where is the explanation of what that means? What are the rebates and when can farmers start using them again? We have heard absolutely nothing about this promise. The coalition Government introduced a concession whereby farmers could write off in full, in the year of expenditure, the cost of providing dams, bores and water reticulation facilities. This was specifically to help farmers build up their capacity to withstand drought. Will this Government maintain that concession or not? In the context of the Government's election promise it is a highly relevant question and one which the Government should answer forthwith. Where is the promised new drought section within the Department of Primary Industry? Where is the promised national drought consultative committee? All of these things were promised in the election campaign. Because of the gravity of the drought, especially at that time, they are promises that should have been acted on with the utmost urgency as soon as the Government assumed office. But we have heard virtually nothing. The silence poses the question: Now that we have seen some rain, have these promises been quietly scuttled?

It is not only promises on drought that have not been enlarged upon. The whole document on policies for agriculture is littered with unspecific promises about which we have heard absolutely nothing more from the Hawke-led Government. How will the Government set up its promised national meat inspection service, especially if the great State of Queensland so admirably led by Joh Bjelke- Petersen continues to oppose the concept? Will we see an attempted overriding of States' rights or might it be like the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) said in the other place today when questioned about not interfering in the Wran scandal in New South Wales? He said that it was a State matter. It was not a State matter when the Government interfered in the sovereign responsibilities of Tasmania. The Prime Minister has said:
Labor is pledged not to impose a sales tax or an excise tax on wine.

Is that an open-ended commitment for the next three years, forever or for the next 12 months only, or what? We want to know. When will we see the promised agricultural attaches in Japan, Korea, the Middle East and South East Asia? Will we deny the Korean people the opportunity to come here and contribute to improving the lifestyle of the Australian people, as the Treasurer, the Honourable Paul Keating, denied the Korean people the right to be involved in the preparation of the gas pipeline? The Government has rejected the previous Administration's five-year $640m national water resources program: In favour of what? In favour of studying an independent report. How long will we have to wait before such a program is implemented? What sort of money will be put into it?

Has the Department of Primary Industry yet taken over responsibility for the administration of quarantine from the Department of Health? What is meant by Labor's recognition that there is an urgent need for changes in the way wool promotion is funded? Will growers have to pitch in more money for wool promotion ? Will the Government provide $28m towards funding for wool promotion next year, as our Government promised and would have delivered? Will it keep funding for wool promotion on a three-yearly basis? What is the future of the live sheep export trade? Given the Government's preference for the export of carcass instead of live sheep, will the Government cave in to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union as it caved in to the shearers union? Will this $6m a year export industry cease?

Mr Speaker, you have been around this place for a long time. You know that all of these questions are vital questions. They are but a handful of the sorts of questions that immediately need to be answered and clarified by the Government. Farmers have a right to know the answers. The Labor Party cannot expect to come into office with a great ream of unspecified policies and a heap of rhetoric and be allowed to sit on its laurels. The Minister for Primary Industry said in Brisbane last week that he and his Department would take a much greater leadership role in the formation of rural policies than did the previous Government. I ask: What is the point of taking a geater role if the policies are never implemented, as seems to be the destiny of the bulk of the election promises? More importantly, does the Minister mean that he intends implementing policies without prior consultation with industry? It would certainly appear so, because in his policy for the beef and sheep meat industries he condemned the previous Government for awaiting industry consensus. Maybe he should get his line of communication established with the Prime Minister who believes in consensus. The present Minister for Primary Industry does not believe in industry consensus. The Prime Minister's great words about national consensus are being thrown to the winds daily, even by his own Ministers. Consensus was heralded as a major achievement of the recent Economic Summit. Let me say immediately that no one is criticising that objective. The trouble is that the so-called spirit of consensus generated at the Summit is now falling apart less than one month after its discovery.

Let us talk about the Constitutional Convention held in Adelaide where the Government talked about consensus. On not one occasion did members of the Australian Labor Party break ranks. They did not agree with a proposition put up by anyone else. That is not consensus. Yet, they condemned us for not agreeing to their proposals. I cannot understand it. If only one man had enough intestinal fortitude to stand up and be counted and break from the pattern that was established-one in all in-I would have been a little bit happier to say that at least there was one member of the Australian Labor Party who could think for himself and who was not a robot. The spirit of consensus is falling apart because of the attitudes of some elements of the trade union movement and because of the inability of the Government to maintain the momentum. As Mr Spicer of the Victorian Employers Federation pointed out, a growing number of militant trade unions are wrecking the spirit of the Summit. But neither the Prime Minister, nor any of his Ministers, nor the Australian Council of Trade Unions seem to be in the slightest bit interested in trying to rein in these union elements. The truth is, of course, that the Government cannot. It has an accord with the unions, and it is becoming clearer day by day that under that accord the Government is nothing more than a puppet and the unions are pulling the strings.

In the case of the shearers strike, for example, sections of the Australian Workers Union are being allowed to threaten the entire industrial relations system of this country-and they are being encouraged by the Government. By refusing to accept two decisions of the Arbitration Commission, sections of the AWU are flouting the law and thumbing their noses at rulings given by the highest industrial court in our country. The Government should be supporting the rulings of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, instead of supporting the right of the union to have the case heard, yet again, for a third time. How many times does the Commission have to rule on an issue before its decision is accepted by the union and the Government? The Commission has ruled twice on this dispute. The Wool Council of Australia is prepared to give a written undertaking, registered in the Commission, not to alter shearers' pay rates for the use of wide combs, and it is also prepared to talk with the union and the Government over alleged anomalies concerning the employment of New Zealand shearers.

There is absolutely no reason for sections of the AWU to hold out any longer, and there is absolutely no reason why the Government should support the union's application for a further hearing. The hearings have been held, and the decisions have been given. Those decisions should be accepted and upheld. The truth is that the Government has copped out, shirked its responsibility. Caucus has said: 'Look, we can't touch this one, we'll upset our union brothers; let's leave it all to the Arbitration Commission and let the Commission cop the flak'.

The Government has already shown itself to be incapable and inept. Its legislative program, as outlined to the Parliament by the Governor-General, is totally inadequate. Such is the importance that this Government attaches to primary industry that it allowed for 53 1/2 seconds in the Governor-General's Speech-five paragraphs-for this vital section of our national economy.

It is abundantly clear already that the Government will not live up to many of its election promises. Already this Government is guilty of perpetrating a fraud on the great Australian nation and its people.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Royal Commission of Inquiry into the 1982 General Elections in Fiji

PROCTEXT.PARA: Royal Commission of Inquiry into the 1982 General Elections in Fiji
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the adjournment to raise a question regarding a constituent of my electorate, Ms Rosemary Gillespie, who has been requested to attend a royal commission in Fiji. The royal commission is the Royal Commission of Inquiry into the 1982 General Elections in Fiji. The sections of its terms of reference which concern Rosemary Gillespie are:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether Ms Rosemary Gillespie had first assisted the Alliance (through Carroll and also directly), but later took documents from Carroll and obtained the 'red file' and supplied them to ABC television, the National Times, and the National Federation Party.
(1) Whether the alliance commissioned the Carrol Report;
(2) whether some or all of the recommendations contained in the Carroll Report were implemented, deliberately or otherwise, by the Alliance Party;
(3) whether Clive Speed-
(a) was appointed on Carroll's recommendation, and
(b) was appointed to, and did in fact, assist in the Alliance's election campaign, and
(c) had his salary paid (directly or indirectly) by the Australian Government;

(4) whether the ABC people involved in producing the 'Four Corners' television programme (and the persons involved in writing the National Times article) collaborated with the National Federation Party both in the content of and the time of release of, that programme.

I raise this matter tonight for the following reasons: In order that the Government may be aware that one of its citizens is required to attend the inquiry; and secondly to ask the Australian Government for legal aid for Ms Gillespie or at least to ensure that she is adequately represented at the inquiry.

The names of two other persons were mentioned among the issues raised for discussion. They were Mr A. Carroll and Mr Clive Speed. Mr Carroll is employed by Business International, an organisation with a reputation for involving itself in the affairs of governments within the Asian region-and this includes the former Australian Liberal Government. Mr Speed is a former Australian Broadcasting Commission journalist who in 1982 worked for the Fijian Prime Minister. I would now like to read a section of a letter which would seem to be signed by Mr Alan Carroll. It states:
Following these recommendations--
Mr Carroll earlier in the letter listed a number of recommendations to the Government of Fiji-

I am happy to note the appointment of Mr Ishmail Bose to the party until the next election. We were pleased to arrange contacts and details of a short study program by Mr Bose with the Australian Liberal Party.
He then went on to talk about Clive Speed. He said:

Following these recommendations we were pleased also at your request to search for and recommend a journalist of exceptional talent to work in media relations with the Government. Mr Clive Speed, Executive Producer, Current Affairs for the Australian Broadcasting Commission who is strongly recommended to you as one of Australia's most mature and experienced working journalists . . .

Does this mean that the Federal Liberal-National Party Government, through Mr Allan Carroll, interfered directly or indirectly in the 1982 Fijian elections? There is proof that Mr Speed reported to Mr Carroll on a regular basis in the period prior to the Fijian elections and that he sent written reports on the performance of the Fijian Prime Minister, Ministers and the political parties involved.

I conclude by asking the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley), who is sitting at the table, to ascertain from the Government whether the Fraser Liberal Government allocated $50,000 to the Fijian Government towards the cost of Mr Speed's employment, thus enabling a person to be employed by and to spy on the Government of the day.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 11.48 p.m.
